description:
Was not feelings good and wanted something soupy, so I thought I'll check this place out. 

Let me start by saying that it's location is not the most ideal, at least to me. A lot of homeless people here, so I wouldn't consider it super safe. None the less, it had the best ratings out of the other Pho places so I thought I'll try it out. 

I can safely say their PHO is AMAZING!!!!! 

I ordered noodles with pho with rare beef and beef balls. And the beef balls were tender, the broth was really tasty. Have to add that their portion was a bit bigger than other pho places too. Will definitely be coming back again and recommend it to my friends. 

Also I have to mention, the SERVICE was the best I have ever seen at a pho place. The waiters and waitresses were super nice, had a smile on their face. I asked for a few things and the waitress happily brought the items for me. 

So all in all it was a great experience. 

A big thank you to the restaurant and keep it up!!!
author: Shanzay H.

description:
What an unforgettable experience...

The Experience:

Again its Friday and I came here with some coworkers (17 of us). I was really worried that we wouldn't all fit into the restaurant based on the picture on Yelp. We got to Miss Saigon early in hopes to beat the lunch rush. We waited for a few minutes and was lead to the back of the restaurant and down a flight of stairs to a private room. We were all seated and served with water and menu and the interesting experience begins...

One of my coworker was looking for the restroom, about to go up the stairs she suddenly came to a halt at the staircase. I looked over and realized onions were rolling down the stairs. As we ordered our food we realized the lights were being dimmed... I mean... I guess its romantic to set to tone, but I was with my coworkers and I didn't want to eat up my nose in the dimmed lights. Then a waiter came in and turned on the karaoke machine! All of a sudden we had these karaoke songs playing in the background and random karaoke scenes on the TV. You'd think thats all but theres more! A few moments later the disco ball turned on and started spinning!!! A waiter came in and brought a fan to blow our way cause it was slightly warm in the room. At this point, we cannot even strike a conversation cause we are all so distracted and amusing by the surroundings. WOW Miss Saigon 6/5 on the experience, it is one I will never forget. 

The Food:

We all ordered a variety of food, I ordered the lemongrass pork with an egg on top. The food was good but to be honest I have had better lemongrass pork. I think it is a general San Francisco thing where its really hard to find good Vietnamese food in downtown. I thought the egg was just slightly over fried and the pork was just slightly hard to cut at places. The pork was fairly thin but at sections there were some fat which made it hard to cut. For the price there was decent amount of meat and honestly it was kind of hard for me to finish all of it at the end. Overall, I give my dish a 3.5/5

Many of my coworkers ordered Pho and they all seem to really like it and would give 4-4.5 stars. From what I heard the broth was really on point but the noodle and meat was ok. With that said the meat was very well cooked and easy to chew. 

With all that said, I would give Miss Saigon an overall 4 star review and would definitely come back again. Whats really nice is that they are able to hold large parties. Maybe you can get the same unforgettable experience as we did.
author: Nina Y.

description:
EVENT: When you just want a bowl of pho or bun bo hue - come here! Seriously my go to place for the past 2 years living around the Mission Bay Area... but now that I've moved.... I miss you :(

PARKING: Super hard to find, but always some how ... find a spot and just walk thru some streets

FOOD/DRINKS:
(1) Pho: I've tried most of the pho-s here! Lots of meat! I love how they slice the beef thins! Mmm
(2) Bun Bo Hue: one of my favs! Love the blood! I love how they have the option with beef thins, rarely do you see that option. I alway add extra blood! SO GOOD! Broth is excellent with lots of flavorful layers~

OVERALL: I miss this place! My go to... for the longest time. Now, that I live else where.. I can only miss it. 5 stars for good pho & BBH memories!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Came by for lunch the other day and it was a delicious one! Despite being in a rather sketchy part of SF, the food was quite delicious although there was some faint putrid smell upon arrival...aye.

Started off with the salt and pepper calamari which was heavenly. Lightly fried with fresh oil and lightly seasoned with salt and pepper! The highlights were the raw white and green onions!!!

Moved on to the Salt & Pepper prawns with garlic noodles. The prawns were decent sized, lightly battered and fried. The garlic noodles were tasty too, although a touch heavy!

The crab egg rolls reminded me of Vietnam with real crab on the inside! Yum! They use the rice paper rolls, like in Vietnam, vs. the egg roll wrappers elsewhere!

Had the Thai tea which was strong and flavorful too!

Service was fantastic by the staff!
author: Derek S.

description:
Miss SaiGon is in an interesting location outright bordering the Tenderloin but down the street are high rise modern apartments. Strange, but what's new about SF. When you walk in you'll be greeted by a mannequin and a lot of colorful neon lights. I did wish my pho was not tinted neon green, but it was a welcome warmth after battling the SF Fogust.

Pho itself was decent although the taste might be different to some- this broth is a little more on the sweeter side. Lots of noodles! I was pretty satisfied with the meal and service. There are also bathrooms in the back.
author: Crystal N.

description:
Miss SaiGon does its job if you have a craving for Vietnamese food. Yes it's in the Tenderloin but if you're in the area, it serves its purpose.

Eat pho or banh mi or whatever you desire and go right back to life. There's really not much else to say.
author: Derek T.

description:
6 stars actually for choosing to pay Abba the respect it deserves. After all, what could be more Vietnamese than eating your Pho while having Mamma Mia / Waterloo / Dancing Queen playing in the background?

Also jokes aside though, Miss SaiGon was in my experience the best pho I've had in San Francisco so far and second only to Madame Vo's in New York (although Miss SaiGon is substantially cheaper). 

Pho is a relatively (composition speaking) simple dish. A simple clean broth paired with rice noodles and a protein of choice. Thai basil and bean sprouts can be added according to preference. That being said though, because Pho is such a simple dish, elevating it to a point where it makes a distinct impression requires a substantial amount of effort. 

The first effort Miss SaiGon makes is to play Abba, which has been scientifically shown to elevate any dining experience by exactly 26.7% The second effort is to utilize good protein. Most pho places have a tendency to either skimp out on the meat that they use, or use poor quality meat. Another common mistake is to mistime the place of the undercooked filet into the broth, and plating up a borderline raw piece of meat.

Miss SaiGon manages to avoid these classic mistakes by utilizing good quality beef and beef balls, as well as having a strong flavorful soup. Rice noodles can be difficult because although they have a fantastic texture, in terms of flavor they really don't have quite as strong of a starchy flavor. This works well with pho, because its meant to be such a clean dish, but it also forces restaurants to create broths that are both pure and impactful in terms of flavor. This is tremendously difficult to do, especially since creating a good broth requires substantial time and effort both in gently cooking the ingredients and skimming.

The short of it is that what Miss SaiGon doesn't lack in effort. And for a layman's dish such as pho, effort is what really shines here. Having the opportunity to eat here was really a tremendous experience. 

(-.5 stars for the slightly startling statue in the front though, although in retrospect is pairs well with the music they were playing.)
author: Samuel W.

description:
Cute place! I'm a big fan of colorful lights.

Crab rangoon was crispy and very creamy. The combination beef pho I ordered was alright. The meat was above average, but the noodles sort of stuck together, and I thought the broth was a bit sweet. Still, I'd come again.

Walking there is a bit scary. Will probably only go for lunch next time.
author: Serena J.

description: On a recent visit to SF, my sis and I stopped by here for lunch. We ordered the chicken wings and my sis got the regular steak pho and i ordered the bun bo hue.  The chicken wings were small, but tasty. My sister liked her pho, but I didn't enjoy my bun bo hue, because all I could taste was freezer burn. I'm almost sure it was from the meat, but regardless, I give my overall dish a thumbs down.
author: Jenny B.

description: Overall, good Vietnamese food for the price.  Service is very friendly, and the pho is good (would be 5 stars if the soup were more authentic / less seasoning).  The lettuce-warppde eggrolls are particularly delicious! :)
author: Colette C.

description:
It was a cold Sunday afternoon in SF and while walking around Spark Social in foggy weather, I was trying to figure out what would be something good to eat for dinner. Luckily I remembered that pho would be an ideal heartwarming dinner after freezing in the fog!

I ordered the Pho Dac Biet from here and was quite pleased. One interesting thing to note is that the broth here is slightly sweeter than other traditional pho broths I've had around the bay area. The rice noodles were good - they were not served in the bowl as a clump of noodles stuck together (some Vietnamese restaurants do this and it just throws off the whole meal). There was also a good amount of meat! There was brisket, tendon & beef balls. 

If you're craving pho in SF, I'd recommend coming here.
author: Henry W.

description: First of all I absolutely love the decor, I mean if you are going to go kitschy might as well go all the way. Their vegetarian pho was yummilicois. It is now my favorite Vietnamese place in SF. I look forward to checking out more items on their menu..
author: Nils H.

description: I think A-OK about sums this place up.  Stopped by for dinner when I was in the area and craving some Pho.  Not the greatest Pho I've have but it was decent.  The decor is interesting to say the least.  And they were playing every music video ABBA ever created on the single TV. There was one waiter taking care of the whole restaurant.  To say he was rude and unhelpful would be an understatement.
author: Paul W.

description:
What a disappointment. 

I'm pretty bummed that I'm writing this because the food actually tasted pretty good. I ordered from here through Caviar and even though it took awhile to get delivered, it was still pretty good.

The beef was seasoned well and the garlic noodles were just awesome. Unfortunately, I couldn't even finish my food because I found a freakin HAIR in it. I barely ate 1/3 of my lunch and I had to toss it out. So unfortunate. I was super hungry too.. 

Honestly, no matter how good the food is, it's a red flag when you find a hair in your food. Made me want to throw up everything I ate. I don't think I'll be ordering from here ever again. Makes me so sad because I really wanted to support their business but what a bummer. It's just not appetizing to find a hair in your food. Says a lot about the restaurant and their cleanliness.
author: Anna D.

description: Always a go to when I'm in downtown area. Super friendly staff and super fast service. This place definitely reminds me of home cooked meals. Price is a little high because of the quality of the food. You gotta try the Pho Tai Mem (Filet Mignon) it's amazing!!! Highly recommend!
author: Billy N.

description:
3.5*

Ordered takeout food here. I had higher expectations due to its high ratings. Their pho broth was a bit too sweet. I also ordered the Bun Thit Nuong Cha. Came with a lot of fish sauce and chili garlic (on the side). The eggroll stayed crispy, but my scallions were soggy.
author: Helen C.

description: We were in the area and found this spot for some dinner. I ordered a regular bowl of pho with medium rare beef ($9.50). The bowl of pho was pretty good with an even amount of ingredients and tasty broth. This place is not shabby, but nothing too special to get me coming back either. Also, my friend's Banh Xeo took so long to come out. We were pretty much done with our bowls of soup before he was able to eat.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
We came here on a Sunday around 11am, and there was plenty of seating around so we're quickly seated. The place has an interesting mix of decorations.

Food: 4/5
We quickly chose the 20 combo beef pho $11 and 29b rice noodles with pork, shrimp, Crab stick and quail egg with soup on the side $11.50 as well as a banh Xeo $8.25. We did a Yelp check in and got 2 free spring rolls. This was definitely too much food for the two of us and I got the spring roll to go. The portions are pretty big, although there's not as much meat as I would like in the combo pho. The banh Xeo was nice and crispy.

Service: 4/5
The food came out quick and we didn't have to wait long when we wanted the check.

Cleanliness: 3.5/5
Decently clean. The bathroom is small and isn't as clean as I would like...

Would I come back? Yes, it's a decent place...
author: Gilda W.

description:
Best pho in town, hands down. 

I've been to every place there is, so trust me, I know what I'm talking about.  

Just make sure you order the filet pho, if you want the best. 

Aside from that, everything else is very good. I actually had a buddy of mine say he had the best mock chicken he'd ever had there and when I tried it, I don't even like fake meat and I couldn't stop eating it.

They have fresh juice, cheap beer, great jasmin tea. A really varied menu with something for everyone.

The ambiance is great, very colorful and they like to play fun tv shows about animals or movies or whatever they feel like. When you go there you get a feeling like you're in their living room, and I like that. It's very family-oriented. Xmas time is great around there.

Even if I didn't love the food, which I do, the service is what I come back for.

Me and my girlfriend have been going here for almost two years, and the servers have grown to know who we are. Every time we go they know what we want and bring it out without us saying barely a word. Occasionally they'll bring out a complimentary desert. 

Showing appreciation for loyalty is something I think is rare these days in SF and I can't say how much I appreciate that kind of relationship with my neighborhood restaurants.

We feel bad because they bring us the bean/milk pudding desert a lot and we don't like beans so we eat around the beans lol. The banana bread one is awesome though, that's our favorite.
author: John W.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised & quite delighted actually by Miss Saigon... it's in the sketchier of places but it's gorgeous inside. I was desperately craving pho & there is a lacking of Vietnamese restaurants (where you can sit and eat comfortably) in the area; 6th/mission street/Soma. Anyway at first glance the soup looked a bit oily but it was actually super delicious. I loved the red onion in it and condiments were plentiful with lovely veg, bean sprouts, and basil. To my surprise I finished it off.

The menu was quite big & quality was definitely on point so I will be back. I've found a gem & I'm glad I finally went in. The fab pho challenges me to try the other items on the menu. Cheers to Miss Saigon!

One of my new favourite lunch spots in the area!
author: Julian I.

description:
For awhile, we were ordering here almost once a week because it is pretty reliable, the food is always delicious, and it is pretty quick!  Generally, we order on Yelp and go pick it up. 

The Pho: The broth is pretty tasty!  Because we take it to go, we try to get the pho where the meat is already cooked.  They do a good job packaging all of the items to go.  

Vermicelli: The vermicelli is pretty good as well!  The meat is always tender and nicely flavored.  

I'm definitely a fan and whenever I go pick up food, there are always people eating in and others picking up, so I think the crowds have spoken in that this is definitely a solid place for a bowl of pho!
author: Lynne T.

description:
Had delivery of the noodle dish with egg roll and pork. Was perhaps the worst version of that dish that I had. Tiny portion and tiny egg roll. Highly suggest you go to Ti lan a bit further up on 6th towards market. 

Give them 3 stars because their other dishes are good.
author: reza n.

description:
UPDATE: as expected, this has become my husband's favorite Vietnamese joint and I've tried almost every vegan-friendly dish on the menu. I'm still not impressed with the delivery service, but if you dine in, this place is 5-stars. My favorite is the vegan shaken beef dish (comes with veggie meat). The coconut curry is delicious as well. Heck, even their tofu spring rolls are salty enough that they require zero peanut sauce (which is good since they add fish sauce to the peanut sauce). 

Vegans/Vegetarians - double check that your dish will not come with fish sauce or beef stock, since they DO cook with both and WILL use it if your meal usually comes with it. This is true even in veggie dishes, unless you specify. 

I love the food at Miss SaiGon and recommend it. I just don't recommend delivery. Pick up is fast and easy if you double park on Mission.
author: Shannon H.

description:
A solid 3 star pho restaurant. Not sure why it was so crowded considering that their pho isn't all that great. I ordered the Pho Dac Biet (combo pho) and the first thing I noticed was how glistening it was. There was a good layer of oil on there which I thought was kinda disgusting. I was worried that the broth was going to be unflavorful as many reviewers stated, but it was okay, it just lacked any dimension and depth other restaurants (i.e. Pho 2000) have. While they are generous with their portions, I noticed a lack of tendon in my bowl. In addition, they use red onion here instead of the typical white onions that many pho recipes call for. 

Also, there's no hoisin bottle at each table which I thought was strange. They bring out individual small plates with hoisin bottle already squeezed in. 

Overall, the food here is just okay. It's one of those places where you would go if you were desperate for pho.
author: Eva L.

description:
Been going here for yeeeears and they have been consistently excellent in my book.

The bun bo hue, the vermicelli, the pho ga, imperial rolls, yummy, yummy, yummy!

***This place is NOT sketchy, YOU are!
author: Tina T.

description:
After a Wednesday happy hour with my co-hort girlfriends at Per Diem, we were craving something warm on a chill night. I wanted Little Sheep, but as my friends recent had hotpot, we opted for Miss SaiGon (as I am not a fan on Tu Lan, and Turtle was closed).

It is walk-able from Per Diem (about a 13 min walk) but we were lazy and grabbed an uber, and before you know it, we were across the street from Miss SaiGon. 

We were seated right away, as it was not too busy (got busier after we finished around 8). After checking the menu, we all decided to get #20, the pho with combo beef. It does not say what is in the combo, but it had the usual (brisket, raw sliced beef and maybe a little bit of tendon). The broth was good (though a little bit more oil on the top than I am use to, but it wasn't heavy) and I wish there was so tripe or bigger piece of tendon. I also would prefer to have the little dishes to make my own combo of sauce (they bring it pre sauced for you), but overall, it was a good noodle dish at $11.50.

Compared to other Vietnamese place, this place is more expensive that other, though the broth is good. I do wish for the meat to be a bit bigger, instead of super thin slices of tendon. I would come back to try to bun bo hue, but I am a bit of a bun bo hue snob, as I have had really good versions in Oakland.
author: Mei L.

description:
My favorite pho in the city so far. (Have tried Pho 2k and a few others.) Area is a bit sketchy at night but the food/service were great. Egg/Imperial rolls a little overpriced and would skip next time.

Their Vietnamese coffee is also pretty good!
author: Steven L.

description: No one will seat you. I had to run after waiters to get a table. Completely forgot about our order. Waited 20 min for the food. The pho is not even hot. Had to return it. Noodle is completely over cooked. Soft and soggy. No redeeming quality for this. Never coming back.
author: Eric L.

description: There's something about their broth that makes it insanely delicious and flavorful, and their secret is probably tons of MSG. Miss Saigon hands down makes the best pho I've ever had. Their noodle and meat portions are more generous than the average pho restaurant, but the soup is definitely what puts this restaurant at the top tier level in pho making. As my coworker would say, "This is so good that I could cry."
author: Victoria T.

description: 15 minute wait for a sandwich, only three people in the entire restaurant, which is more than the number if pieces of chicken in this light-as-a-feather sandwich that's over 50% more expensive than Saigon Sandwich a few blocks away. Hard pass.
author: Mike V.

description:
3.5 STARS

For our office lunch on Friday, September 1st, I decided to try Miss Saigon. (Our company provides three restaurant options a week and each employee just picks a restaurant. We're provided the choices a week prior and auto check out is typically the day before.) Our delivery order arrived via Caviar around 11:45am.

I was in the mood for noodles and meat, so I got the Mi Toi Bo Luc Lac (Lunch): Shaken beef (filet mignon) served with garlic noodle ($16.50). It was a hefty portion. The meat was tender and the noodles comforting. Good amount of garlic flavor. They also had a nice chew. I asked for extra sides of hot sauce and they gave me three sides. Enough for the amount of beef and noodles I ate, but if I finished the whole thing, I'd probably want more.

I'd love to try their soups once day as most of the reviews are about their noodle soups. Maybe when Miss Saigon comes around again.
author: Elena N.

description:
I had the Vietnamese sandwich here with a spring roll. For being in San Francisco, the restaurant did smell and look like a Vietnamese restaurant, and the food tasted pretty authentic, without any odd adjustments to it.

That being said, the food was just okay. The sandwich was good, but it's not really something to write home about. Being in San Francisco, I will probably be back since the selection of Vietnamese food around here is rather poor, but overall there isn't anything about this place that truly stands out besides it being the only decent option in town.

The bread was decent, the meat had that slightly fatty, slightly fishy smell. The spring roll was fresh tasting, and overall not too bad.
author: Tyler T.

description: The food was absolutely 100% delicious. I had an UberEATS customer cancel on me so I got to keep an order from here. Honestly I hadn't eaten Vietnamese food before but I think I'll be coming back here again soon.
author: Isaac S.

description:
When I walk in here, I like I'm back to my youth. They play old school Vietnamese music and the kind of songs you find in old asain karaoke places. Even the movies they play in the TV are subtitled in Vietnamese. It's a very nostalgic experience.

My two favorite dishes to order here:

Bun Bo Hue with the pork blood
Cha Gio - Fried egg rolls - because they use the clear rice paper wrappers instead of the yellow ones and comes with all the greens to wrap
Bu Luc Lac - shaking beef
author: Song C.

description: Good looking bun rieu.. but wasnt taste like real bun rieu... need more crab paste.... the smell is good though... i didnt like the coffee either.... 3 stars for cleaning looking reataurant... not the food...
author: Michael P.

description:
Ahhhh, a Vietnamese place in the city open for dinner, sells my favorite Vietnamese dessert (che ba mau), and makes their egg rolls with delicate, yet super crispy rice paper.  I was milling around FiDi on a Friday night when I got hit with the sudden craving of banh mi.  Most banh mi places in the city close at 5, so I wasn't left with many options other than what my handy dandy Yelp told me what was open nearby.  

I had previously ordered delivery from Miss SaiGon, so I was interested in how this place would be as a sit down.  Friday night was PACKED.  Cheesy Vietnamese screensavers were rolling on the monitors, dated Christmas decorations still adorned the walls in March, and table runners, employees, owners, and disapproving Vietnamese ladies were running around me furiously serving tables.  This Vietnamese place had the adequate amount of chaos to make me feel at home.  I ordered a banh mi thit nuong, and I was happy to find that the baguette was crisp with a hearty butt (my bocadillo/baguette people know what's up), easy on the lard and pate, and no pig ears--this all was w/o modifications, and it's like they knew exactly how I take my banh mi.  The food made me feel very comforted, and I was so glad I stopped in.  I have to return to conquer the rest of the menu.
author: Crystal C.

description:
Worst restaurant that I've ever visit in my life.. place was a bit dirty and smelly. when I sit down i thought its because of body odour of someone who sat beside my table, but then they left and still smelly. 

we ordered pho with rare beef this one was okay a bit sweet, salty noodle with beef - just so so, chicken fried rice - this is the worst dish ive ever eaten in my life, half rice was mushy & uncooked, chicken was tasteless.. 

thats not even the worst part, when we asked for 4 small plates, they gave it to us stacked.. and the middle plates on that stacked was dirty, unwashed,and have a lots of leftover food.. I was so shocked and disgusted.. 

will never comeback..
author: Monica T.

description:
Garlic Noodles with Wings.
Great LunchBreak!
The Sandwiches Are Awesome and
the dinning room connected to the pool table and bar are Awesome.
author: Kosey T.

description: Best pho in town. Just like your granny in Saigon used to make. Large menu of other dishes too. Gracious attentive service and a funky decor. Food comes out fast but prepare for a wait to get in. There's always a line. Iffy neighborhood but worth the trip. Parking is problematic.
author: Kenneth O.

description: The best Vietnamese food in SF, in my opinion with incredible reasonable price, good service, quick seating time and friendly staff. The best bun bo hue you can find in the city! Super authentic and satiating!
author: Paulynn Y.

description:
Bun with grilled pork and egg roll is good here. Nothing spectacular but solid. Good ratio of vermicelli noodles to meat and greens (you'd be surprised that more and more places fail at that).

I like that there are vegetarian and vegan options here. 

We saw a table of young Vietnamese folks grubbin' on fried chicken wings. Wings and rice, that's it. There must be some secret menu we don't know about but damn, those wings were looking mighty succulent and amazing.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Food: 4/5
Space: 3/5
Service: 4/5

Came here on one of those days where you really need a bowl of Pho to get you through the day. When you walk in the decor throws you off a bit but it didn't take any of the awesome flavor out of the food. I really enjoyed my small bowl of Pho Dac Biet (pho beef combo) and paired it with a Chicken Banh Mi. Both were very tasty. Our waiter was really quick and attentive as well. The area around the restaurant isn't great but it's an awesome alternative to go your go-to Pho spot in the Tenderloin when you're in SoMa or need a change of scenery.
author: Derrick F.

description: I tried Garlic Fried noodles. They are slightly on the sweeter side that made me slightly uncomfortable after eating. To me, the food is like 3.5 stars. Other then that, the service is really good, the food came on time, ambiance is great and the prices are really good. Not a big fan of Vietnamese food so will probably won't visit gain.
author: Qasim Z.

description: We got pho and the Nam Vang dried noodles. They weren't very good. The place was pretty clean even though the veggies was not very fresh (see attached pic).
author: Neema C.

description: Jesus, quality has gone down these past years. I took my mom here thinking their food was great. And I was so disgusted and sad. Our food was cold. They were getting a lot of uber eats food and I'm guessing they are trying to meet demand and losing their quality. Definitely not coming here anymore.
author: Lynn C.

description: This place is a gem, solid Vietnamese food. I came here a bit hungover after a trip from Vegas (okay a lot hungover) and man did it cure me! I had the tofu pho and it was delightful and full of veggies with perfecto noddles! My BF had a vermicelli dish. He loved it, in fact he ate it so fast I didn't even get to try it! If you check in they also give you free spring rolls. Sweet deal! The staff is very friendly and the service is quick. The other major plus, this please is very reasonably priced. I'd stop in again next time I'm in the area.
author: Terese O.

description:
Tl;dr Pho gets 5 stars, location gets 2 stars. Great vegan options. 

I really like their pho, probably my favorite on the west coast. I get it delivered about once a week and make it to the restaurant whenever I can. I've also tried some of their meatless options, which are also fantastic (specifically the meatless shaken beef).

That brings me to the next point--location. It's in a sketchy part of town and walking there is always an adventure. 

The restaurant itself is definitely interesting, but appears to be clean and is comfortable. Can accommodate a larger party if you want to dine with family and/or friends. 

Service has always been good and haven't had any issues in the few times I've dined here. 

Overall, I highly recommend the Pho and food!
author: Thomas T.

description:
"OG style pho that keeps it 100 (6th street - because that's the address -_- )"

This is a legit Vietnamese place. Like the kind of place that when you walk in it smells like your friend's mom is cooking. They have a full menu with 100+ items (no hipster half stepping here)

For pho, you always have to get the highest number beef dish, which is the pho dac biet here (number 20). Yeah there's a lot of stuff you may not have eaten before, but be an adventurer! It's worth it.

Portions are good. Better in person than take out. Service is fast and nice. You can also walk up to the counter to pay (efficiency ++).

The place closes at 9:30, but maybe it's not the best idea to wander around the tenderloin past then anyway. When we were there during lunch a homeless guy wandered in and gave Miss Saigon a newspaper and shook her hand. 

Protip: if you feel extremely sick, like you can't even move. And Vicks vapor rub isn't doing its thing. Get two orders of pho from this place through Grubhub and call me in the morning.
author: Joel L.

description:
One of my favorite go-to Vietnamese places in the city, Miss Saigon is a great gem that has a huge menu, interesting decor that gets changed up every season, and a warm and attentive staff.

One of my favorite dishes has to be their 17b - fillet mignon phõ that has a rich but not overpowering soup that's always consistent. 

Although the general area does tend to be a little bit rough on the edges at night, the food is worth a visit.
author: Ka L.

description: We had two choices by us when deciding Viet food, Tu Lan or Miss Saigon. We decided on Miss Saigon. To be honest, I was a bit throw off by the decor of the restaurant, at the entrance of the place was a plastic mannequin dressed in Vietnamese dress, I was a little creeped out by it. We ended up ordering pho to go. There was plenty of noodles and beef, but I did not have enough soup. Overall tho, food was good, eating environment was. . . . different, I'm sure some people might like the decor.
author: Jie L.

description:
One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the city. I have always been getting their food through Doordash delivery. The deliveries have been really efficient and the food have always been well wrapped and packaged.

I really like their rice & vermicelli bowls. Their grilled chickens are pretty good. My favorite dishes from them are grilled lemongrass pork. The pork has always been well cooked -- juicy, flavorful and well seasoned. The portion is large for decent price. Recommend to check this place out!
author: Clare L.

description:
Definitely one of the top three phos I've ever had. The filet mignon pho had the most tender chunks of meat I've ever tasted in a pho and the broth was delightful. 

This was our first experience with imperial rolls so I don't have much to compare them to, but I read you're supposed to wrap them in lettuce and mint and eat them while they're piping hot. Ours came with one piece of lettuce... so what were we supposed to do with that? Share?! (Channeling Meryl Streep in Devil Wears Prada) 

The crab rangoons were sadly all cream cheese, hardly any crab... and maybe krab at that! For shame... 

Like I said, one of the best phos I've ever tasted; would like to try some of their other mainstays the next time I'm around. 

Finally the decor is quaint and they had ABBA music videos playing on loop which was a real delight for me lol
author: Rachel A.

description:
It was crowded when I came by Miss Saigon so I assumed the food must be great. Unfortunately the food did not impress me much. I got their large size filet mignon beef pho. While I liked the tender pieces of beef, it is the broth that makes or breaks the pho. The broth was simply not salty enough, and that is unheard of! This may be the first time I complain that a pho didn't have enough salt. To add insult to the injury, I was still hungry after finishing my large pho.

I would give points to the unique atmosphere of the restaurant though. There is a bunch of colorful lights, I felt like I was at EDC. Old pop songs was also playing in the background, which I actually enjoyed.
author: Wayne C.

description: It was the worst. A Vietnamese restaurant that senses racism. Even though Westerners first served food to us rather than Oriental, we did not give them water. I do not want to go again.
author: Minseong J.

description:
Not gonna lie, Miss SaiGon is in a sketchy neighborhood (especially at night) but if you're rolling in with a bunch of friends it's not so bad. 

But what's good is the food and the fact it doesn't look hole in the wall. 

We came in for a late dinner and it was almost closing time. They were still gracious enough to serve us. 

I ordered pho with beef balls and it came piping hot, the soup had a nice beefy flavor and lots of depth to it. The beef balls weren't actually balls but ground beef cut into cubes which was also fine with me. 

My pescatarian friends ordered vegetarian pho and enjoyed it. 

They even brought out a delicious and moist banana pudding dessert for us  Thank you Miss SaiGon for the great service and delicious food!
author: Nette T.

description:
i ordered pad thai... they should have mention in description that they dont know how to make padthai 

no falover at all... just white noodles AND 28$ ... wt* 

PLEASE REMOVE PAD THAI FROM YOUR FOOD MENU IF YOU DON'T KNOW HOW TO MAKE IT
author: Pradip M.

description: One of the best Vietnamese places in the city. So cozy, family run, and the pho is incredible. 27b is a good start. Their beef is all soft and well cooked. A Sf staple.
author: Nate W.

description:
A colleague of mine suggested we get out of the office and grab some food for lunch and when it's cold and gloomy outside what's better than a bowl of Pho? 

We found the closest pho restaurant we could find to our job and ended at Miss Saigon. It's definitely located near the rougher areas around market, and upon seating, I noticed a urine order which I'm not completely surprised about because of the area. 

They had complimentary springs rolls if you checked in so you know I had to take advantage of that! Pho came out piping hot which I really enjoyed. I got the combination pho and flavor-wise it wasn't the normal bowl of pho I'm accustomed to-definitely had a different flavor to it but it wasn't bad. 

Overall, I think the pho was decent. I can't rate it 4 stars as I've had a much better experience as well as better tasting pho. 

Would I be back? I'd like to find a different spot before going back here.
author: Michael T.

description:
This is my favorite pho restaurant in the city. The broth is so good!

The decorations are perfectly random and everything on the menu is delicious.
author: Francis C.

description:
Vietnamese food is comfort food and Miss SaiGon delivers on being a comfort food experience.

You know when you get off a flight and just feel gross? If you can't empathize, gtfo. For me, Vietnamese food, especially pho, is that kind of comfort food that I love and always want to inhale when I feel sick or generally gross.

As you can guess, I had Miss SaiGon right after I landed in SF. I was feeling icky and luckily, my friends were amiable to my choice of lunch cuisine. Miss SaiGon was a close walk from my hotel, so we opted to eat here.

Entering, it is definitely a typical run-of-the-mill Vietnamese restaurant. Nothing fancy. If anything, a little run down. But the servers are kind and the menu extensive.

When I was here, we were able to check-in on Yelp to receive a free order of spring rolls, which were tasty! Nothing amazing, but I have had restaurants screw up spring rolls. These were definitely fresh and good quality.

For my main, I opted for the vermicelli noodle bowl with pork. I love pho, but that weekend was a hot spell and pho just wasn't gonna happen. For the price, the size of the bowl was huge! The meat wasn't the best I ever had, but the amount for the price made sense.

The waiter was great at refilling water and even gave us a free dessert which was delicious! Honestly, food wise this place is probably a 4 star, cleanliness is a 3, but service is a 5. So overall, a good, solid 4 stars and a place that I will be back to for my Vietnamese fix.
author: Angela C.

description: I got the chicken pho here, which was decent, although the chicken did not taste fresh. The staff was nice. The place has a very tacky atmosphere - the lighting, music, and decor. Not my kind of spot.
author: Dan B.

description:
Yelp Food Delivery for the WIN. 

Here's the deal - I always come to SF armed with a bucket list of places I want to try (and places I want to go to again) and then I work and usually host a conference and take calls and walk back and forth to the offices and then, when I get to my hotel room... I really just don't wanna go out. The number of times that I have needed some sort of Asian soup and haven't gone to get it myself while in the city is up in the double digits guys. I know. It's lazy, but maybe I can put this issue under "self care" ? 

I ordered up some pho, some spring rolls with shrimp and just to stay edgy - the fried bananas and ice cream for dessert. How would that travel? Time would tell! 

The Yelp app counted down to my delivery time, which was prompt. They managed, in one plastic bag and with a delivery via bicycle courier, to deliver hot soup AND not too melty ice cream. That alone gets a star. 

I ate the ice cream and dessert first - while the broth cooked up my raw meats. That was a little sketchy, but it cooked enough to be medium rare and that's good enough for me. the broth isn't the best I've ever had, but the veggies and noodles were fresh and delish and I really enjoyed all of this in bed, in a robe. So... yay me and gracias Miss SaiGon.
author: Trish S.

description: Ordered takeout for lunch. Food was prepared quickly, but maybe a little too quickly.... Ordered the Pho Tai which comes with "medium rare" beef, and the beef was extremely rare (as shown in picture). I did not eat it and just put the noodles in the broth.
author: Trish D.

description: Huge portions/great prices/delicious food/friendly service. We ordered the combo beef pho and pork vermicelli noodles. If you check in on yelp, you also get free spring rolls! The food was authentic and tasty.
author: Sophia H.

description: Loved the Pho Ga. The noodles were so N I C E. Soup was flavorful and I also ordered a honeydew slush that wasnt too good.
author: Kevin L.

description: Ordered pickup through web site - arrived and they didn't have the order at all - waste of time!!
author: Mike E.

description: Overall, I would order through them again....perhaps a little wiser this time though.  While staying in a hotel in San Francisco, I ordered delivery from Miss Saigon.  The delivery was fast, and service was friendly.  I based my order on other Yelp reviews.  I had the lunch portions of the Cha Gio (Deep fried egg rolls (Veggie Version)), Crab Rangoon (Deep fry of cream cheese and crab meat wrapped in wonton skin), Canh Ga Chien Nuoc Mam (Spicy chicken wings in Vietnamese style), Pho Tai Mem Soup (Rice noodle with filet mignon rare beef).   The egg rolls were good & crispy.  I had the veggie version, that has perhaps a bean filling that was a little strange to me. I think in the future I'd order the pork.  The crab wontons were my favorite part of this order!  So good & herby.  They were even good the next day, and I'm not much of a leftovers person.  The wings were also really good, and not overly spicy.  I was really looking forward to the pho, and the one I ordered sounded awesome reading other reviews. But unfortunately, it is not the right thing to order while staying at a hotel with no kitchen.  The meat arrived seeming more raw than rare to me.  I get it, the broth is probably supposed to help cook the meat...but by the time it was delivered to me, the broth had cooled.  Staying in a hotel, I had no way to reheat it.  I did taste the broth, and it was delicious! But unfortunately, I was too grossed out by the temperature of the meat to be able to eat it.  I did get a surprise order of what I think must have been Che dau do (Red beans with coconut).  Not really my cup of tea, and because I was didn't order it, I was confused about what it was. At first I thought it meant for my pho.
author: Joby W.

description: Solid place for a big bowl of pho. Came on a Saturday night and sat immediately. The soup came piping hot and was quite filling. The broth was not salty and very drinkable.
author: Edward W.

description:
Vietnamese girl from San Jose...working in San Francisco.  I have food envy every time I see my Viet friends post their lunch dates in San Jose and all the awesome eats.  

The criteria I'm working within is I can't leave the office, so I need food delivered to me.  Ordered Bun Thit Nuong Cha Gio through Postmates.  Extra fish sauce and chili garlic.  Eggroll came still crispy.  They even included a che dau do which was a really nice touch.  And they included nem nuong, which they prepared really well!

One big thing they need to improve on is the delivery containers.  Please please please spend a little extra on your containers.  I'd love to order stuff like pho and hieu tieu.  However, I'm also stuck eating in a cube at my desk, so I need it to be ready to go.   They should take some notes from the places that deliver ramen.  They put all the noodles/meat in a ready to eat bowl, and the broth in a soup container.  When we get the food, we just pour the soup in the bowl and it's ready to go.  Great for the corporate lunch orders!

I'll be ordering from them regularly...but I'm still scared to order anything soupy :(
author: Vi Y.

description:
I highly recommend Miss SaiGon, especially number 24. It's free ranged chicken pho. Number 25 has a similar description but I would recommend 24 if your down for eating some chicken meat with tendons and joints (the delicious bits that add so much flavor!). 

Number 25 is mostly white chicken breast meat, still great but less flavor and the meat is boring. 

The rolls are delicous too, the order comes with two rolls per order. We had three people in our party so that made it difficult to share, the staff accommodated us by making these rolls on the order. Amazing service!

Prices are on point, cheaper than most other Viet places. I recommend Miss SaiGon over Tin Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Ming Y.

description:
This place always delivers delicious noodles. There are a variety of different kinds from your average pho to the spicy bun, to lighter style wonton or chicken noodles. You will also find the stuff that's not as common like pig's blood. 

The restaurant is quite spacious so it isn't too hard to find a space here. The only gripe I have is that the place is a bit grimey and the service isn't great - not unusual for pho places, but they tend on the slow side, which is weird. Since there are other great Vietnamese places in the city, sometimes I do prefer one where the table is a bit more wiped down and the cuts of meats are not as grisly.
author: Alice C.

description: Delicious pho bowls! We had the rare filet mignon pho and it was awesome! Cute little spot. Two thumbs up!
author: Danielle D.

description:
Food is great, reasonably priced, and the staff is super friendly. Got the chicken rice plate and the serving size was great. 

DO NOT USE THE EAT24 APP. You'll pay more, and they'll indicate a wait time that is far longer than is realistic. The app indicated 45 minutes, the food was ready in ten.
author: eric c.

description:
This is a dive deep in the cut. The food is great! 

It's in one of the worst parts of town on maybe the worst corner. It's shady outside.

Great Service.
Some of the best Pho in the City.
author: Justin S.

description: Really awesome place for vietnamese food in SF. Would def come back again once im town
author: Ådrian R.

description: Solid spot. Great takeout and they always fill your boxes! Love this place. One of the most solid spots out there. Always recommend this place if you live in soma. I truly appreciate the service at this place too.
author: Kuan H.

description: If you are a pho lover, omg are you in for a treat! I've had the 17 and the 17b which are beef pho and filet mignon pho, respectively.  OMG, this is the best broth I've tasted in San Francisco. The bowls are average size for a large, and it looks like a fairly standard bowl of pho. However, this pho has the most succulent broth I've ever had. It's a concentrated mix of spices and oil, perfectly balanced with just a hint of a spicy aftertaste. I've *begrudgingly* shared bites and sips of my pho here with friends and they've all been amazed as well at how delicious the pho is!  If you come here at lunch time though, be prepared to potentially wait, as it can get really crowded. 10/10 would recommend to any pho lover.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Hands down my favorite pho in the city. If broth is important, than this place beats all others. Pay a little extra and get the filet mignon, it's totally worth it. The area around is a little sketch, but yes come here if you want good pho.
author: Vinayak P.

description:
The best place if you want to eat a good northern Vietnamese soup or some Vietnamese dishes. It's for me the only restaurant I can eat a good Vietnamese meal in San Francisco. Other restaurant cooked with an awful taste. 
However, I ate only good Tonkin soup and pork shredded rolls. Hu tieu nam vang is not tasty, spring rolls are fresh but 1 shrimp in 2 rolls, bun bo Hue has no the taste of it. Che 3 mau is bad, too sticky because too sugar and jelly is dry. They have a sweet with taro not bad but revisited with fruits and it's not necessary.
I just take away pork rolls. They did a clean cooking.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description:
Great food, fast service, on time delivery.
Items tried: crab rangoon, pho tai, grilled beef sandwich.

Easy parking on the street. 


Update: i order pretty much every week and asking to replace their bean dessert with some other one, which they never do. Is it so difficult to replace it with an equal worth.
author: Jaroslav S.

description:
This is my go to Vietnamese restaurant when I'm craving pho... or hungover... or both. Literally around the corner from my grandma's house (yes, my grandma lives in this crazy neighborhood lol), this restaurant is not only convenient for me but is also super delicious. I've never had an unsatisfactory experience and my cravings are always fulfilled here.

Allow me to express myself *cues Calvin Harris*
Spring rolls
This is what you came for.
Happy thoughts
strike every time she chews
And everybody's watching her
Cuz she's slurping bun rieuuu eu eu
eu eu eeuuuu

Joking. I don't actually order the bun rieu here, but it rhymed and I got your attention didn't I?

I always get pho dac biet (rice noodle with combination beef). I like my pho with tripe and tendons and all that beef part goodness, and that's exactly what the combination beef comes with. It's a texture party in my mouth. I also appreciate that the beef is actually medium rare; it drives me crazy when I eat at a Vietnamese restaurant and the steak is thoroughly cooked through. Like damnit, how am I supposed to eat with my eyes?!

The broth is also perfect to my palette-- rich, beefy, and aromatic. That said, if you're not a tripe and tendon fan, pho tai is also good. Same awesome broth. Or pho tai mem w/ filet mignon if you're feeling fancy, which my bf got once and it was delightful. Literally, my taste buds were happy. 

Also really good:
-Ca kho to, aka traditional claypot catfish. It's just so beautifully braised and caramelized, and the catfish is wonderfully flakey. This one time I tried to order it, they were even sold out. 
-BUN BO HUE: my other go to order when I'm trying to spice up my life. I'm used to the BBH at Ben Tre by where I live, and the BBH at Miss Saigon is also everything I want a BBH to be. The soup is perfectly spicy and really flavorful, and the meat portions are generous.

Ok granted, I'm not Vietnamese. But half my clique of all Southeast asian baby girls is so I feel like I would at least recognize good pho from embarrassing pho (aka Chinesey pho or worse, "white people pho"). And this is some good phocking fo.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: I would give 3.5 stars  if I could...I got delivery today on account that I'm working from my desk. My food came right on time which was awesome!  Now for the bad part... I would give my Pho 3 starts on account that my hoisin-only sauce instructions were not followed, my pho was much saltier than most I've had and my meat to noodles ratio was off (I'm pretty picky about what amount of meat I get lol). I think in the future though, I'd get their Buns as the looked amazing, but I don't come downtown often, so we'll see!
author: Kimberly B.

description: Really liked this place. Came in for dinner before a show at the Orpheum. Was able to get a seat pretty easily on a Wednesday around 6:30 pm. Service was great, place was clean, and the food was delicious! We got the crab Ragoon appetizer and Vermicelli noodles. Both were awesome! Only thing to note is that you'll have to walk through one block of questionable regard. But will definitely be coming back again!!
author: Sara F.

description:
Yuck yuck yuck yuck.... faaaaaaak!!!

See video/photo. Just received my door dash order and there is a long black hair in my noodles. 

It's intertwining into the noodle itself, spliting noodle down the middle whenever I tug at it. So god damn gross and unsanitary.
author: M E.

description: First time here, came because of the ratings. Food was good!! Will come back if I'm ever back in the area
author: Shy O.

description: Favorite place to grab pho and service is friendly. They have old school Vietnamese decor, which I greatly appreciate.
author: Michelle B.

description:
legit Viet food. good pho and lots of choices. they use real mint for the pho, lots of place skimp and use basil. busy at lunch but that's a good sign. it's a big menu, lots of variety with the pho, vermicelli bowls and rice dishes

reasonable prices too. highly recommended
author: Bob U.

description:
Not bad. Came here with coworkers for birthday lunch at 12, was quickly seated, right after us, the lunch crowd poured in. 

I got the Bun Bo Hue special with pork blood and knuckles, but they forgot to add that "special" touch in my soup, I told them about it and they quickly brought the addtitional items to me in a bowl with clear soup. The broth was ok, flavorful but not the best, I had way way way better Bun Bo Hue in Oakland from Pho King. 

My boss got the chicken and string bean, portion was HUGE, smelled yummy! but it's just a regular rice plate, nothing to be impressed about. She mentioned the flavor was very good! 

3 of my coworkers order their seafood noodle soup, #22, it looked ok, like any vietnamese seafood noodle soup. The seafood was ok, didnt use small baby shrimp, you can actually see the decent size shrimps. They raved about the soup being extra good. I think everyone was just trying to be nice lol

Overall, a good place for lunch. Service is fair, a bit slower compare to other vietnamese restaurant but overall I think I can return again for lunch
author: Kris J.

description:
4.5 stars. Very flavorful, rich, clean broth. Pho Ga has wide rice noodles, which I love. Bf loved the meat ball pho. Portions are generous and worth the slightly higher price. 

The half-star decrease is for the red bean coconut dessert we ordered which was made with KIDNEY BEANS instead of red beans. So strange. Still edible somehow though??
author: Lauren R.

description: Ordered bahn mi for delivery.  Really fast service,  but the sandwiches were just OK.  Bread as not very fresh and it didn't really have much of the creamy sauce on it.   I may try something different next time.
author: Annie C.

description: Very good service, excellent soup and egg rolls.Very low key from outside but good. Woukd go back if visiting SF
author: Jon D.

description: I ordered some pho and spring rolls to the hotel where I was staying. The food was delicious, and the pho broth was savory. The broth arrived a little too cool to cook the meat, and I had to get a microwave up to the room to heat it back up... but again, it was delivery and not their fault. By the way, if you get delivery, you have to use a delivery app (I used Uber Eats). I wish there was some cilantro with the condiments. I don't know if cilantro is a normal part of the pho experience, but that's what I'm use to. Really, really good pho!!  I would go in person next time instead of delivery.
author: J H.

description:
Came for dinner, good quality and fun ambiance, albeit a bit pricey. We ordered some vegetarian imperial rolls and the seafood claypot. The vegetarian imperials rolls were unique - they had a kind of starchy bean curd in them. They only came with two, but they were decent size for 5.95. The claypot was really delicious, with fish cake, squid, and shrimp, as well as mushrooms. I thought it was well-flavored and cooked, though my wife thought the claypot was a little too salty. We also ordered some jasmine tea which was nice to have with the meal.

I think the prices were definitely fair, but higher than what I think of vietnamese food costing in this part of the city - most of the entrees were $15 or higher. 

It was a nice little spot, clean bathrooms, attentive service, so I could definitely see coming here again - the wide menu and wide range of prices on the menu too meant that you have a more affordable meal or a more luxurious one at the same spot.
author: Ari F.

description: Good variety of Vietnamese dishes are reasonable price. Pho is good. Also like their sweet and sour soup. The staff is very friendly and nice.
author: Tinou B.

description:
Shrimp egg rolls are very good. The sauce is so good I'm eating all my veggies. Lots of extra condiments and sauces. 

Won ton soup is just what a chinaman needs after a long day of nonsense at the workplace. 

High lee recommended. 

Oh coke with a wine glass full of ice. Nice tough. 

Very very clean restaurant. 

Like Arnold says "I'll be bock"
author: G S.

description:
Ordered lunches for two - delivered ($2.99 fee) by Eat24.  Food was very fesh when delivered. 

I had #31- vermicelli noodles with chicken and veggies [included peanuts, which were not ndntioned on the menu description].  I really enjoyed my fish. My co-worker ordered Chicken Fried Rice. She enjoyed it snd says that she will probably order it again soon.

I'll order again.
author: Tara V.

description:
Best pho is San Francisco 

Better pho than Tin's

Broken rice is great

Friendly service
author: Charles C.

description:
Consistently good Viet food for fair prices? I'm down! I hadn't been back to this place for a few years, but when my dad was in town and we were craving some homey food, I immediately thought of this place. Service was very quick and attentive and food was delicious!

Bun Bo Hue (BBH)- Properly thick plump juicy rice noodle. It's a slight pet peeve of mine when restuarants use the thin kind of rice noodes, or worse (in my opinion), left over pho noodles at the end of the day. T__T But anyway! lol Miss Saigon does BBH well, with a decent amount of spice in the flavorful broth. There isn't huyet (blood cubes), but there is plenty meat!

Bun Cha Ha Noi- "Cha" to me usually refers to the steamed meatloaf that is typically finely processed pork/chicken...sometimes fish meat. But, because of the Northern VN dialect differences, I found out that in this case the "cha" was more like a softer version of grilled pork (thit nuong). All very tasty so I'm not complaining! The sweet juice works great poured over the side of thin noodles...you can even make a wrap with the accompanying side of salad, cilantro, sweet picked cabbage, and cucumber. 

Seafood eggroll- We got this appetizer as a togo snack... I don't recommend this method because of the rice paper they use as the wrap for the eggroll- storing it in a non-breathing container (like say....that plastic togo container) quickly turns the fried crunchiness into an unpleasantly tough/chewy consistancy. Taste is just fine though so if you're gonna get this, eat it asap!

Shrimp spring rolls- We also got this togo- pretty standard. Nothing standout, but still yummy with the peanut sauce. =]

Definitely will be back the next time I have a hankering for Viet while in the city!
author: Yen D.

description:
While holed up in a hotel one night we ordered from this place on Caviar and it was really, really solid. Like this is probably not the best asian in the entire city, but the pho here was delicious as was the 5-spice chicken. Fried dishes were a little greasy but, on the whole, this is better than 90% of all takeout places here in  NYC. 

I had the chicken pho by the way. I know, I know, don't hate me.
author: Paul A.

description:
I have no idea how this place got its 4-star, 800+ reviews. The pho here taste horrible. Bland soup, dry meat, undercooked noodles, even the lemon slices are expired-looking. It's also $11 per bowl. The popularity is just bizarre.

I'd travel a few blocks for Tu Lan or Turtle Tower if I knew this...
author: Joseph L.

description:
Honestly the worst pho I've ever had and I've had a lot of bad pho. I'm baffled how this place ends up on several "Best Pho" lists. Watery broth, overly sweet and extremely flat/bland, just hot oily beef water. Spring rolls weren't bad but nothing special. 

Maybe we came on a bad night or at a bad time since it was later in the evening about an hour before closing time, but we still paid full price for our meals (not cheap by any means) and the staff gave no shits about our clear dissatisfaction. I had maybe two bites, and when our server asked us how the food was and we told him, he was just kind of like "Oh" and walked off. I understand that Asian restaurants tend to be much less philosophical about food and if you don't like what you're served, then it's a personal problem (none of that "we take ~pride~ in our food" sentiment), and that's fine. Pure business transaction. But objectively, the food that I paid $15+ for was ass. Would never come back.
author: June L.

description: I ordered food from them tonight and the order was delivered completed destroyed. The restaurant took zero responsibility over the order. I cannot eat it and I am completely dissatisfied with this experience. Do not order from Eat24 ever.
author: Connie K.

description:
Pretty good food, but I do think it's a tad bit on the pricier side when it comes to Vietnamese food. However, we decided to go here because it was nearby. I ordered a rice dish with grilled pork and egg cake ($9.50), which I enjoyed although the egg cake wasn't quite what I expected. It was a darkish color and a bit dry too. I honestly couldn't tell there was egg in it. The fish sauce the dish came with was pretty tasty though. A bit more pungent than what I'm used to, but not in a bad way. We also ordered the calamari as an appetizer ($7.75), which was tasty but for the cost and the portion size, I would probably pass.

As I wrote this review, Yelp informed me of their poor food safety score. Yikes! Although I can't say I'm surprised. The toilet had no handle (you had to pull some cord to flush it) and one of the people working there was sick, which makes me wonder if he handled my food because I'm actually sick right now. In any case, I give it 3 stars because the food hit the spot. Not sure if I'll come back again the next time I'm in SF, but at least the food was enjoyable and they were nice enough to do split checks.
author: Alice L.

description:
I had prematurely declared Turtle Tower as my favorite pho place but hadn't yet tried out Miss SaiGon which my roommate had decided was his favorite. I'd actually been to Miss SaiGon five years ago and I didn't remember loving or hating it, so I thought maybe it'd be worth giving a second try.

I took a glance at the menu and saw they had filet mignon for the pho. It sounded exciting, but I mean, I knew it wasn't really going to be anything special. It's a pho restaurant after all. The concept seemed novel though, so I went ahead and pulled the trigger.

What a mistake. What should have been the best part of the meal was actually the worst. I didn't even finish the meat. The broth was good and the noodles were fine, but the supposed filet mignon. Nope. Looks like I was right in declaring Turtle Tower as #1!
author: Charles L.

description: Take out pho, delicious broth, good quality meat, generous toppings portion, and catered handsomely to my request for extra extra jalapenos. Really enjoyed it, will be back.
author: David J.

description:
DO NOT ORDER THE BUN RIEU HERE!

I LOVEEE Bun Rieu (crab meat tomato soup). However, I was super disappointed with the Bun Rieu here because it was not even close to authentic Bun Rieu.
I didn't think it was quite possible to mess up on Bun Rieu, but this item was seriously not their forte. I think they were missing the tomato paste because the broth was a light orange color rather than red??  and the there wasn't much crab meat flavor... 
They also had immigration crab meat in the soup.... And the pork shrimp balls lacked in flavor :/ 
Boo.. I should've been suspicious when I didn't see any Bun Rieu photos on Yelp. 
Prices were pretty high considering the area as well at $9.00+ for a bowl of Pho?

2 stars instead of 1 star because my friend's bun bo hue was pretty good and was authentic. I think it's only safe to order the beef noodle soups here!
author: Leilani Y.

description:
I used postmates to grab one order of pho tai, kimchee, and one grilled pork banh mi. I love how everything was packed. It was sturdy as well and aesthetically pleasing and nothing had leaked. 

My pho came as one package of broth and one tray of noodles, raw thinly sliced steak, and all the fixings.

It was tasty but missing some "oomph" that usually hits the taste buds when eating pho. 

The kimchee was very islander and reminded me of the sweet kimchee cabbage my aunts used to make in the Marianas islands. (not your traditional kimchee here)

Banh mi was awesome. I have had a hard time ordering banh mi in SOMA. This one was nice. Fish pate was nice and tangy and the pork was tender and so savory. 

I'm not like impressed and shocked. But I am more than happy to receive some good quality- clean- tasty- traditional food. Yums all around.
author: Niana D.

description:
Absolutely delicious! I let my nose do the walking to this place, which wasn't my first choice for lunch, but seeing as though my first option had a line out the wazoo, I figured this place couldn't be all that bad. It looks like this place is closed from the outside (depending on what if you're coming from the Mission or the 6th street side), and the neighborhood is kind of sketch, but you can't judge a book by it's cover, folks! 

I didn't have time to eat inside, so I was able to grab something to go. This place is definitely busy during the lunchtime (lunchtime rush hour, I like to call it), so do plan accordingly! I was able to place my order pretty promptly, and it came out relatively fast. This isn't the biggest place, so if you are anywhere near the front (either ordering or paying) don't get offended if you get bumped around a bit.

I ordered the shrimp with onions in a curry sauce, with white rice. The shrimp and rice were cooked just right, and the curry sauce was perfect. I didn't mind the onions (I like onions), but found some to be cooked right and other pieces to be a bit more on the raw (and more pungent) side in terms of taste. 

I found this place to be relatively inexpensive, but if you're interested in something a bit more cost-efficient, then check out their banh mi sandwich, which starts at about $5 during lunch. 

Likes:
- fast and prompt service
- delicious (flavorful) options 
- relatively inexpensive (the banh mi is super cheap!)

Dislikes:
-sketch neighborhood: watch where you walk to avoid trekking poop into your next destination!
-beware of the lunch crowd (although not a bad thing, but just plan accordingly if you're time is limited during lunch).
-poor food rating (so don't be surprised if you get a bout of Montezuma's revenge after visiting this place...weak stomachs should proceed with caution
author: Tracy T.

description:
The pho was excellent. I ordered #17 and couldn't have been more satisfied. It had a delicate yet flavorful broth, a clump of rice noodles, and delicious beef slices. 

Additionally, we got a free appetizer for checking in on Yelp! It was fantastic! Only complaint is the location. It isn't a great location.
author: Zoe Z.

description:
Little Miss Saigon.
I visit you twice last week.
You are affordable,
tasty,
and centrally located.
I appreciate you!
author: Jen M.

description: We did delivery and thought the pho with filet mignon rare beef was delicious.  We were really impressed.  I wasn't a fan of the summer roll which was 98% lettuce.  The bun with grilled chicken was okay - the vermicelli and toppings were good, the chicken was a bit dry and not as flavorful as the five spice chicken I've had at other restaurants.
author: Vivian W.

description: Decent pho, a bit oily. Great portion sizes! I am a bit confused as to why this is rated quite highly. Staff definitely gets 5 stars but food? Solid 3.
author: Eden W.

description: Finally had the opportunity to try this place and was disappointed. The five spice chicken was gross. Chicken was huge. Flavoring wasn't good. The rice was very mushy. Pho was okay. Soup base was okay. Meat wasn't that good.
author: Ann L.

description: The food and portions here were pretty good, but the people who got here after us were served first. They got our order wrong at first too. When they finally came with our order, they didn't provide us with utensils and the lady rushed off to serve other people instead. I had to go up to the counter to ask for utensils. We then had to subsequently keep asking for condiments/other utensils. The overall dining experience paled in comparison to the food itself. The wait staff is not very attentive to the customers here and the wait times for food once you're seated are pretty long.
author: Gloria L.

description: One of the few restaurants where you can get real food before 11:00 am in SF. Located in a sketchy area of SF, but other than that the food came out fast and our server was very helpful. Fresh ingredients.
author: Doran B.

description:
I ordered chicken noodle pho as well as chicken and string beans through Caviar. 
The pho was was too spicy, it felt like I was eating Jalapeno broth. I like spicy food, but this was beyond tolerable, I ate a little, and thew away the rest. The chicken and bean was just mediocre. 
I do not recommend this restaurant.
author: Monica R B.

description: I ordered delivery from doordash and the food came pretty quickly.  I ordered the seafood pho with egg noodles and I specifically asked for hoisin sauce (3) sides of it and this is why I'm giving 5 stars because they gave me 3 sides of hoisin sauce and the pho was delicious.  I also ordered crab and shrimp imperial rolls and they were sooo good.  I'm so happy they had this option because I don't eat pork.  I also ordered the grilled chicken breast and it came with a side of rice and that was also delicious.  I will definitely order from this place again.  One of the best Vietnamese food I've had in awhile
author: Lennie G.

description:
The food here is fresh , balanced and tender.
I would give it a 5 if it had a better location.
The eggs rolls fantastic. The green papaya salad is fresh and delicious
author: charlene s.

description: Decent place to dine. The background music was beautiful. SoundHound couldn't identify any of it.  The portions were large. I could barely finish my dish. Overall, a positive experience all around with polite, friendly wait staff. We'll be back. I should honestly issue 5 stars. I do too many 5 star reviews in San Francisco given the awesome foreign food restaurants.
author: G M.

description: Pretty great pho! Delivery was super fast and the broth tasted great. wish I had gotten more broth though.
author: Tate C.

description:
I eat here often for lunch and I don't even work in the area. That should tell you what I think of their food. 

Food: I love their papaya salad with beef jerky. I like their pork or other meaty dishes when I'm feeling low carb. But their che (desserts) are something i can't day no too. Sometimes I'll get bun bo hue and have them make it more Viet style with all the accoutrements on top. Very tasty.

Service: at this point the core people know me and hopefully like me. They aren't professional servers, i believe mostly friends of the owner. That said, service can be sporatic because they are so busy at lunch!

Ambiance: I suck in my breath and find parking and walk on 6th through the colorful tenderloin area. Once you pass the overwhelming smell of urine and other things, you'll be fine in the restaurant.
author: Viyada S.

description: Flying from Korea to US, we stayed in SF for a week and spent half of our time for VN foods. This restaurant is so far the best. The tastes are similar to Vietnam. The service is really good and nice. Price is acceptable. Tips rate is quite high, but it is acceptable considering the quality of service and foods. A must try for Vietnamese lover.
author: Cntu C.

description:
Lets keep it simple:
1. You dont care about who I was with
2. You just want to know if the food is good and if its cheap/accepts credit card
3. Also food quality

- Cheap? - Fuck yea. my meal cost me around $12 (not bad and portion sizes are decent)
- accepts credit card? - Yes.
- Food Quality? - I got a lemongrass porkchop this time around but i know their vemicelli is good
author: Li-Xing C.

description: I was recovering from a weekend with a terrible head cold and was craving some nourishing soup. I ordered the chicken pho with vegetables, and it hit the spot. The broth was flavorful without being too salty or oily. It came with tons of broccoli, cauliflower, carrots, and zucchini. I do wish I had asked for some spicy sauce or chili pepper. I ordered delivery, and was relieved that Miss SaiGon's didn't ask for a $25 minimum like the other nearby restaurants. Already feeling better!
author: Cassady S.

description: I ordered the Filet Mignon Pho and Crab Rangoons. Hands down the best pho I've ever had. This pho is the first pho where I didn't feel any need to add additional seasoning in it. The broth and seasoning was perfection. The beef, ridiculously tender. I've seen reviews comparing this restaurant to Turtle Tower, and honestly, I don't understand why people are comparing the pair because Turtle Tower is northern style pho, completely different from Southern style. I am a southern style pho girl all the way. Miss Saigon takes it all home for me. Hands down.
author: Sharey V.

description: The best pho in town.  The shaken beef is really good as well. Made with real filet mignon. The service could be stepped up a bit tho.
author: David S.

description:
While I would've loved to enjoy disco roller skating with my mates on my last night in San Fran, I found myself scanning Yelp for nearby delivery options. Feeling a little under the weather, I opted for  Pho dac biet (beef combo), Goi du du bo (spicy papaya salad with beef jerky, peanut and basil), and kimchi. 

Using the Eat24 app was quite simple, and I was able to put in my credit card number, and tip with ease. It also gave me an estimated time of arrival, which was pretty spot-on, as well as status updates when I checked as to when my order was being processed and when it went out. 

Upon receiving my order, some of the broth had made its way into the bag, which I wasn't shocked by, but maybe packing it a little bit better and providing napkins would be a good idea. Also would've loved to have a pho to-go spoon, since the soup spoon they provide doesn't really get much on it (so much as it gets on you), when eating pho in your bed watching Wheel of Fortune. 

The pho was still a good temperature, with plenty of fixings to add. The taste of the broth was up to par with what I enjoy, but some of the meat was chewy and some parts were inedible. My favorite meat was the beef balls, so I'd suggest just getting that and the medium rare beef (I think) since it also worked well in the dish. 

The kimchi was good. It wasn't super stinky like a few kimchis I've had in the past, so my roommate thanks you. The papaya salad was super meh. The papaya tasted fresh and had a nice crunch but the dish overall was pretty dry and the jerky didn't really add any complexity since it was just sprinkled on top. It says it's spicy, it was not so. 

I'd potentially order a different pho again from here if I was craving and really could not get myself out of my PJs, but maybe pack a big ol' spoon and maybe try some other dishes out.
author: Morgan F.

description: My new favorite Pho restaurant in SF.  Can't believe it took me over 6 years to discover.  Get the Filet Mignon Pho, amazing broth!
author: Jay H.

description:
We had the banh xeo (Vietnamese crepe w/ pork & shrimp) and bun bo hue (spicy beef and pork with vermicelli noodles). Both were delicious and affordable. They even separately brought out a pig's feet to go with the bun bo hue- legitness. 

The menu is extensive and offers a ton of Vietnamese options- noodles, soups, rice plates, appetizers, stir fry, dessert, etc. 

Busy during weekday lunch hours. We came around 1:30pm, and the place was still crowded. Service is friendly and helpful, though it can be slow.
author: Joanna L.

description: I have no issue giving them a solid 5 star review even though I have only been here once. Great authentic food. Large portions. No one in my party was able to finish our food. This gem is nestled in a little bit of a dodgy neighborhood.
author: Keith P.

description: You literally can't beat the prices here. The service was great. I ordered a pho and the broth was one of the best I've ever had. The consistency of the beef was a little off though.
author: Paulina K.

description: Extremely  rude not friendly  I will not return  the guy was a complete  jerk hes not geting any of my money
author: I Call Them H.

description:
We found this place via Yelp of course, after parking the car in a pay lot off Mission. We had tickets to a musical at the Orpheum and wanted a lunch place within reasonable walking distance.  We normally don't frequent this part of SF, so we were not sure what to expect.

Located in a nondescript street corner, the restaurant had a nice wow factor upon entering.  It was extremely bright and clean, with music videos playing and mannequin clad in a Ao Dai.  Menus had bright photos and they even offered boba and other desserts.

Won Ton Soup Appetizer: Had a nice Vietnamese twist in that the broth had a good amount of lemongrass. Won Tons were pork only, but soft and juicy.

Combination Pho: Good sized, and very flavorful broth with strong lemongrass flavor.  The only minor flaw was that it was on the oily side.  Had they skimmed off some of the oil, it would have been one of the better phos. Kudos to the waiter who asked whether we like tripe (we're not fans) - it was nicely missing from the dish.

Grilled Pork Bun: This had surprisingly lots of noodles, way more than the sauce can handle!  I got the version with sprouts and fried egg rolls for crunchiness.  The pork had good flavor and was soft - but would have been better with a little more sear.  

Overall I'd give 3.5 stars for the food but am rounding up for great service and super cleanliness.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Came in today for lunch with a friend and we both ordered the papaya salad. The salad was good with a nice dressing which featured a tiny amount of delicious fish sauce which provided salty, sweet, and savory notes throughout. The pieces of pork in the salad were good, but quite small, and any refined palate could easily tell that the shrimp were previously frozen - which is expected of this type of establishment.

The bill came and we both handed a credit card to waiter. He comes back a few moments later saying that he could only use 1 card, and has already charged my credit card without giving my table an opportunity to alter our preferred method of payment. 

Absolutely unacceptable! I'd rather sacrifice my daughter to pagan gods before coming back here.
author: David D.

description: Pho is excellent- really good beef broth but location is not so good -lots of homeless around ...
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Very good Vietnamese food. I go here every once in awhile and every time I get great customer service and awesome tasting food. When my family comes in town it's the first place I want to take them too.
author: Jordan M.

description:
This 2-star review is mostly due to the customer service experience. Food at Miss SaiGon was about average for Vietnamese soup noodles, but the price was somewhat expensive for the portion size and the service was atrocious.
