On Wednesday, Ka Barry said that everyone who trusts in God knows that everything that happens to a person's life always ends up for their own good - even if it starts out bad or you experience great sadness, it will always end up being for your own betterment.

Miss SaiGon is the perfect example of this.

I went to Pho2000 with my coworkers 2 weeks ago when it was hella cold. I couldn't wait to slurp those noodles and fill my tummy with slices of medium rare rib eye in the #6 Pho Tai wif extra Tai. But I knew something was wrong as we were walking over there and noticed a small crowd staring at the store front - they were closed! and not only were they closed but they were in Vietnam so they'd be closed for a few weeks! awww =(

I did what any Pho-craving sane person would do, I immidately consulted Yelp and it brought me to here.

We took the 5R (my first time riding Muni in 15 years maybe? it's been so long I didn't know the "R" replaced the Limited) and walked a few blocks to 6th and Mission and just going inside felt as if we were entering the streets of Ho Chi Minh City - lots of eccentric doodas and hickey dos littered the restaurant and of course the tv monitors playing the latest in Vietnamese karaoke. 

17b. What does that mean to you? Here it means it's the soup to get. 17b is Pho Tai Mem - Filet Mignon soup! My mouth waters just thinking about it. Loved the broth and the chunks of Filet Mignon and they didn't skimp either. 

Will come back here for sure!
author: Ray R.

description:
Great restaurant near a theater we went to last weekend!

The service is totally above and beyond-- so so friendly and even with a group of 10 of us, the owner (?) who was taking our orders remembered every single one. And he even split our checks!

The food was great as well; I love that they have tons of veggie options, even making pho with a veggie base. I had the vegetarian pho, and it was great! Big portion size, generous with tofu and veggies, and even in the lime shortage they gave me lots of limes to squeeze into the broth. Everyone at the table really enjoyed their food... Fewer were able to finish it!
author: Allison M.

description:
Their filet mignon pho had incredibly tender beef. Really, really tender.

The only problem was that the broth, and the beef by proxy, were a bit lacking in flavor. Not exactly the depth of flavor I was expecting from pho as usual.

Aside from that, the pricing for the portion sizes and service are fine.
author: Alan Y.

description:
The filet pho is the best I've had. I've eaten many bowls of pho in different cities around the world. Spring rolls are excellent as well. 

Walking south down Mission street is a little sketchy as the street can be a little rough. But there are all types of people in the area and the end result is worth it.
author: Colin S.

description: Good affordable pho. 6th Street is a bit sketchy so be careful if you're walking to this restaurant at night. Inside its clean and tidy. It's $9 for a small bowl and $10 for a large bowl, best bang for your buck is to get the large size. The food is good but the service is very slow. Order as soon as possible if you don't want to wait while. Despite being slow the staff are friendly and accommodating. The deep fried spring rolls are yummy too.
author: Ashley S.

description:
The food was delish! All the orders at my table were just delectable and fresh.  My food was simple- grilled pork and egg rolls with vermicelli noodles. 

The only reason why I didn't give this place five stars is because the food came significantly later than everyone else's order. I was somewhat ignored when I tried to make eye contact for service. The place does get very busy at noon but it seems like a table opens up every few minutes.  

I'm coming back for sure but only to order ahead and pick up lunch since my job recently moved to the area; I'm planning to be a regular patron.  :-)
author: Sharon B.

description: I've been a fun for this place for a few years. In addition to personal occasions, we've come here for corporate events as well. All of my family members , friends and co-workers like this restaurant so much, both for the friendliness of the people here and the fantastic food! We'll absolutely come back again and again in the future.
author: Colomb Z.

description:
I came here for dinner because it was near my friend's work. We didn't want to drive back to Berkeley during rush hour, so we decided to Yelp a place. This place got some great reviews, so we tried it!

Service:
It was empty were we first walked in. Should of been a sign for us to get out. The server just gestured for us to take a seat and went to get us menu. The server wasn't too friendly, but he wasn't rude either. He just did his job. meh,

Cleanliness: 
This place did not clean their dish and utensils properly. There was a lot of residue left over on our forks and knifes. I had to ask for a new fork about five times before I felt that it was acceptable. 

Food:
The food was below par. The rice on my lamb dish was overcooked. The lamb itself tough and bland. I really had to drench it in the fish sauce to make it bearable. 

Overall:
I would not recommend this place.
author: Christina L.

description: I was hunting around on Eat24 for a healthy-ish lunch with a *reasonable* delivery fee and found Miss SaiGon.  My pho was delish and arrived with a very generous serving of noodles, meat, bean sprouts and basil, etc. - the whole nine yards.  Speedy delivery too, for lunch time - I definitely recommend!
author: Emily M.

description:
A perfectly pleasant and tranquil atmosphere on the middle of skid row. But the food is definitely lacking in flavor. I was so excited to try the garlic noodles, which many yelpers review as a highlight....but they were dry and tasteless, only helped by a generous slathering on of hot sauce. Mine came with chicken which also lacked any kind of seasoning. 

Bummer! High hopes dashed.
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Very good Vietnamese food. The portions are large, so actually quite worth the prices. The place fills up at lunchtime pretty fast, so you're better off getting here before noon if you're a party larger than two. Service is nothing special--the employees and servers are pretty nice, but can be a bit slow when it's busy. The menu is very expansive, with lots of pretty photos that match the food well, so ordering based on those is a good idea. Got a vermicelli with pork and egg roll--noodles were great with the fish sauce added in, lots of fresh and crunchy lettuce and bean sprouts, tender and tasty pork, and a crispy and savory egg roll. The coffee was a bit smaller than I expected, but they give you the full drip cup thing along with the condensed milk unmixed, so you can pour and mix as you wish into the second (iced) cup.
author: Tony D.

description: This place is so bomb. Especially for delivery. Their bang xeo is awesome and they give you lots of lettuce with it which I appreciate. I also always order the egg roll and BBQ beef noodle plate-- so good! Highly recommend! And delivery is quick. Trust me.. I'm Vietnamese ;)
author: Holly M.

description: Came by for lunch with my roommate over the weekend - food is alright, not the best but exactly what you would expect walking in for a bowl of pho in the middle of town. Honestly I was having a good experience there until the waitress poured a inch of my pho soup all over my left thigh and sweater.. the soup was very hot and my skin was burning from the heat. I won't be coming back.
author: Ruby C.

description: My favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the entire city of San Francisco. Both noodle soups and rice dishes are absolutely on point. Excellent service. If you can deal with hole-in-the-wall design sensibilities, this is the go-to Vietnamese place for you.
author: insipidphishie P.

description:
Maybe it was the smell when I first walked in (musty), or maybe it was the dimly lit interior, but whatever it was it felt very sketch and I don't think they were going for the whole in the wall look (not with the white linens on the table).  

The menu is pretty extensive with different rice plates, noodles, and buns.  We decided to go with the combination rice plate and the shaking beef with garlic noodles.  For the rice plate, the Egg cake was really good but everything else was just okay.  I think it said pork chop, but it was more like think strips of pork meat, which was okay in flavor.  The shaking beef was on the sweeter side, and I don't think it was supposed to be top quality meet, but it was quite tender.  The salt/pepper/lemon sauce was good.  The garlic noodles that accompanied it were good as well.  

The food is decent and portions are good, but I don't know if this is a destination point.

Service was friendly and quick.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Service is great :) 5 stars for the service
bo hue is just mediocre, good amount of meat, but the broth is not impressive. - 3.5 stars 
Thai iced tea is wayyyyyyy too sweet. Diabetes in a cup
Overall a pleasant lunch experience
author: Clair C.

description: This place is AMAZING! The mannequin scared the shit out of me, but their service and food here is unbelievable. I was here with 7 of my cousins and we got seated fairly quickly. I ordered the #32 which was the pork & egg roll vermicelli. The noodles were thin, lots of veggies, and the egg roll was so crispy and fresh. The rest of my cousins really enjoyed their food as well. I don't know if it's the owner that's going around making sure everyone is okay, but he made sure it wasn't too hot, made sure that if they ever got the order wrong they would be more than happy to fix that. I mean, it's rare to get this type of service in a viet restaurant. Would def come back when I'm in the area!
author: Tracy V.

description:
Our work is just down the block from Miss SaiGon and there aren't a ton of good food options.  My co-worker turned me on to Miss SaiGon and I'm glad he did as it's really good.  I ordered the Bun Ga Nuong to go.  It was a good amount of food and really tasty.

Good, relatively cheap lunch spot in a tough part of town but worth it.
author: Blake B.

description:
Price: SF price (pretty expensive for what it's worth)
Food: rice plates are acceptable. please don't order pho.
Service: good
author: Jenny W.

description:
My favorite viet place in SF thus far. The place is pretty spacious, with lots of tables.
Great for groups and always a no-hassle lunch spot. 
I usually ask for pho with just vegetables, which isn't on the menu; they are very accommodating about making adjustments etc. The pho broth is super flavorful and aromatic, it's addicting. Noodles r super thin, and light. Just perfect. 
I will def be a regular here.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
The pho is incredible - one of the best in the city!! The broth is full of flavor, spiced right and is generously huge. 

  The desserts - Che in particular - are perfect in every sense, size and dimension.

 A great place to try !!
author: Anthony N.

description:
Decent food, terrible service. I'd probably come here again since the food is decent and terrible service at an establishment like this is almost expected.

My little group ventured here on a Sunday when our normal pho spot was closed early. The mister ordered the Chicken Pho which was pretty generic, he was still feeling the night before so it did the job of soothing his body aches. I ordered the dry noodle (hu tieu nam vang) and although it wasn't the best I've ever had, it was definintely delicious. For first timers I enjoy ordering the dry noodle and pouring a little bit of soup into the sauce and noodles. Super yummy and different if you've never had it.

We also ordered a watermelon smoothie that didn't come until we asked for the bill. We're assuming they forgot about it and instead of giving us the option to drop it off our bill, they hurried and made it for us before they brought the check. Eh, whatever.

Not my first choice of places to go, but as plan B or C.
author: Mindy T.

description:
Since moving from San Jose (which has like 4 pho spots per square mile) I've been looking for a great Pho place. Miss SaiGon is the best we've had so far. But it's still nothing compared to other Pho spots in SJ. 

What I Liked:
Fast Service
No White Onions
Ordering take-home tasted just as good as it does when you eat in-house.

What could have been better:
The broth was very watery, it wasn't hearty or jam packed with flavor. I could barely taste the clove/star anise that Pho is traditionally made with.
Chicken -- I wish they had an option for only white meat. I had a lot of .. chewy / hard pieces of brown meat that looked like scraps. 
Sauce distribution. Instead of having a bottle of sriracha and hoisin sauce on the table, they give you a saucer of sauce. Its hard to make the perfect broth without all the tools!

Overall -- good on a rainy day. If you know of a better pho place PM me!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
This place has some absolutely amazing pho. One thing unique about this restaurant that I haven't seen at many other Vietnamese places is the filet mignon pho. I ordered the combo beef pho but replaced the regular beef with filet mignon (not on the menu but if you ask, they'll do it). Pricy for pho, but yolo right? It's not every day you get to try filet mignon in pho.

I didn't expect to be able to taste the difference but WOW the beef was so much more tender. I'm doubt the beef was legit filet mignon but it was definitely better quality than the beef I usually get at pho places. Definitely coming here again!

I'm giving it 4 starts because we went there with a really big group (16 people) and they didn't handle it very well. I had almost finished my food by the time other people got theirs, and I was trying especially hard to eat slowly.
author: Richie Z.

description:
I go to this place for lunch often.  The food is real Vietnamese.  

The Cafe Sua Da is fantastic and the eggrolls are done the real Viet way (with rice paper).

The Pho is authentic and the staff are very friendly.

The parking is horrible though (let me clarify....parking is okay....location is horrible).  You will be greeted with some of the more "colorful" characters in the area and you will be assaulted with many of the "interesting" smells from the neighborhood.  I've come back many a times and see people sitting or leaning on my car.  It's always a great conversation starter when you have to start with "get the F off my car".

But the restaurant is worth it.  Take a bus if you don't want to park the Ferrari here.

Also, as a quick FYI....as with all authentic Asian restaurants, the servers first language is not English, but they are super nice and are very accommodating.  They try to get you in and out quickly, but the lunch rush can be a little slow.
author: Edward M.

description:
Solid pho, rich broth, and the filet mignon is so tender. I would even ask for it raw on the side so it doesn't overcook.

Be aware of the human excrement on the sidewalk before you enter.
author: Joanne L.

description:
What do you want to eat when you're about to talk to a bunch of people in close quarters? Garlic pork with garlic noodles in garlic sauce. Garlic garlic. That was the lunch special at Miss SaiGon, and even if I ruined anyone's afternoon with my stank breath, I regret nothing.

Although some of my companions were not quite as pleased with their papaya salad or their summer rolls, I was absolutely in love with my pork. With chopped up chunks nearly indistinguishable from the included potatoes and beautiful, thick, slick noodles, the dish was everything I'd wanted and more. 

I'm grateful that I had a Don with me, fresh off a plane from Vietnam, to tell me I was supposed to squeeze my lime into the salt and use it for dipping because that kicked it up a notch. And I'm glad they had the traditional pastry filled with cream cheese on the side. (I might be making up the traditionalness here.)

Miss SaiGon seems to be the rare Vietnamese joint (from my limited experience seen) in that it is not only tasty, but clean and staffed by friendly folk as well. Head over over with a group of sharers and get down with as much cheap, tasty food as you can. And if you're on your own and can only afford one thing, I'd say garlic pork and noodles is the move if they've got it on the menu.
author: Peter D.

description: Been here twice on two trips to San Francisco. First time--ordering Pho--I found it above average. Second time, ordering a slightly more ambitious beef dish, I found it below average. Service is friendly enough but sort of lackadaisical: I didn't get my water refilled even though the restaurant was mostly empty. But food is generally under-spiced and some of the ingredients, although not unhealthy or anything, don't seem like the freshest. Not great. Not truly awful. Still, not going back.
author: Eli L.

description:
Walking down 5th towards 6th, one would not know what to expect.  We stumble upon this place and decided to give it a try. Walking in, the breeze from outside brought the urine stench in the restaurant. I couldn't shake off the smell, moments later, it faded but the smell of bleach came out from the kitchen. 

Aside from the smells,  we ordered the cold peanut noodles, shrimp summer roll, and pho. Pho was good, while the summer roll and peanut noodles were generic like any viet restaurant. 

I couldn't get the smell out and watching now they cleaned their utensils in front of you made my experience unappetizing.
author: Louise C.

description:
Delicious!!!!! 
Takeout and delivery are on point.  Eating in is delicious and on point as well. Great prices with higher quality than tu lan.  I love the pho, the bun Bo hue.  Shaken beef is delicious, garlic noodle is great, mussels are great.  Haven't had the Vietnamese sandwiches yet.
author: Matt N.

description:
Does it seem weird that just after spending three weeks in Vietnam I come back and eat a bunch of pho? I guess not, since I was eating the shit out of some Viet food in the weeks running up to my trip. I simply love the stuff. So when some comrades decided to head here for lunch, I gladly tagged along. 

I went with the goi du du (papaya salad) with tofu, pho ga and a ca phe sua da. The papaya salad here is kind of phoned in. Just shredded papaya, some fried tofu, fish sauce, a few chilis, not enough mint/herbs, and not nearly enough fried onion. It's okay, but could easily be much better. 

The pho ga (chicken pho) is actually pretty damn decent. The meat portion is small, but the noodles are generous, and the broth has a nice solid depth. Tasty stuff. But the price is way high (something in the $9 range) for pho. The ca phe sua da is brewed a little weak on the coffee side (watery) but has plenty of condensed milk and is served up proper (mix at the table). Totally satisfied my craving. 

I'd come back for the pho but am not sure what else I'd try. The dishes my neighbors got didn't look at appealing (lunch specials - noodles with pork and crab puffs) but at least they did the traditional thing of serving a dipping dish with lime and salt/pepper. That's cool.
author: Don B.

description:
Pretty good, but not amazing.

I had originally meant to use eat24 to order to go, but it strangely thought that the store was closed, so I had to walk in. The beef itself was flavorful, but not as tender as I would have liked(a little dry actually.) Not sure about the addition of the potatoes, but the dish was pretty good overall.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Picked up a quick lunch of #2 (veggie summer roll) and a #35 (bun ga nuong noodles- Vermicelli noodles with grilled chicken breast and vegetables.). 

The summer rolls were solid. Tightly wrapped veggies and with a peanut dipping sauce. Standard, but good. 

The #35 was better than expected. LOTS of food for the under $8 price tag. They could've given more sauce with it (it was a big bowl), but that was my only complaint and a problem easily remedied. Moist chicken, lots of veggies and noodles in a bowl? I'll be back everyday of the week! 

Good meal, shady part of town. Go!
author: Drew A.

description:
You get a bargain for what you pay. 

An anecdote I want to share: Close to my work so I come here often. Once, I went in with about 10 co-workers. Each ordered a dish but slightly modified. The waiter was a champion! He didn't write anything but got all the orders right.
author: Astro D A.

description: This place is not overly busy or empty. They have pretty everything you'd want on their menu. Service was a little slow, but in general things came within a reasonable time. The décor is TRIPPY. Stereotypical Asian paintings on the way featuring over colorized cartoon-ish scenery, long forsaken stringed lighting of various neon colors randomly strewn, a fake tree near the door and a mannequin to greet your entrance. You definitely feel like you're in the twilight zone here. The restaurant is in a slightly sketchy neighborhood, so careful where you park!
author: Leo M.

description:
Ive ordered delivery from miss saigon as well as dining in a number of times.  I really like both.  Delivery pho always comes with a ton of side bean sprouts, basil, etc.  Dining in is great because I love all the tacky decor, and they always have on some random nature show on the tvs.  Very eccentric atmosphere.

Ive only ever ordered the combination beef pho, but its really really good.  Never been disappointed.
author: CC C.

description: If you are willing to trudge through the relative sketchiness of this neighborhood for some good pho, this place is totally worth it. My friend and I ordered some Spring Rolls, and I got the Bun Bo Hue. The restaurant was not super busy at night, but the service was still super fast regardless. The waiters watch the tables like hawks! The noodles come with generous amounts of meat, and the broth is delicious. Definitely one of the better pho places I have visited in San Francisco.
author: Stefanie C.

description: This place is batting 1,000. I've ordered the filet mignon pho so many times and it's always perfect. Branching out to the stir fried chicken with black mushrooms and ginger and it's amazing as well. And the owners are so nice. It's a pleasure to dine here.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
I live around the corner, and am extremely lazy--so I have been a regular of Miss Saigon's for almost two years. I don't mean to say their food isn't good. It's four stars good. Just that I don't know if I would come here as much if I didn't live nearby.

Food: Their menu is impressive in length and variety, but I recommend only their selection of Vietnamese soups, specifically their pho. Their sandwiches, rice plates, and vermicelli bowls have all been misses with me, and this is their one area of much-needed improvement.

Price: Pho is reasonable for the area: $8.50 for SM and $10.50 for LG. Beef and specialty dishes are more expensive (~$13), yet with small portions. 

Decor: From the dressed-up mannequin to the landscape paintings to the fake fireplace teetering over the staircase--the decor is literally off the rails and I love it. And the entertainment--I walked in one day and they had ABBA's best hits playing over a live-action Hercules movie. Spectacular.

Service: Lately it's been very good. Fast, and they'll often comp dessert just because. They have free Wi-Fi, just ask.

Location: It would be remiss not to talk about location. But what I can say that others have not? You will have to walk over a sidewalk poop stain to get here, so get over it.
author: Kharissa F.

description: Great food, quick service, kitschy and amusing decor!
author: Michail Y.

description:
From the outside, the place looks sketchy! We decided to walk here from our hotel, since parking would be a pain.

as soon as we walked inside, it was a different story. It was quite busy. The food turned out to be decent as well. It wasnt mind blowing good. But pho is pho, I didnt think it was super special, but it was good to have.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
I've been to this restaurant many times before. The food is decent but the service is slow. I was going to order delivery from them and then I saw their Health Score. YIKES! Methinks not.

Health score:  54 out of 100
author: Vincent P.

description: This is a solid lunch option, either to dine in or take out; it's fast, cheap, fresh, and good. It's definitely not the best Vietnamese food you're going to ever have, but it's also no where near the worst you'll find.  I usually get the pho during the rainy days, and the broth, noodles, or meat aren't anything to write home about, but it'll keep you warm and satisfied.  If I'm in a rush, I pick up the banh mi to go, and the bread's crust is weirdly too crunchy/dry and I wish there was more filling--but also for five dollars, I don't know that I can really complain.
author: Dorie C.

description: We use to eat at Miss Saigon often because it's closer to us then the Vietnamese restaurants along Larkin Street. We ate here for lunch on the weekend and we were very disappointed because the quality is just not as good as before. We got the vermicelli with grilled pork, egg rolls, and vegetables, the grilled pork lack a little flavor but the really disappointing dish was the grilled chicken cabbage salad because after each bite it left a weird bitter aftertastes, and the grilled chicken was super dry. Also, Miss Saigon is a little pricier than the Viet restaurants along Larkin. I don't think we will eat here again.
author: Amy L.

description:
Definitely walk here in a group or with friends, the neighborhood is pretty ghetto.  
We were seated right right away and the staff was extremely polite and attentive.
Interior is clean and bright. I tried the bun bo hue which was good. They give you A LOT of meat!
author: Lydia Y.

description:
First things first, try the garlic noodles with prawns. It's a little pricey but you will not be disappointed. 

I usually get the Garlic Noodles with Prawns, because it is very good. The noodles are nice and are not too garlicky. The prawns are magical, they're fresh and the batter and sauce they use give it a crispy but moist texture. 

I'm also a huge fan of the beef in curry and coconut sauce, probably the best I've had. It's flank steak with black mushrooms, onions, and vermicelli noodles, and it is delicious. 

The service here is also very good. The employees there are very nice and always have good recommendations. 

I just wish this place had a better location, as it is in a bit rough part of town.
author: Chuck C.

description: We come here for pho magic #19 after drinking too much. The good is good, served super fast cheap (pho comes in lunch and dinner portions and with a ton of noodles..you might want to get less). Spring rolls were good too. It ends up being under $16 for 2 pho during lunch hours. Parking isn't too bad but $3 an hr with the meters so bring a lot of change.
author: Lily P.

description:
From the outside, this place does not look so appetizing..but once you go in, it's a nice restaurant with tables and chairs.

We had a party of 5. I started off with Thai ice tea with boba--AVOID!! Some of the boba balls are hard and crumbly inside and some are mushh, they do not know how to cook it properly. They also served my drink in a wine glass which I thought was weird...

Any who, the food was a-okay. I've had better Vietnamese food before.
author: Luc L.

description: I ordered the 5-spice chicken rice plate. The chicken was dry, stringy, and hard. Yuck.
author: Mike M.

description: Ohk,so i live in union city and obviously there is no Pho restaurant around our area that is worth any stars so u go when u are desperate.. From time to time we travel to san jose to find a pho restaurant and with yelp reviews we follow and no where is good.. "Pho Kim Long" is suppose to be the spot for a lot but not I, since I truly can cook Pho so it would take a lot to impress me.. So I traveled to SF for my Citizenship test (which I pass btw:))  then my husband suggested that he takes me to this place which he and a coworker discovered while on a job delivery, I was skeptical as usual because it has been years since any place is I considered  so good.. Well!!!! Thank u miss Saigon! This pho is so aromatic the meat slices seemed hand cut but not the sliced rare beef they were machine sliced... The pho noodle is aldente to perfection, the broth was perfectly balanced and so savory... When eating pho the aroma you smell must wake up all your taste buds for your brain to go OH that was nice!!!! This place truly does that to my nose, my tongue, and my brain.... The hubby took our daughter up there which is 35 miles away from us just to eat and come back home... The to go he bought me I just ate today on a monday and usually to go pho's are only 50 percent good, but nope still so good as a to go!!!Thank you Miss Saigon!!!
author: Keli P.

description:
Great bowl of pho!

I went in and felt like I was digging my way to Vietnam, not coming up for air until I reached the bottom of the bowl. A belch and I felt embarrassed for my gluttony,  until I saw the guy next to me doing exactly the same.
author: Gary B.

description: Amazing food, great atmosphere, clean restaurant and awesome service! Definitely one of the best Vietnamese restaurants you can find in San Francisco! Highly recommend.
author: Alexandra T.

description:
Vietnamese soup was spicy with a spectacular broth. I also enjoyed the shrimp and crab imperial rolls. 

I do not know San Francisco very well, but I would not recommend a walk to this restaurant, by yourself, late at night. Some sketchy people and lots of homeless in the area. 

However, I must admit the food was terrific.
author: Robert C.

description:
Good service but just bland food.  The chicken vermicelli salad dish was just ok, but the chicken was not grilled or browned and had not flavor.   Also had tofu in it and the tofu was sour, like it was old.

Also had seafood soup and the broth was just a weird no flavor brown sauce.

Also, what's up with that weird Miss Saigon manikin that is actually a white women with Farrah Facet wig!
author: D H.

description:
We came here since Sow or whatever was closed and my friend really, really, like really, wanted to eat pho for some reason.  So we drove here after I found it on Yelp and she looked at the neighborhood while I was parking and she goes, "Where are we?  How come this is dangerous?  Where is this in San Francisco?  WHERE ARE WE?"  So we get out of the car and run to the stoplight.  Then we run across the street that leads directly into the restaurant and we're pleasantly surprised that it's NOT ghetto!  It's clean and the colors are light.  It's pretty spacious too.  We sat, ate our pho and spring rolls and talked for awhile.  Nobody minded.  The pho broth was clean and didn't make me sleepy afterwards, which means limited MSG (yes!).  They have other Asian and Thai dishes so it's an eclectic menu suited to please everyone.  I would come back!  

Yes, and we did run back to the car, avoiding the solicitors.
author: Chris L.

description:
Try this test...

We ordered dinner from Miss Saigon and it was delicious. Light sauces, fresh vegetables and everything arrived hot. We were so happy that we decided to order the EXACT SAME MEAL the next evening, and we couldn't have been more disappointed. Flavorless, overcooked vegetables, satay that was hours from contact with the grill, and everything arrived cold. Cold food could as easily be blamed on Eat24 but the preparation was dismal. We felt like we were eating leftovers of the previous night's meal. Yuck.

So 2.5 stars for food quality and .5 stars allowance for bad delivery service from Eat24. Sad that our closest Vietnamese restaurant is so unpredictable!
author: Paul A.

description:
I DON'T PHO AROUND!

Richmond, Berkeley, Emeryvile, Oakland, SF. If it serves "good" pho Ive tried it.
So far as of 10-22-2012, this place had the best pho I've ever had. The broth was flavorful but light. the beansprouts were fresh, meat was tender and not over-cooked. I usually dive for the bottle of Sracha, but this time there was no need. 
Since then, everything has been ehh.. or nasty. Places I used to go often don't compare and I am left sad..=(

Pho Combination FTW!
author: Ray C.

description:
I agree with the health score, which is 54/100, so a 54%.

We came here on a Sunday afternoon for a late lunch, and left neither happy nor disappointed. Decent crowd, but zero wait. 

They seemed to be understaffed. We sat at our table for about 15 minutes before they asked us for our order. There were at least four tables around that had not been cleared since we arrived, and were not cleared until halfway through our meal.

Location is meh. 6th Street, the river whereby the Tenderloin flows south of Market--not the greatest neighborhood, even by the light of day, but I wouldn't take a date here at night.

#1 Spring Rolls (shrimp) - These were middle of the road. I wouldn't order them again. There was a single shrimp, laterally cross-sectioned, on each roll.

#32 Vermicelli with grilled pork, egg roll - This was OK. The pork tasted a bit gamey or "dark" for me, and the egg roll tastes Filipino. Odd.

I won't be back--there's way too much good food waiting to be discovered in this area!
author: Molly L.

description:
The neighborhood is not great- avoid walking on 6th street if at all possible. Ambiance is the usual busy pho place- service has always been prompt when we've eaten in. Only time we've waited has been when they forgot and put cilantro in my broth- they realized before giving to me and insisted on replacing it. (Yes, I'm one of those ppl.)

Imperial rolls and raw beef pho are my recommendations. Broth is flavorful- oily as someone else mentioned but good.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Flew to the West Coast for work and got off the plane in search of pho. Went here because it had good reviews, was close to my hotel and open on a Sunday.

I ordered the pho and seafood fried rolls. Although the skin was crispy, the filling was 95% carrots I don't even think I saw anything else. Thinking maybe it was just the one I picked up, I checked the others, and was equally disappointed. 

The pho came out hot but the broth looked way too clear to me and before even tasting it I knew I picked the wrong thing. Didn't have that aroma and beef flavor that I wanted it to have and was too sweet. The actual meat was good and noodles were cooked well, but pho is all about the broth! 

 Service was okay but I was also the only one there.
author: Jenn V.

description:
Love the bun noodle bowls with added egg roll. Delicious. Only dock one star for the atmosphere and location. 

Definitely a great to-go spot!
author: Lee R.

description:
The neighborhood where its located can be a bit sketchy so be careful.

The food for the price here is great!

I would highly recommend the crab and shrimp rolls.

Everything I have ordered here as an entree was always delicious. Most recently I ordered the beef balls and rare beef pho and it hit the spot.

Come here for an affordable and hearty lunch or dinner!
author: Christine W.

description: Service sucked and pho wasn't what I expected. Too much star anise in broth for me. Pho shouldn't take 15-20 mins and I had to ask where it was and he didn't even apologize or return to let me know it's coming. It wasn't even busy tonight.  Very disappointed. Probably not returning.
author: Noy S.

description: The best pho you will find in SOMA. I usually pop in about 3-4 times a month on my lunch break. Order the #3 (deep fried egg roll) and the small #17 (pho with rare beef). Sure-fire way to kill that midday hangover. Staff is friendly and the price is reasonably cheap for San Francisco.
author: Jeff S.

description: Updating a review.. I think quality has gone down a little bit, or maybe take out just isn't as good. I ordered some takeout through DoorDash. The Bun thit nuong was just okay. Pork was very thin and dry, almost like jerky, and not much flavor. Also got the flan, which was just okay -- not creamy or custardy at all, and full of holes/air bubbles. There was also something stuck to the bottom of it.. not sure what it was but it looked dirty so I just threw it away. Maybe the in-restaurant dining is still good? But take out was not that great.
author: Rhea K.

description:
I dragged my coworkers here for lunch after reading they have the #1 pho in the city on one of the "best of" lists for SF. I know pho isn't vegetarian, but they did list vegetarian options on the menu, including soup, so I figured I'd try it while convincing my friends to try the authentic stuff.

According to them, the regular pho was amazing. They ordered the standard beef pho, plus we had appetizers of spring rolls and chicken wings to share. 

I ordered the pho tofu/vegetable soup and happily as asked if I wanted a vegetarian broth instead of meat-based (I chose the former). Food came out pretty quick, actually overlapping the appetizers, but that was workable since we had a limited amount of time for lunch. 

I'm sad to say though that the vegetarian pho here is adequate at best. The broth was rather plain and weak and the main vegetables were large cuts of broccoli and bok choy, along with chunks of tofu. Lacking flavour and just general "oomph", I ate the noodles and most of the broccoli but left the bok choy and over half the broth. This is not normal for me with ramen or pho... I love broth, it's one of my favourite parts of the soup. This was not worth a second try for me though. If looking for good vegetarian/vegan pho or noodle soup, Ramen Underground or Loving Hut are two amazing options.

I would go back here, as they have other vegetarian options in both noodle and rice dishes, and the spring rolls I had were *delicious*, but I'm sad about the pho. They might be #1 for their beef pho but definitely not a good option for veg*an ones.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
First time to San Fran so relied on Yelp for dinner. We loved everything. It's casual sit down and the prices are great. We shared the wonton soup. Delicious. 

Had pad Thai and chicken with lemongrass and veggie.
author: Robin V.

description: So good pho noodles!!!!!!!! This may be my new favorite Vietnamese place in the city. Got crab Rangoon and beef combination pho. So tasty and not expensive. I wanna come back if I'm craving Vietnamese food againnnnnn.
author: Silin N.

description:
Great vietnamese place! Decor and staff clothing are authentically Vietnamese, haha. A great selection of great Vietnamese dishes here. Bun thit nuong (vermicelli noodles with grilled beef) had ample side fixin's and was a big portion for a great price!
Pho was delicious as well, can't complain. Spring rolls came with delicious sauce and was not skimpy on the shrimp and pork = friends were quite pleased, yay!  For Vietnamese food first-timers, the pics on the menu were extremely helpful.

Might I add, our waiter took my table's (party of 7) orders without writing anything down, and didn't get anything wrong. Wow, what a working memory! He was even trying to suggest different things while we were ordering, it was quite a hoot. 

We got there right at the tail end of lunch, and got to witness the restaurant transition from serving lunch to dinner: lights were dimmed, and white tablecloths laid out. fancy! lol :)
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I came here looking for some good vietnamese food, and got mediocre vietnamese food.  I ordred the lemongrass beef vermicelli.  The vermicelli was a bit over cooked (more spongey, less "el dente" as the italians say) and the beef was stringy.  I could over look those things if the overall flavor was great, but it was just ok.  

So overall, decent food in terms of flavor, but nothing special.  Good portions. fast service and ok ambience with some cheesy decorations.  I'm going to try out the other vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood.  I'm hoping with the density of restaurants in the areas that one of them will become a favorite.
author: Helen Y.

description: Disappointed that both appetizer and entree were problematic.  The Imperial Rolls stuffed with shrimp and crab: the stuffing was soggy and the roll was wrapped too loose creating another soggy layer. My main was the Beef with Garlic Noodles, it arrived cold! The beef was on the tough side and lacked flavor, however the noodles were flavorful and cooked for the appropriate amount of time.  I never received my flan dessert instead they substituted some dessert with red beans without informing me. Completely disappointing.  The highlight was the nice delivery driver.
author: Kandle S.

description:
Let me get all the way through placing my order, even though the first thing they asked for was an address, then told me they wouldn't deliver four blocks because it's too far away.  Nevermind that they've delivered here several times before, which I told them repeatedly, and that it's never been a problem in the past.

Not cool.  My coworkers are angry at me and I've wasted ten minutes at lunchtime, and now my order is after everyone else has ordered and so will take forever.

I wish Yelp didn't claim places like this deliver.  It doesn't matter if they actually do; the upshot is that a bunch of people try to order from a place they're not able to order from, making those people unhappy with Yelp and the restaurant.

This restaurant should have better sense than to claim that it delivers.
author: John H.

description: Certainly not the best pho I have had. Actually, one of my least favorite. Also, did anyone see the health inspection sign? That is a little scary. But this overall was your typical Tenderloin Vietnamese hole in the wall with some simple pho. The broth seemed a bit watered down, and the beef was not prime quality. But the price is very reasonable, so if you just want some quick cheap pho, this is a decent spot.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Ugh...what is up with the red lighting?  

Besides the awful choice of lighting and the strange mannequin greeter, the place was standard fare, compact, and clean.  Plenty of tables for small and large parties.

We went with the standard bowl of pho and bun bo hue.  Maybe it is because I am from Texas, but $10+ for a bowl of noodles seems excessive.  Granted the portions are good for almost any appetite - but I rather have smaller portions (and prices) so I can include other goodness from the menu.  

The broth for the bun bo hue smelled and tasted just like it should.  In the broth various pieces and cuts of meat were thrown in - and lots of it.  I did not like the noodles used though as they were a bit harder than what I prefer - almost tasted like spaghetti noodles rather than rice noodles.

The pho was solid.  The broth was nice and beefy without much hint of MSG.  The noodles were perfect - not soft and mushy and not to firm/hard either.  There was plenty of meat floating around in the bowl.  I did not care much for the flank (I believe) as it was a bit tough and cut a bit thicker than I prefer.

The service was good.  I had to wave them down to get water and the bill but they responded pretty quickly.  

Overall not a bad option for a nice hot bowl of noodles but I would hesitate on dropping in too often due to the price and the lights gave me a headache.  Plus the neighborhood is sketch but usually normal people walking about.
author: Roy L.

description: Not bad. I ordered the medium rare beef noodle soup. Beef came out fully cooked which is less fun. The sauce saved it tho. Noodles all stick together a the bottom of the bowl. The younger waiter is very polite and nice.
author: Jov T.

description: I just discovered this place and am a total fan. They even have 33 Export too! On my first trip here I had a beef/garilc noodle combo. It was really satisfying. I can't wait to explore their huge menu (bang mi, pho and bun)...and practice my Vietnamese.
author: Darin E.

description:
The area around this place is sketchy, but the restaurant inside is like a safe haven, very clean with a conservative decor. I see many tourists and some locals coming here for a cheap meal. They have LCD TV screens on the walls - that night's movie was Kung Fu Panda (I really like that funny movie). The menus are designed like a handmade photo album, printed menu items on one side and pictures with a corresponding item number on the other.

Most of their customers are non-asian. And all the food plates have a nice presentation. The cha gio are larger than average, similar in size to an egg roll except for the typical imperial roll filing (ground pork, noodles and veggies) - it was very crisp and hot off the fryer. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/gE0h8As66SzyV4zJqFIWEw/l The shaking beef (bo luc lac) is their most popular dish, as I saw many customers ordering it - it looked good, taste was as expected. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/THNGG0XbEuyb32sbtsTlOQ/l But the flan dessert was a let down. http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/98C0AoKx6YbYV6rYvnc4lg/l It's the only item that didn't match the menu picture, also not creamy or delicate, a little dense.

The lunch specials are a good deal. Worth coming back to try more dishes.
author: Luis C.

description:
My first visit to Miss SaiGon was after a night in Mission that I shall never forget - despite having a lapse of memory that spanned 11 hours starting around midnight. Piecing together what I could from various sources, it was a surprise I was still alive and fairly unscathed. Having never been quite this hungover before, I was unfortunately unaware of the fact that pho doesn't sit too well after such binging, which led to me stopping after managing to hold down a mere hand-- mouthful, of bites.

Having been back once or twice since then though, my opinion remains the same as it did the first time: the pho here is actually pretty good. Despite being located in a sketchier part of town, they have an extensive menu (albeit with limited pho options), friendly waitstaff, affordable entrees, ample portions, and there's never a crowd or wait, making them one of my current go-to places for pho.
author: Johnny W.

description: The food portion doesn't justify the price they charge. Could have gone done the block and got more for less. Lastly the food is alright... Nothing to brag about.
author: Peter P.

description:
A fast, cheap, pretty decent lunch spot near downtown. Despite being located in a pretty dirty part of town (that nail salon without windows nearby seems like they might do things other than nails), this restaurant is clean and inviting. Be ready for a lot of pretty random foreign music in the background! They're very accommodating with large groups which is always a plus. 

I've noticed the menus each seem to have been individually made, scrapbook style with both pictures of food and an assortment of dried flowers. Charming?

Lots of entrees to suit most dietary preferences in addition to a very extensive beverages (non-alcoholic) menu. 

If you've got a large party and don't want to break the bank, I'd definitely recommend.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Want a nice comforting pho soup? This is your place! Funky combination of plasticy decor, edm (?!) music and stereotypical Asian service (for all you politically correct people, that isnt racist).
author: Alexander P.

description: HUGE bowls of noodles. I tried the egg pancake thing with fish sauce and it was really good. Extensive menu -- not just pho!
author: Vivian H.

description:
(See pics)

Review #1085.

Fancy looking but inexpensive place with more Chinese style Vietnamese food. Vermicelli and the eggrolls were both good, in decent portions but were totally Chinese style. The clay pot was very delicious with the rice at the bottom crunchy.

I was told by a Vietnamese that their fish was very authentic. Something to check out on my next visit.

This can easily be a good and convenient choice if you are in the neighborhood, or come for the nice authentic and traditional looking setting.
author: T L.

description:
I won. Just wanted to get that out of the way. In my group of four, I definitely won the ordering game. Not that it's a competitive thing, but I'm pretty sure if they handed out medals for ordering I would have taken home the gold.

My dining mates may not have known it was a contest, but that doesn't mean it wasn't challenging. The menu at this place is big. Monstrous, even. From pho to rice plates, to noodles, entrees and daily specials it's a challenge to wade through it all and find the right answer.

Still, I stuck with it and ended up with vermicelli noodles and grilled pork. Oh, that pork. That sweet, sweet, succulent, savory pork. We could have forgone the noodles and just had a heaping plate of pork and I would have died happy. Still, the noodles were fantastic and I opted for the egg roll order and it made a nice break of flavor. 

Even though I won, I would have been happy with a consolation prize. Everything else around the table looked delectable. I can't complain one bit about the two bits I tasted from other peoples' plates. The food here isn't overwrought. It's not precious. But it's not plain Jane either. It's just well done and pleasant. 

Know what you're ordering. With a menu this big, it's not all going to be your cup of tea. They're not all going to be winners. But just go out there and give 110% and play your game and you're going to walk away full and happy - champ of the ordering game.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Came here after Outside Lands and it was the most satisfying meal we could've gotten after three days of overpriced fries and pizza. They had run out of the regular beef broth and only had the spicy broth which the server assured us was not really spicy. I ordered pho tai, and the broth was actually really good. The large size is only $1 more than the small, which is half the size of the large, so I'd say go for the large. The server was really nice and made sure we didn't have any complaints. Good food and friendly staff. Would definitely go again!
author: Catherine C.

description: Very good and reasonable Vietnamese restaurant, which seems to use high quality ingredients. Pleasant service. Location a bit seedy (Mission and Sixth).
author: Jethro B.

description:
I had the bun Bo hue and it was very authentic. The soup base is very very good. Easily beats all the Viet places I've been in SF.
I also tried the pho tai and the soup base and noodles were also wonderful :)
The chicken satay!!!!!!! It took a little longer to cook but was amazing. The chicken was tender and not overcooked unlike most stay I've seen.
The servers were super friendly and fast to respond. Will definitely recommend to anyone who likes pho.
author: Jenn L.

description: A piece of glass in my chicken sandwich chipped my tooth. Every time I walk past this place, my tooth hurts a little  :(
author: Hameed T.

description:
This place is legit. I was contemplating whether it deserved a 5 star, but why not. 
There are a ton of Vietnamese restaurants in the city, but somehow lots manage to serve average pho broth. The quality of pho broth is generally my standard for judging how good Vietnamese restaurants are (just like ramen broth!), and Miss SaiGon is definitely above average. 

I was hesitant to come here at first, given the sketchy location and often times...scary walk to get here. But I live just a few blocks away and it was just too convenient to pass on. Glad I gave it a try and came here with an open mind - bc I'm definitely a regular now. I've tried a few other dishes besides the pho, and everything's pretty good. Two thumbs up for having the option for delivery.
author: Nattie X.

description:
Having actually been to Ho Chi Minh (Saigon) and eating Pho and Banh Mi from the best places there........I have to say that Miss Saigon is not very good at all.

1. The Pho.....was harsh. It was not balanced. It did not have a deep beef flavor. Too many slices of red onion for my taste. The meat was pretty good though. 

2. I ordered Banh Mi at around 1PM, and guess what.......they were out of stock. huh? How do you run out of ingredients that early in the day. Poor planning if you ask me.

3. Cafe Sua Da was too strong and bitter. 

Sorry guys.......you need to tighten up in the kitchen........there is too much competition out there to be playing around.

So people......don't waste your time...too expensive for what you get.

PS....the service is good. The staff are very courteous, and the place is clean.
author: Food P.

description:
Miss Saigon! I have been looking for a place that makes good Mi Hoanh Thanh for the LONGEST time. I must note that I live in SJ which consists of a bazillion vietnamese restaurants and every place I've tried in SJ has been mediocre when it comes to Mi Hoanh Thanh. So this one fine day during my lunch break, my coworkers wanted pho so I came along. Low and behold on the menu was Mi Hoanh Thanh. Had to try it. The staff here is super friendly unlike your typical vietnamese restaurants which is a huge plus. So anywhos I ordered my lovely bowl of Mi Hoanh Thanh. It comes out. Take a sip of the broth...

#dead

The broth was so amazing! The Hoanh Thanh Was amazing! Can't believe it took me this long to find a place that makes amazing Mi Hoanh Thanh and it just so happens to be in San Francisco.

Definitely coming back here. One suggestion I would make is to add more hoanh thanh. Still awesome though.
author: Quyenna T.

description:
They have really good pho. I wasn't disappointed. 

The food took awhile to get served tho, I wish they were a little quicker.
author: Song Z.

description: Great spot that I stumbled upon for a satisfying warm bowl of pho dac biet. Very bizarre decoration scheme which makes it funny and unique. I'd recommend this place to pho lovers and also the service is fast.
author: Briget P.

description:
Overall I enjoyed my time here at Miss Saigon. 

I ordered the banh xeo and the vermicelli noodles with grilled shrimp and seafood eggrolls. The banh xeo wasn't loaded with a lot of shrimp, but was still tasty. The dipping sauces were a perfect accompaniment. The lettuce and mint leaves given on the side were fresh. 

I will have to say that unfortunately, the vermicelli rice noodles that I received were slightly hard and the texture was a little disappointing. The overall taste of the dish was fine. I enjoyed the seafood eggrolls. It was fried perfectly.

Customer service was really sweet.
author: Ann S.

description: Well, I used to be a fan, but after today's Pho Ga Fail, I think I'm going to find another Vietnamese restaurant.  Luckily, I work near Little Saigon, so it shouldn't be a problem.  The chicken pho had what might have been chicken meat, but it really seemed like chicken connective tissue.  I like my pasta al dente, not my chicken.  The broth was tasty though.  I do love their fresh shrimp rolls and garlic noodles, so might just stick with those.
author: Ms. C.

description: Like most Asian cuisine restaurants that I frequent, there are always TONS of food selections on the menu. Variety is definitely important but if you're like me, having so many options makes it overwhelming to choose something to eat. For that reason, I always end up ordering spring rolls and beef ball pho. I would agree that the food is good at Miss SaiGon but it's not good enough to go out of your way. I wasn't blown away by my selections. While they are pretty generic, the spring rolls and pho were simply okay. Just to be clear, there is nothing wrong with this place. I just think there might be something better out there.
author: Sasha P.

description:
Not a bad place to come for lunch.  I work just down the block and if you're able to brave the gangsters and crack heads, you're going to have a good time here.

The bun thit is pretty good, very generous with their portions.  I haven't tried the pho yet though.

nice place to grab a quick bite for lunch if you're in the area, but nothing to go out of the way for.
author: Tu T.

description:
The food was good, big portion, and delicious. The service was pretty decent as well. 

I wasn't a fan of the decro tho, it's so dark that it kept reminding me the fact that I was in Tenderloin... And what's up with the mannequin in the front door?...
author: Cissy M.

description: Vietnamese street food at its best. Hanoi Pork is my favorite dish here. The fried prawn with garlic noodle is second.
author: Michael R.

description:
I've been here almost 5 times and I'd have to say this place is very consistent and serves very flavorful food.

I've had the Pho with brisket and beef ball. The broth is flavorful and comes out very hot. You can taste the msg in broth just a fyi.

They use quality cuts of meat and give you decent portions.

They have tasty rice plates as well.

They're located on 6th St in the hood so if you don't mind seeing a few Crack heads and sketchy folks come check them out its worth it!!
author: Lyle D.

description: I used to love this place - and always joked about braving the less than desirable location to eat here. Don't get me wrong, I like their pho and several other dishes that I've tried. I'd probably give those 4 stars, but they just don't seem to have enough people on staff.  The food takes forever to get and the waiters are hard to track down to get a replacement fork or even to just get the bill.  What should be a one hour meal will turn into a two hour one, even when the restaurant is half full.  Sigh.  I'm sad that I'll be visiting Miss Saigon less often that I used to.
author: Janet Z.

description: Food was excellent. Lots of flavor and good service. We  enjoyed 3 different entrees to share and had desert and it was all cooked well. We will be back.
author: Wil A.

description:
Three stars and I keep coming back. Good pho in the downtown-ish area, with a really comprehensive menu. Has something for everyone. We usually order, pho, shaken beef, some vegetarian something, and spring rolls.

They're relatively quick, but the amazing thing is the way the waiter doesn't write anything down, and gets everything right. We are usually a group of 6 with some fun dietary restrictions, so...impressive, sir. Impressive, indeed.

The good: decent food, easy to get a table for a larger group at dinner.
The bad: the music is so. weird. The last time we were in there, they were playing instrumental top 40 with...barnyard animals overlaid. What. The. Hell. Can't make this up.
author: Amanda B.

description: Too expensive for the lack of quality in their food and small portions. We ordered 2 types of noodle soup and pork vermicelli. It was just okay. Not worth going back to.
author: Trish M.

description:
In terms of food, there's not much to say. 

The pho was good and clean - nothing more, nothing less. I'd come back for it. Eggrolls were crispy and seemed pretty fresh. One complaint in regards to food was that the spring rolls came out with one tiny piece of shrimp in each - disappointing.

The service is terrible. We had to ask for everything - napkins, flatware, the plate of sprouts, jalapeno, mint & lime, water, sriracha. Really, we had to ask for each thing individually multiple times.

I'd come back only because of the proximity.
author: Grace K.

description:
Quick review as I don't have much good news.  Here's the breakdown

Pros:  
very friendly accommodating staff
tasty strawberry smoothie

Cons: 
not a great part of town, had to avoid a bunch of shady looking characters to get to the door
Out of boba 
Got the vermicelli with tofu and the vermicelli was so overlooked it was mush as though it was precooked and warmed up.

I will not be going back.  I'm only giving 2 stars bc the guy was very nice who waited on me otherwise, 2 thumbs down.
author: Julie S.

description: Loved this place. Stumbled upon it before going to a car show. Ambiance was fun with Christmas lights and music, which I love! Got the filet mignon pho, the beef was super tender. Also got the fried pork egg rolls which were great too. The wait staff was also quick and attentive. Will be going back!
author: Jessica B.

description:
This is my go-to place for pho!  What I like about it:
-family owned place, always very friendly and efficient service
-great tasting pho
-reasonably priced items
-extensive menu

the only negative I would say is that it is located in a seedier area of town, but other than that, this is great find!
author: Viv J.

description:
I wanted to love this place so badly because I'm always searching for good pho restaurants in the city, but I didn't. The atmosphere was alright (aside from the creepy mannequin who welcomes you in the front), the space was clean, the staff was friendly, and the cucumber in my water glass was a nice touch... but in the end, it's all about the food for me.

My bowl of chicken pho tasted so much like soap that I couldn't get over the feeling that I was slurping up a Sriracha-flavored bubble bath. On top of it, I was shocked by how few teeny chicken bits there were in the broth! I had to diligently search for protein morsels in the soapy noodles. Not ideal. 

Sometimes, it's possible for a restaurant to simply be too clean...
author: Kelcey M.

description:
Disappointed.

I was reading the good reviews about miss saigon and decided to give it a try. We ordered the special noodle soup bun bo hue and bun rieu. It did take some time before the two bowls of noodle soup came out (longer than I expected). 

First taste to both soup was - MSG. Both noodle soup were pretty salty, and to me, it's more like MSG rather than just salt. The noodle itself was ok, and the ingredients as well, but I could not take the soup.

Overall it was just alright. Service was alright, food was just so-so. I will not be back.
author: Louisa L.

description: After eating crab today from my aunt's, I had one of my crazy cravings... This time for bun rieu (crab noodle soup)! Called multiple places and many Vietnamese restaurants are apparently closed Tuesdays. Finally found a spot that was open and had this dish! Lol. Not the best I've ever had but it filled the void.
author: Penny N.

description: With the plethora of amazing restaurants in SF, this isn't one of them. We walked here in this sketchy neighbor, when Tien Tin was packed. Should have stayed there, but with a party of 11, Miss SaiGon could accommodate us, which was a plus. The restaurant is fairly large, so if you have a large party, this place is a plus. Guess I should bump them up a star for that. Oh well. Pho (#17), was ok. Broth was a little too sweet, and they served a lemon slice with it. Isn't it supposed to be lime? $10 for a bowl of Pho. A little on the pricier side, but it was OK. Not amazing, but not bad either. Shaken beef was tasty, but was $16. Again, on the sweeter side, but the potatoes and onions softened it up a bit. A little too sweet for my taste, and I like sweet. OK, but pricey for what you get (especially when I ordered it for a 6 yr old!). Also got said daughter the garlic butter noodles for $5. Thought that was a steal, but it was a pretty small plate with not much flavor or composition. Just a little pile of noodles. She didn't eat much, so $5 down the drain. Others seemed to like their entrees. Not a lot of Vietnamese people here as patrons. Bad on a Sat night. 11 people, tab came to $150 w/ tip. Actually not bad, considering most entrees were $10+. So, guess I'll bump it up a star. It was ok. Nothing amazing, but not bad either. But I'd check out other places. My kids were scared of the area.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Pho was definitely on my mind, as I traveled over 2500 miles with a cold from tropical temperatures in the mid-90s, to the chilly 60 degrees of San Fran. I wanted something soupy, with a kick, to warm my soul and clear my sinuses. 

A quick search of who delivered in the area, so Miss SaiGon it was. 

First of all, EXTREMELY easy ordering process directly through Yelp. With a couple of clicks, we made our selections, and within the designated time-frame of 45 minutes, there was a knock on our hotel room door. Major bonus points!

I just ordered the standard, and was pleased with the amount of the usual add-ins. Tons of noodles, cilantro, onions, basil, sprouts, lime and rare brisket. And none of that already browned sh*t, this was pink and rare. Swooooooon. 

The broth traveled fairly well, and I was delighted to find a little bit of fat forming at the top... "that's where the flavor is"  and is missing from most of the places in my city. I added some jalapenos and spice and began to breathe again. The broth was flavorful and hit the spot... I desperately tried to finish it all (huge portion) and felt a bit of sadness inside when I couldn't. 

I have no idea of what the boyfriend ordered, as I was completely immersed in my own hotel bed soup eating experience. 

The next time San Fran calls me for work, you bet your ass I'm ordering delivery from Miss SaiGon again. 

YUM.
author: Allie A.

description:
Reviews on here are hilarious... ;)  I hope I don't get toll mein ...

They were really nice but because I was a white woman ...talked me outta the five spices chicken because they would have to clean the wok!  That's a new one.  Give me a break and thanks for discriminating against my taste buds because I am white.  Condescending attitude was as follows:   "I think that YOU should eat something like this..." Pointing to the bland Pho Ga, I wanted to say:  "and I think that you should be eating this" while pointing down.  I chose the high road. The rolls were good but it's hard to "F" up spring rolls.

Notable, it's clean AND there is a scary mannikin dressed as a hot Vietnamese lady standing by the doorway that I said "Hello" when I first walked in which made me look like an arse!!!  

I doubt I would go out of my way to eat here again if when I return to the Bay Area.
author: Patricia Patti P W.

description: Don't let the neighborhood scare you. This place is great. Chicken pho is good. Place is clean.waiters are prompt
author: Sri K.

description: First I do want to mention that while I was waiting for the food, I got an education on Brazilian birds! They play beautiful nature programs on their tv's !! A huge thank you as I hate places with giant screens playing sports! The music relaxing, and the food excellent! Veggie bun and Thai ice tea. Delicious. Service excellent! Price is right. What more can you ask for? There is a page for vegetarians. That's me. Thank you! I wish more places had nature programs on their tv's!
author: Louise M.

description: Run of the mill mom n pop. Decent food, but service was messy. Forgot about one of our dishes.
author: Howe L.

description:
Shrimp and pork spring rolls didn't have hardly any flavor. The pho broth is clean with lots of beefy flavor w/o being greasy. Small portion w/ lots of noodles and little meat. I really wanted to like this place but it was disappointing.

They also use plastic chop sticks. Not a fan of plastic.
author: J G.

description:
The food was good but DO NOT ORDER TAKE-OUT HERE, especially online.
I ordered through eat24 via yelp and it took forever.  It said it would take 15-30 min on the site and I got there in 15.  People ordered and got there food while I sat there waiting for my order.  I ended up getting the food 30 min after I got there and 20 min after the time window they gave.  This was all for Vietnamese sandwiches!  I've seen people make Vietnamese Bahn Mi sandwiches in 30 seconds.  Obviously they don't prioritize their take-out customers.
author: Alex M.

description:
Don't let the mannequin at the front scare you - this is some really, really good food. The menu is overwhelming so just to save you the trouble, get the #33. It took a few tries for me to land on this one (there are a *ton* of options) but now I know I will never deviate. It's basically a bowl of pho with some kind of pork or veggie rolls placed on top, all mixed together with a sweet hearty broth. It's a massive meal, actually, but mix in a little hot sauce and you basically have the perfect dish. 

Saigon also gets points for the bizarre 70s-ish music videos they inexplicably play in a never-ending loop on the TVs overhead. Somehow, it all makes sense.
author: James H.

description: Visiting San Fran from Boston make me cautious of where to go for Vietnamese food since we don't know the area at all.  My friends and I decided to try Miss Saigon.  When we walked to the place, I was skeptical to walk in but my friends said we could try.  It turned out the place was good.  All my non-Vietnamese friends liked their food.  The price was reasonable.  The portion was decent.  The service was nice.  My Com Phap #98 was so good.  By boyfriend shaken beef with rice and noodle (I had to custom order because it was not on the menu), the other two orders #97 shrimp and noodle and #44 chicken and noodle was also good.  Appetizer: chicken wings (Vietnamese style) and skew chicken with peanut butter sauce was also good.  And plus, we have free dessert (I think it was called corn pudding which was a combination of sticky rice, corn, coconut milk and vanilla).  Thank you for a good dinner.  If we ever come back to San Fran, we definitely come back to Miss Saigon.
author: Mongbinh D.

description: They make you realize that Vietnamese food is a bit bland with out fish sauce.  My rice box didn't come with any fish sauce at all.  Also, no utensils and napkins.  The egg cake looks like meat loaf.  Where's the egg?  It's brown and flour and not yellow.  Well, at least they deliver.
author: Byron L.

description:
If you are coming here for the Pho, Pho some where else. It really is not that great. I mean I had high hopes. It looks clean, smells clean, and the staff was nice, but the Pho was ehhhh. I should of had Ramen noodles from the super market bad.

Sorry Miss Saigon, but you should go back to Vietnam and bring back some real Pho for me. You owe me after that bad Pho.
author: Luis D.

description: Decent bowl of pho but they lack the variety of beef pho that other typical pho places have.  And it's the only Vietnamese place I've ever been to that didn't serve the pho I usually order, except for his place in a suburb in Illinois.  I'm not convinced I'd come here again to get my pho fix.  It just isn't as good as other places I've tried.  I'd come back to try a different dish though.
author: Debbie L.

description:
I came here with a large group for lunch, and they had a little trouble accommodating us despite the fact that we had a reservation. In their defense, they did seem to have several large groups that day.

The food was pretty good. I had Pho with seafood. The broth was tasty and it was a balanced soup. The service was just ok. I would go back to check out other items on the menu.
author: Alex M.

description: This is definitely a great place to go to when you're craving good & cheap Viet food. Their noodle portions are generous, so you'll get bang for your buck & I love having some rolls along with the noodle. It just completes the meal :) But the ambiance there isn't the best. It has more of a traditional asian restaurant feel with foreign decorations & music playing. It also doesn't look like the cleanest place, but with the delicious food in front of you, you won't notice.
author: Alice H.

description:
Great spot for a sit-down Vietnamese lunch during the workday. The food is delicious, the portions are ample, and the service is friendly and attentive.

I've had both the bun (rice noodle bowl) and pho (noodle soup), and both were excellent. This shouldn't be a complaint, but I think the pho actually has too much beef in it for my taste(!). I'll be back.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I came here on my lunch break with a group. The place was fairly busy, but they were able to seat all 8 of us promptly. 

I ended up ordering a small bowl of pho with beef balls for the cold San Francisco weather. While the garnishes of basil and bean sprouts seemed fresh, the pho itself was very mediocre. The broth was full of MSG, to the point where I spent the next few hours guzzling down a gallon of water. I can feel my mouth and throat drying out just thinking about it.

Service was not the best. Food came out slow and it took forever for them to take our orders. Additionally, no one bothered to refill any of our waters. The price was expensive for a small bowl of pho; however, they were nice enough to split checks for everyone
author: Vivian L.

description: This is a great, inexpensive Vietnamese restaurant.  The menu is organized very well and the pictures help a lot for people that are not familiar with Vietnamese cuisine.  This is a great place for lunch or a casual dinner.
author: Adam B.

description:
Step 1) order the pho
Step 2) put 3 parts sriracha to 1 part hoisin sauce
Step 3) squeeze some lime juice in there 
Step 4) enjoy life
author: William L.

description: This is a good Vietnamese restaurant. Convenient if you are at the Moscone Convention Center. It is in the worst part of town, but hey, you got to eat and many of the best food is in lousy areas, especially Vietnamese food. Not quite as good as Tú Lan, but more upscale. I like their shaken beef and garlic noodles. Their wonton soup is really good too (I know it's Chinese not Vietnamese and it's not even authentic Chinese, but it's really good). I love the mannequin that greets you at the door, she may be a bit tranquil but she's worlds better company than the creatures right outside the door.
author: Peter K.

description: Dish #42 gave me food poisoning. I didn't realize they had a score of 54/100 before I went. I will never go back.
author: Michael M.

description:
Miss Saigon has the best Pho Tai Mem (filet?). 

My credibility:
I'm from the Bolsa/Viet central in Orange County.
Currently live in Berkeley so I hit up the pho shops in Oakland as well.

Why Miss Saigon beats everyone else:

1) the broth is not overly opaque, but still has a clear sense of taste. good use of beef bones and bone marrow. 
2) noodles on point. not too soft like some Kevin's Noodle House near USF.
3) Hanh Tran (extra green onions on the side) were soooo on fleek. they added green chives instead of just the white scallions parts. and their scallions are always so thin which is hard to find these days.

4) SERVICE - LOVE THE LITTLE OLD LADY THAT WORKS THERE. if you can speak viet, speak viet to her. she says it makes her happy.
author: Vi T.

description:
I can't count the number of pho restaurants I've frequented in my short 21 years of life, but MY GOD, Miss Saigon blows every other pho restaurant out of the water. I had pho with meatballs and everything from
the broth to the noodles were to die for. I'm someone that won't eat pho without sriracha, but their pho was so good, I didn't even drench the soup in the hot sauce. If you're in San Francisco and need the best hangover cure, go here and you'll sober right up. 

Ughhhhh I want some right now just thinking about it.
author: Caroline C.

description: The broth for the pho is absolutely delicious. Some of the best I've ever had. I'll be sad if I find out there's MSG in it though - I find myself being quite thirsty after the fact.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Was not super impressed with this place. The spring rolls were almost too big and didn't taste fresh. 

I order the chicken with glass noodles and did enjoy the taste of the broth but there weren't alot of noodles in my bowl but runs of parsley and green onions. My chicken also wasn't tasty or fresh either.

Given its across town from where I live and in a super shady area (my bf and kept looking out the window to check our car was still on the streets in one piece) not likely we'll be stopping by again.
author: Pauline T.

description:
These guys "profile" a bit. With my pho I was given a fork n spoon.  Ok fine, I looked around to see who else got this with their pho and see if there were any traditional soup spoons.   I definitely noticed that a group of Asians next me were using them.  So I wanted one as well.. I never used a Western spoon with Pho. I asked for one holding up my silver spoon... (They spoke English) .. He looked at me and said use that spoon.. I'm like NOPE , give me the other one.. Pointing to the group next to me..( I shouldn't have to argue with this!!). He laughed.. SERIOUSLY!?!?!!..   GYFGABTAM1!!!!!  

Oh the pho is definitely for newbies.. Way better in the Loin.. Had it so many times in San Jo, Orange County, and several times in Vietnam ( southern n northern style) .. Also my Vietnamese friends from all around Cali take me to their hidden spots..   I would definitely recommend the Pho to people who are new to it:)..
author: Demanding T.

description: The vietnamese sandwiches took almost 30 minutes to make and added to my pork sandwich was some sort of liver paté - the sandwich itself tasted like cat food. I actually believe my cat's food is better than the food served here. I tipped generously anyway. Ive had my fair share of low budget banmi before and this one takes the cake.
author: Sarah T.

description:
A friendly, delicious place for lunch.  I love the crepe (which I get with shrimp only, as I just don't like pork that much, though I'm sure theirs is great), pho with beef meatballs, and any of the lunch or dinner combo plates (especially with five spice chicken or garlic noodles).  A great price, and a nice fresh option for the area.
Host/Manager Cory is super friendly and helpful.  Become a regular; they'll remember you!
I also order from them all the time for office deliver on Eat24.
author: Aileen J.

description:
Went here several years ago on my first trip to SF with a Vietnamese friend and she gave it mad props. The area gets a little shady at night, but the food is great. 

I'd actually forgotten the name/location of this restaurant since my first visit, then, fortuitously, on my most recent visit to the city, the friend-of-a-friend I was staying with lives right around the corner! Went back to try the newly-added pork banh mi, which was amazing. It takes 15 min for takeout, but it's so fresh and delicious; it's worth it.
author: Renee G.

description:
Literally the worst service I've ever had. I have never felt inclined to leave no tip until I went here. They flat out ignored us. 1/4 of us got our main meal a full 45 minutes before the rest of us did. There were several people in the restaurant who got their main entree before we did. And all we ordered was pho. This was ridiculous and the waiter did give us 10% off, but not enough to make up for the terrible service. 

Despite all of this...the food was pretty good.
author: Sarah D.

description: I really like this place. They are incredibly nice and the food is fresh and varied. I especially recommend the Bun Rieu.
author: Marc V.

description:
i work right around the corner from this place, so often times i will either hear  coworkers on the phone ordering to-go, or "wanna go to Miss Saigon for lunch?" echoing around the office. i must admit that sometimes the msg overload kills me, but most of the time it totes hits the spot.

i find this place a hit or miss.

HIT:  the thai iced teas
MISS:  the teas are served in very tall, narrow glasses, and served with your average bendy straw that is too damn short for the glass. prepare the fishing abilities, because the straw is guaranteed to sink down in the glass.

HIT:  #19 - Pho with beef balls and medium rare beef... YAWM.
