MISS:  who da hell cuts their beef balls into thirds??? trying to make it look like there are more beef balls than there really are...i see you miss saigon.

HIT:  one day, we had a party of six. three of us order straight numbers, no modifications. other three make modifications due to peanut allergies, personal preference, etc. server took our order using no notepad, no nothing.  impressive. very impressive.
MISS:  his success rate: 1 / 3 times.  screwed up all three orders the last few times we were here.  almost killed my peanut-allergic coworker by piling peanuts on her noodles.

oh and the ice waters are served with cucumber slices. cool cool.

i wouldn't exactly say miss saigon offers the BEST pho in the city, since you can definitely find the same good quality of pho (if not better) at a cheaper price with larger portions. but considering the area, miss saigon is one of the better (and safer) places to be for lunch.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Over the past 6 months, I've become a regular here. Nothing beats some good pho and imperial rolls when you're nursing a nasty hangover. I always get some variation of pho ga (chicken). The vegetables always seem fresh and are cooked to perfection. My bf gets the number 29, seafood pho, and the shrimp are always perfectly deveined (which is my personal test for restaurants). 
   I have to give a serious shout out to the awesome staff! They are always so polite and provide excellent service. Since we frequent this joint often, they know our order and provide us with other options to help us spice up our food even more.
   Can't wait to visit again!
author: Ariel B.

description:
Another date night with the wife.  Tonight she was working late at the new Federal Building on 7th Street and Mission.  I was hungry and wondered what was in the area, since I had parking.  She said she goes to Miss SaiGon for lunch and we could go there.

Miss SaiGon is located right on the corner of 6th Street and Mission.  The neighborhood is not the best...so be smart and be aware of your surroundings.

We arrived and was seated, the place was a bit busy.  There were 3 workers at the front of the house, taking orders, serving and busing...sort of not efficient.

From the time we were seated to when we had our order taken, was about 15 minutes...a bit long I would say.  The staff would walk by and look at us and then head off, each thinking the others were helping us.

For appetizer we ordered the small wonton soup #7 ($4.75).  You get 5 wontons in light broth with.  The broth is wonderful with some fried garlic....yummy.  The wontons were pork and shrimp...good size about the perfect size for the spoon.

For the main course she had the  Bun Rieu #28 ($9.50) - Minced crab meat in a tomato soup base with vermicelli noodles.  Nice flavor broth,,,slightly tart.  The minced crab meat appears to be suspended inside some light fish balls.  The only problem is that I do not taste any crab at all.  Should be called fish ball with vermicelli.

I had the Com Suon Nuong #46 ($8.50 + $1.00 for a fried egg on top) - Crushed rice with pork chop.  First of all, I love the side veggies (pickled cabbage, shredded lettuce and carrots, sliced cucumber...all with the fish sauce poured over it).  Now for the bad news...it was not a pork chop...it was actually a single thin piece of pork (like the one they use for the grilled pork).  For $8.50, I expected at least a 1/4" thick real pork chop or 2 of these 1/8" thin sliced pork.

Bathroom time: there are a separate men's and women's room.  The men's room is only a single user one.  The room was well lit and basically clean except for the location of the trash can.  The trash can was next to the sink, which would be fine if the door was within reach.  The trash can had a lid, so people would was their hands, use the towel to dry their hands, then use the towel to unlock and open the door....now how to reach and step on the lever to left the lid of the trash can....not possible, so what would you do?  Of course you throw the paper towel on to the lid of the trash can.
author: Jerry W.

description:
How the heck does this restaurant have so many stars? This was the nastiest Vietnamese food I've ever had. My husband and I started out with the banh xeo and it was so gross. They barely gave us any pork and shrimp and it was so greasy. My husband, who was starving, could only take one bite of it. We're from Austin so we thought Vietnamese food in SFO would be 100x better but we were so wrong! As far as the pho goes, the quality of the meat was poor and the noodles looked old and were clumping together. I got the seafood noodle soup and I didn't even touch my meat out of fear of getting food poisoning.

Also, this restaurant is in the GHETTO. I almost had an anxiety attack walking to this place from our hotel because there were crackheads left and right yelling at you.  Stay away!
author: Julia P.

description: The pho was sooooo good and the chicken wings are incredible. The bowl didn't have much meat in it. The imperial rolls were super yummy. Avoid the sandwiches - this isn't the best place to get them. There wasn't much flavor in the filling, and the bread to filling ratio was wayyyyy too high. I had to tear off half my bun. The banana cake was seriously amazing.
author: Monika M.

description: I have been here quite a few times, and I have to say they hav some excellent Pho. My favorite so far has been Pho #19 (yikes... I get it so much I remember the number). During lunch the place is usually quite busy, although it could be because me and my friends come here in large groups. Its a good sized portion, even when ordering the lunch size (which I did, and I think they gave me the dinner size anyway). Cucumber in the water is a nice touch. The server was always very friendly and smiling... kind of creepily actually, like.. constantly smiling... like maybe his face was stuck.
author: Bryan M.

description: We had the chx with lemongrass and chili, noodles with garlic chx basil  and won ton soup. All were excellent and fresh.
author: ryan j.

description:
This review is strictly based on my experience with there service, Pho Ga, Minced Crab soup, drinks, and location to niceness ratio ...

I been here almost once or twice a week since I discovered it.. The location in right on 6th St ... boy howdy if you live in the SOMA you know what 6th st is about ... but once you walk in you:

A: Get spooked by the manikin holding a menu but then get calmed by the water flowing behind her ..

B: Get greeted with a smile and given your choice of where to sit n eat

C: The food ...

The Pho Ga, to me, is great flavorful and sweet with a good amount of chicken and a great noodle . Mmm and the minced crab in tomato broth is also a winner .. Thai tea and drip iced coffee is also a favorite ..

Service is friendly and responsive ... Just a winner in my book what another great little oasis on 6th st ..

Odd choice of music selection though .. :)
author: Anthony S.

description: SO yummy! Quick delivery and great product. I actually ordered it two nights in a row (I was visiting from LA). Deffo recommend it for delivery :)
author: Paget K.

description:
By far my favorite Vietnamese joint in the city!! Maybe it's because I live just down the street. Like a block away. But I come here regularly. At least every couple weeks. This is also my go-to place whenever anyone comes to town or wants to eat in the neighborhood.

It upsets me people would pass this place up for Tu Lan (now closed, FYI) or Turtle Tower (I thought it was just 'ok'), but I think more and more people are finally starting to talk about Miss Saigon.

My favorite dishes are the cold vermicelli noodles with grilled pork, fresh vegetables and fried egg rolls and the pho tai (pho with rare meat). They also always have some interesting stuff playing on the TVs (like a British boy band concert DVD or clips that look like they belong in karaoke videos - you know which one I'm talking about!)

The staff are always friendly and recognize me now, even showing concern when I call in my orders and don't ask for no onions (I hate onions! But I'll just pick them out when I take out).
author: Matthew B.

description: First off getting our food was a hour an a half late!!! On top of that every time we called it was always 10 mins!! When we are in fact 4 blocks away!! The food was ok but not very warm at all. The delivery man was pretty embarrassed an wasted no time in leaving an already knew he wasn't getting a tip! Now onto the food....I ordered the chicken lemon grass curry. Normally lemon grass is in big chunks an then taken out they chopped me up An eating the dish was a lil hard to eat considering it was like there was toe nails in every bite considering lemongrass is pretty fiberous! The egg rolls weren't as crispy an a lil soggy. My bf got the combination dish with shrimp, wings, and short ribs he said it was fine just needed to be heated up.  Also the restaurant blamed there lateness on losing our order. I'm sure dine in a lil better! But If you order beware!!
author: Greg S.

description:
To the tranny with the cherry jubilee lipstick - you looked ravishing, seductively walking around the restaurant. I'm not sure of your role here, but you certainly had my undivided attention. 

You must be real special for me to willingly share my food with you, cause I DO NOT LIKE SHARING MY MF FOOD. I don't care. Don't ever serve me a communal bowl of rice!! I want my own bowl. 

The service here is ridiculously slow. Every time I come, it's empty so I don't understand what the hold up is in the kitchen. The kitchen looks unsanitary and the window where orders are placed, was FILLED with dirty dishes. 

People rave about the pho, but that shit tastes regular to me. Their rice dishes aren't anything remarkable either. I ordered the Ga Xao Sa Ot, it was shrug worthy. The veggies were perfectly steamed tho, so kudos to them for that. Our apps were brought out in the middle of our meal -- THREE MEASLY EGG ROLLS. They seriously couldn't find the time to make them before our entrees?! 

Oh and their tapioca sucks. That's hella disrespectful. Don't ever fuck up my taro slush with your gross balls. 

Don't believe the hype, this is just another Vietnamese spot.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Points for decking the place out with ALL the Christmas decorations and playing an "It's A Small World After All"-like Christmas DVD on loop on the six screens, but there were a few misses that make me think I probably won't rush back. 

-Egg rolls were sups greasy and just didn't have a lot of flavor. 
-My bun (the grilled chicken) had only a wee bit of chicken and was served with the traditionals, but for the lettuce, these folks use iceberg, yuck. 
-They forgot a dish, no biggie because we were full after the app and my bun, but still, would have been nice to have received it.
author: Corey D.

description:
Best Pho I've ever had!

The staff is very friendly, and always delivers great food and service. I'm a big fan of the #23 and #27.

I always start off by ordering the egg rolls!
author: victor s.

description: Great Vietnamese food! I had the pho and shaken beef and it was amazing. Definitely one of the best places I've eaten.
author: Alessandro P.

description:
Ah yes, I remember Miss Saigon. That's the musical with the huge helicopter, right? Oh, and of course, yet another example of the powerful white man exerting his undue influence on the poor Asian bar girl, pregnant no less. For shame. But there's not a helicopter to be found at this new Sixth Street eatery, and you can probably have all the racially motivated persecution you want outside. Regardless, I have to applaud the owners for joining Split Pea Seduction by putting another stake in the ground for urban renewal in this godforsaken neighborhood.

It's a clean, open space with a pretty extensive Vietnamese menu. Jamie W. and I decided to come here just before seeing a bunch of voice-cracking kids perform Elton John songs at the Zeum. I immediately went for the $6.25 Pho dac biet, which had all sorts of different kind of beef in a big bowl of noodles and broth (see my photo). Savory and tasty. If pho is not a good litmus test for good Vietnamese, then a spring roll truly separates the men from the boys...it was decent though the rice paper was a bit chewier than I like.

Jamie had the $6.95 Com thit nuong bi cha, which was a couple of pieces of grilled pork, a big scoop of rice, a little zucchini and carrot salad, shredded pork and noodles, and a little egg cake (see my photo). Pretty good for the money I'd say. We even got treated to a bowl of Vietnamese-style tapioca in warm milk for dessert. Service was so gosh-darn friendly that you couldn't tell if they were being bombarded with the shopping cart brigade lurching by the windows. And it's all such a good deal considering the arm, leg and other appendages you may need to sacrifice for a meal at the Westfield Shopping Centre just a block away.

FOOD - 4 stars...a very fine pho and such a good price
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...clean, bright...wonder how long that will last in this area
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...super-attentive...and they wear matching shirts with their logo (see my photo)
TOTAL - 4 stars...oh yeah, so worth it...prospects on Sixth Street are looking up one place at a time
author: Ed U.

description:
Don't let the reviews fool you this place is not as good as it seems.

I had the shaking beef with garlic noodles. The beef was ok but it was prepared with onions and potatoes and the potatoes were HARD, as in not cooked. I also ordered a green tea peach flavored boba. It was horrible, I never send things back but I could not drink it at all. Tasted like a shake and not tea and no hint of peach just tons of sugar. The boba was hard. When I told the waiter I didn't like it he just looked at me and smiled. I had to ask him if I can exchange it for something else and got the Thai tea which was fine, nothing special, super sweet if you like it that way, I watered mine down. 

Overall, I would never come back here again. Its also in a terrible part of town so I didnt feel comfortable walking around by myself.
author: Meghan N.

description:
This is definitely one of the most delicious places for pho around the Union Square/downtown area. During lunch hours there can be a wait, but the turnover is pretty fast. 

The food itself is definitely 4 star, but the service bumps it down to 3. Every time I visit here they try to upsell you on the food. A lot of the time, they do it in a way that doesn't make you realize that if you agree you're going to be charged extra. I am all about working for your money, but there are plenty of people in and out of here everyday that you don't need to try to use shady tactics to get an extra couple of dollars. 

Also, the wait for your check and running your card or getting change is extremely slow. They're super fast to bring you your food though, which really is just mind boggling to me. If you're in a hurry, ask for the check as soon as you get your food, that way you'll finish eating and get the check around the same time.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Great and friendly service, out of the 20 Pho places I have been to so far, this is certainly one of the best. One small downside is that the tables  weren't super clean. But that's kind of how most pho places are.

Btw beware of the neighborHOOD. I think it would be the main reason why I wouldn't come back. Street walkers, drug addicts, and gang bangers is not necessarily something you want to venture through to get soup on your lunch break. Unless you're feeling lucky that day.
author: Max N.

description:
I loved their great food and I loved their Bánh Xeo x) but I'm giving them a 3 star because of the location....

It is pretty shady around that neighborhood and I will def not go eat there after 4pm.
author: Rio S.

description: :) great services. food were great. Deep fry rolls ehh were okay. Summer spring rolls were good. I ordered #29. It was seafood and pork, but there was only one piece spice of pork meat?!?!?! They only give you one plate of sprouts with all other goodies :/ (we had four bowls of pho) yes, we all had to share one plate of sprouts. Price range was okay.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
I came here for the first time for lunch with a friend. At first it looked super suspicious from the outside because all the curtains were down, and it looked like there was no one inside, but we went inside and the inside was actually quite pleasant. The inside was actually quite clean. There weren't many people, but I thought that with 400+ ratings on Yelp, I'm sure they got substantial business and I stayed.

I got the pho with rare beef and beef balls. It took a little longer than I expected for the food to arrive despite the very few customers, but they had a TV set up with a movie playing so it was okay. 

The pho was really good. I didn't have to add any hoisin sauce and sriracha to make it taste better (I usually like to add it in after having a bit of the normal broth). Both the noodles and beef were plenty, and for $7.95 , even the size of the bowl was bigger than what I would have expected. It was a small size bowl, but it looked like a large when it came out (I can only imagine what a large bowl would look like for a dollar more!) 

The staff were very nice and since there were few people around, they would ask how the food was and they were very polite and friendly. I'll be coming back when I want pho again!
author: Marjorie M.

description: Pho, pork spring rolls and chicken salad were all amazing! Price was right and packed even at 3:30 on a Sunday afternoon. Great find!
author: Kalie G.

description: This place has some really good noodle! The egg rolls are fresh (and mouth-burning hot)! My girlfriend said the shredded pork was below average but what can you expect when it is mixed together with a bunch of different things? Overall this place is great for dinner and I had a good experience!
author: Rob G.

description: Delicious soups - Pho Go and Mi Tuoi - fast delivery - Con Ga Ngu Vi was also surprisingly good as well. I will order from them again.
author: Andrrs B.

description:
This is my favorite place in all of SF for takeout Pho.

I say take out because I will never. ever. eat. inside.  When we drove past to pick up the Pho, we witnesses a very strung out woman, pull down her pants and proceed to defecate on the street between market and mission on 6th.  I kid you not.  

Also, it's right next door to the illustrious Henry Hotel with excellent security measures (aka two iron gates) for all it's quirky customers, whether hourly or until the crack runs out.  Oh and I saw a crack deal go down another time right outside.  The looksouts are starting to recognize us.

BUT I WILL STILL GIVE THIS PLACE 5 bloody stars...because it truly is the best Pho in all of SF.  The broth is phenomenal.  I don't have any idea what they put in it, but it's AMAZING.  It's so good that my BF who used to hate pho because he only experienced the lack luster faux phos...now asks to get it as take out every week.

Any food where I'm willing to risk getting mugged to attacked--is a place that deserves 5 stars.
author: Jae H.

description: The best Vietnamese restaurant in SF. Hands down. Staff, ambience, price, and food is incomparable.
author: Sandra O. N.

description: This place has been my go-to for years. It's delicious, it's in a neighborhood with easy parking, the prices are quite reasonable for a "nicer" Vietnamese (read: non-hole in the wall) place, and it's very consistent.
author: Sean B.

description:
Enthusiastic mediocrity.  I'm not sure those words belong together, but they somehow sum up how I feel about Miss Saigon.  I'm thrilled to have another Vietnamese food option -- and it's ostensibly cleaner than Tu Lan -- but I'm really not sure that the food measures up, and I can't for the life of me understand why they have so many TVs tuned into bootlegged, subtitled copies of blockbuster movies.

Why can't I find better?
author: Laurence W.

description:
Compared to the surrounding neighborhood a step inside to the Miss SaiGon restaurant is like stepping into paradise.  The restaurant is beautiful inside and as you sit down and take a look around you'll almost forget what part of town you're in.  I used to walk down Sixth Street from my job to get here, pass the crackheads, the filth, the attitude and the overbearing scents, but now I use Seventh Street and turn on Mission.  It sounds like an adventurous walk just to get here, but the food at Miss SaiGon has been excellent each time.

Yesterday I ordered the Cha Gio (crispy egg rolls) for the very first time and one of my favorite noodle dishes, Mi Xao Gion (crispy noodles with beef, chicken, shrimp and vegetables).  The restaurant is less busy around 2 PM, but patrons continue to trickle through the doors regularly.  The wait staff is friendly and attentive.  As soon as you are seated they bring you a slender glass of cucumber-infused ice water - so refreshing!  

The Cha Gio (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kPRMsrxQhRC4NMX8Mord_A?select=w-coy2RetlBdhOzFwjPqWQ) arrived at my table no more than three minutes after the waitress had taken my order.  Accompanied by fresh lettuce, a sprig of basil, cilantro, cucumber slices and a dipping sauce the two egg rolls appeared to be pretty plump.  Wow!  These are some of the best crispy egg rolls I've had in a very long time, and surprisingly not greasy.  The rolls are overstuffed with a seasoned pork mixture, vermicelli, carrots and mushrooms.  I ate everything on the plate but the basil.  I'll be ordering this again in the future.

The Mi Xao Gion (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kPRMsrxQhRC4NMX8Mord_A?select=P2AzEPfEq6IeLCVYgW3AoQ) is loaded with tender slices of beef and chunks of chicken breast.  There were maybe four small shrimp mixed in with the broccoli, zucchini, straw mushrooms, Shanghai bok choy, carrots and snow peas served with a light sauce over a massive bed of crispy, thin, fried noodles.  Again with this dish there was surprisingly very little grease on the bottom of the plate.  The ingredients work well together and it is a very satisfying noodle dish that will leave you stuffed.

I haven't tried the pho yet, but Miss SaiGon creates some excellent rice plates too.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: Could definitely have been better. But I guess not too bad overall. Veggie pho was a little skimpy with the tofu. However, not as bad as the veggie pho from Sunflower- Potrero Hill. Area is pretty sketchy. Not worth going out of your way for. Service was also a bit lacking. Didn't get a refill on water until the waiter came with the bill (and our glasses were empty for a long time!)
author: TZ J.

description: I'm really picky about my pho and I must say it was one of the best bowls I've had! (Other than my mothers, of course) I highly recommend this place! The service was a bit slow but it was pretty busy when I went.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Vegetarian noodle soup. They have it. It's pho-like. It's delicious. It's affordable. It's oddly rare in this city. 

Also oddly rare, and yet contained within Miss Saigon's four walls: a mannequin to greet you (I bumped into it and actually apologized before I realized what it was); bizarre karaoke videos (these change to bizarre christmas carol videos once it hits mid-November), and a menu that's as thick as some magazines. 

Cheap prices for dinner and lunch, and they accommodate large groups without much fuss. I like it.
author: Allison S.

description:
Breakups do funny things to people. And by funny, I mean kinda awesome, in a really f*cked up, I wasn't even looking for awesome, awesome kind of way. 

My best girlfriend got back from a recent trip to visit the man in another state and came back single. Me, being cut from the "if she doesn't cry and doesn't broach the subject everything must be fine" cloth, and her being from the "don't show my feelings and pretend everything is fine cloth", I figured we would go on as normal, pretending her four-year relationship hadn't just ended in the most mutual, heart crushing, we-really-love-each-other-but-neither-of-us-is-willing-to-leave-our-life kind of ways. 

But she cried. Yeah ... the bitch went out and cried in front of me. She didn't mean to. And it wasn't really her fault. I mean, we walked into a place where "I Remember You" by Skid Row was playing. I mean, who could blame the little thing for letting wet stuff come out of her eyes? But me, being cut from the aforementioned cloth, panicked. 

"LET ME BUY YOU DINNER!" I screamed. 

I looked at her wide-eyed, silently begging her to stop with the emotions. 

**sniffle** "What?" 

"LET ME BUY YOU FUCKING DINNER!" **chicken dance chicken dance**

"Why are you doing that weird walking thing?" **sniffle**

"I DON'T KNOW! YOU NEED FOOD! FOOD MAKES YOU HAPPY AND YOU DESERVE TO BE HAPPY AND I WANT TO BUY YOU HAPPY FOOD!" **triumphant fist pump, ballerina spin**

"Uhhhh ... .okay. I mean, that sounds nice". **wipes eyes**

Did it sound nice? In retrospect, probably not. Mostly because I had just proved myself to be the creepiest of friends by squawking like an eagle and chicken dancing to make her feel better about her life. 

I'm fucking amazing under pressure. 

Anyway, we decided to try Tu Lan on 6th, as it's our favorite terrifying Asain restaurant, and we were both feeling like shoving a whole bunch of marinated meat into our mouths. So we packed our travel mugs full of wine, grabbed our cigarettes and jumped on the 9 off Potrero, headed for the TL...

...Only to find Tu Lan was closed forever due to health violations, most notably the amount of "roaches, rodents, flies and 'other animals'" present at the famous hole-in-the-wall. 

I looked at my potential dinner date/hostage, "So ... I'm cool with the first three offenders. But what in the FUCK is the 'other animals' part? I'm not cool with that. Other animals could literally be anything. I mean, is it the effing rodents of unusual size from The Princess Bride? Is it gun-wielding raccoons? We're on 6th and Market, it could seriously be winged crackheads with machetes". 

She agreed, and we walked up to a restaurant I had heard about, but had never visited due to its proximity to Tu Lan (because who gets near Tu Lan and goes somewhere else?). Turns out, this place rocks. And it's CLEAN! Like, really, creepily clean. I even braved the bathroom, folks. For real. And it was fine. 

What we got: 

Spring Rolls - filled to the brim with shrimp and pork
Imperial Rolls - light and flaky and almost as good as Tu Lan's
Chicken in Yellow Curry - The winner of the evening; I added broccoli to mine
Beef with Basil and Ginger - Slightly sweet with a hint of spice; beef was excellent

NOTES: 

The food is all very good, and the ingredients are a step up from your normal, run-of-the-mill Vietnamese joint. But the portions are much smaller, which is to be expected, so prepare to order more than you're used to if you're looking for that family-style dinner. Also, many of the plates don't have veggies, so if you're a veggie-head like me, make sure to add some to your entree. The servers are a bit on the dick-ish side, but if you go often enough they'll eventually warm up a tiny bit, and by "tiny bit" I mean they might crack a smile.

And the best part? This is one of those rare Asian cuisine joints where you don't have to wonder whether or not your immune system is going to be working overtime defending your body from food-borne illness. You know, unlike Tu Lan.
author: Mel H.

description:
this is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  i always get the filet mignon pho #17B and it's SOO good.  The broth is always super hot and really flavorful.  The meat, looks like its been pounded to oblivion, but that just adds to its tenderness!  After you eat this, you won't want to go to back to the regular cardboard textured 'rare steak' :)  Something about this pho that just really hits the spot every time.

The owner is ALWAYS super nice and has a smile on his face.  The Bun Bo Hue is also really good!
author: Lucy K.

description:
Pretty impressed...best Vietnamese all around I've found in my hood.  Will definitely come back and try the other dishes.

-Pho with Filet Mignon was good
-Bun Bo Hue was great!
author: Alex T.

description: I have yet to find a favorite pho spot in San Francisco, but Miss SaiGon isn't a bad option. The chicken pho comes with a lot of noodles, and the broth has the right flavors. I was hoping for a little more chicken in the dish, just to add more protein as a whole. As usual, the MSG in the broth left me drinking water all night, but it was pretty good while eating it. Their spring rolls are also mediocre, with nothing really to set it apart from other spring rolls that I've had. Miss SaiGon would probably just be a go-to because of its proximity and lack of better options.
author: Ashley T.

description:
A pho joint in the city that can be considered cheap, feels authentic, is clean, and is centrally located in downtown with somewhat easy to find parking?  Normally I'd say "pho-getaboutit!" (actually I normally wouldn't), but this place surprisingly delivers.

Had a rice dish, a pho dish, and a spring roll dish here on separate occassions and each time it's made enough of an impression on me to want to come back for more.

I will say that the noodles in the pho did have a very beefy essence to them and that the broth is a smidge on the oily side the last time I went.  Might not be your thing, or it might be bonus flavor, you decide.

Banh mi here is a new thang apparently and they are $4 a hoagie.

Service is quick and friendly.

I did get tricked into thinking the spring rolls were $3.75 (they are actually bit above $4), but I'm going to chalk that up for reading too quickly in my excitement and head floating hunger.

Speaking of getting tricked, the manequin in the ao dai up front is NOT the hostess so don't make that mistake.
author: Dan P.

description:
Came in at 7pm for a party of 4. Wait took around 10-15 minutes. 

1. Told us they ran out of beef pho. It's dinner time. We are at a Vietnamese restaurant. Ridiculous. 

2. Half our party got their food 30 minutes after ordering. The rest of us got our food an hour after ordering. Oh and they didn't even bring us what we ordered - took even more time!

Food is overpriced and definitely not worth the  horrendous service.
author: Kat K.

description: I had a great steak lunch at Miss Saigon with some colleagues from work.  This is a nice place to eat with many unique dishes. My only issue is the creepy mannequin in the entranceway.  This place could probably do without it, haha.
author: Joshua S.

description: This place really sucks ass I ordered my food to eat 24 I arrived to the restaurant to come to find out that my order of the food was not even fired up little cooked the manager couldn't even explain to me why they did not have my order ready he was rude and nasty and I would never  go to the trashiest place again
author: Yondome C.

description: Place has good pho comparable to some spots in San Jose. I would recommend as the area isn't the greatest but food is good and restaurant is nice.
author: Darryl S.

description:
This place is aite.
Pros:
The food is not bad.
Clean
friendly service

Cons:
Small portions
a little bit more expensive
author: Eugene H.

description:
Went here based on reviews but was beyond disappointed.  The service was terrible the waiter was very rude. The door kept blowing open and it was freezing inside. 
The food was terrible. the pho was bland.  I got the filet pho and the meat had a terrible texture. If you want real pho and the best Vietnamese food in SF Ha Nam Ninh is it.
author: Jack M.

description: One of the best Bun's I've had in SF! So meaty, perfect noodle texture, perfect fish sauce. #32 all the way.
author: Jess C.

description:
I came here for dinner with a friend before seeing Interpol at the Warfield. It was pretty clean inside but a bit dim for my tastes. I ended up getting the garlic noodles with shaken beef. The beef was a bit chewy but the garlic noodles were pretty good. Service is nice - nothing to write home about, but they were attentive. My friend had pho (which he said was ok) and Thai iced tea (which he said was pretty yummy).

Overall, not a bad experience but I probably wouldn't come back here unless I happened to be in the area and was craving Vietnamese food.

Some interesting tidbits: they have a female mannequin at the entrance with a "Miss Saigon" sash and they also play odd music videos =P
author: Jennifer T.

description: Portions are reasonable if you get extra noodles.  Above average taste.  A bit pricier than average.  But seating is good usually.  (I would give 3.5 stars if I could)
author: Javier G.

description:
heck yes i'm a fan... i've been frequenting miss saigon almost every week for the past two months!! 

despite that it's located on 6th and mission, the place is always clean and i am always greeted with a smile! a real smile... not from miss saigon at the front door =P

my favorites are the pho with the filet mignon... it's good! the broth is good... the noodles are good... and the beef is minced when it's ordered! 

I also like their prawns with garlic noodle... noodles are super tasty and the prawns are huge! and I also like their #80... shrimp/prawns with special onion sauce... the prawns are battered in a light and sweet batter... it's awesome.  the onions they use are sweet and goes really well with the prawns! 

can't wait til next week!
author: Kelly H.

description: Surprisingly nice vietnamese restaurant on the corner of 6th and Mission. Food was good, and well staffed. No complaints here.
author: Y L.

description:
Probably one of the best places to get pho in the surrounding area. I prefer Miss Saigon to Tin as well as Turtle Tower.  The pho broth is delicious but not overly salty, the pho comes with all of the fixings... Jalapeños. Beans, Mint leaves, lemon, lime, and of course the sauces. 

The sandwiches are also phenomenal, I usually take one to go, and for the price you can't beat Miss Saigon.
author: David C.

description: Really thought the food was outstanding here. The claypot catfish was a standout. And, then I absolutely loved the chicken with coconut and turmeric. WOW! We loved it. Also a fan of the Miss Saigon mannequin in front.
author: Andrew K.

description: Miss Saigon is in a bit of a sketchy neighborhood, but the food was tasty and the portions were biggish.  We ordered the spring rolls, deep fried rolls, filet mignon steak with garlic noodles, some other beef and rice dish, and pork chops.  The rolls came in twos, but they offered us a third roll for $1.75 or so more.  Overall, we were very satisfied with our dishes, particularly the deep fried rolls and filet mignon dish.
author: Kristen H.

description:
I'm Vietnamese and I like Viet restaurants that have a menu that goes beyond Pho and spring rolls. This is exactly why I like Miss Saigon. They have all the dishes I miss from home and for the most part, everything is pretty tasty. The only thing I advise not getting is the Bun Bo Hue. I feel like it's a bit bland and lacking the different meats (and yes, blood cubes) that they usually put into it.

My favorite dish from there is their hu tieu. The broth is amazing and it has a good amount of shrimp and meat in it. Their won ton soup is also a favorite. It's made Vietnamese style and so it has a unique twist from the traditional Chinese style.
author: Amy N.

description: Finally writing the long-overdue review after my third time there. Echoing Dai N., #17b Filet Mignon Pho...WORD. Service is fast and courteous. Will keep going back and will keep getting #17b. It's all I need there.
author: Scott C.

description:
Great service, very nice staff.  Had a great conversation about our trip to San Fran.  The location was fine to me, though some might think it is a little sketchy.  It depends on where you are from and what you are used to.  It is not in a tourist area and located a few blocks outside of Union Square.  

This review is based solely on my love of Pho!  I am a Pho junkie, meaning I have had lots of it at many different locations.  This is my first review on Yelp, so I'm excited!  I had 17b, which is the Pho Tai Mem (Rice noodle with filet mignon rare beef.  The large bowl was $11.00 dollars, which to me is just fine for a great bowl of Pho.  The filet mignon was perfect!  Not too chewy with absolutely great flavor!  They utilized quality meat with great flavor.  The rice noodles were perfectly done.  I have to say that this is where many places go wrong; however Miss Saigon does it right!  The broth was the the best I have ever tasted, hands down.  The temperature was perfect and you can tell they know what they are doing because the taste was a perfect blend of Pho spices with the right bones for flavor.  The bowl of Pho comes with all of the fixings and a small plate of Sriracha and Hoisin sauce which is paired together, not mixed though.  

if you are into Pho, and in San Francisco you have to try this place!  You can't go wrong!
author: Chris A.

description: We ordered the green papaya salad with dried beef topping, Bun (vermicelli bowl) with BBQ pork and the Pho.  Everything was authentic and good.  Prices are low.  It's a rough neighborhood.   Didn't seem Americanized.  Though the hot/spicy peppers were sparse in the salad.   I ordered this dish in Vietnam and it was very spicy.
author: Jason G.

description:
I can't speak to anything else but the Pho.

IT'S SUPER DELICIOUS! Best Pho place I've tried in the Bay Area so far. I'm a huge Pho fan and truly miss the authentic stuff from Vietnam. But Miss SaiGon's pho takes me back like no other Pho served in the Bay Area can.

YUM! :)
author: Lucy C.

description:
I love the food from restaurant. 
There are thousand of Vietnamese restaurant in SF, however it is too difficult to get any good one for the person who came from the North of Vietnam.
author: Dranai N.

description:
I love pho.  Who doesn't?

So I went here with the recommendation of a coworker.  And I of course ordered some pho.  The waiter tried to upsell me on the pho to the filet mignon pho, and I decided to go for it.  BEST DECISION EVER!!  You know how great filet mignon is, right?  Now just imagine that tender cut of beef in your pho.  It was amazing!!!
author: Rick D.

description:
Good food
Not crowded
Really cheesy music
Always plays strange things on TV
Flawless service
I like
author: C J.

description:
This is quickly becoming my go-to place for pho. Their broth is good here, and they have a decent selection of meat. My only qualm is that they don't serve tripe with their pho dac biet! I love tripe, and I grew up eating tripe in pho; not to have tripe seems unreasonable. But the broth is so good, I won't dock any stars. Their papaya salad is also worth getting. I also ordered a honeydew boba because I had a craving, and they made it with real honeydew, not the powder stuff you get at most boba places. Boba itself is alright, but the honeydew was really tasty. 

So the location isn't the best, but the pho is worth braving the mean street of 6th. It sure beats Tin on Howard!
author: Angeline P.

description: This is the best Vietnamese in SF by far.  I've been here dozens of times and never had anything remotely close to a bad experience.   Live around the corner and this is our go to place.  Pho is amazing, large portion, and high quality. Also, everything on the menu is incredible, tried literally 80% of the menu and never been let down.  Particularly love the hot pot.   Warm and friendly vibe here with the staff always trying to do whatever they can to make you feel at home.   Highly highly recommend!!!!
author: Matt B.

description:
Got the shaken beef with garlic noodles. The beef was so tender! like a filet mignon. I really liked the lime salt that you dip it into.

We also got sesame noodles, that was pretty good too.
author: Lilian K.

description: Actually tasted great to be honest and service was quick and prompt. But the msg overload nearly killed me when I got home! Im sensitive to msg so I can tell when a place puts way too much. Dizziness and nausea, passed out on the sofa for like over an hr lol. Lastly the neighbourhood is pretty damn sketch.... So.... Two stars.
author: Samson T.

description: Decent pho tai, friendly service, clean restaurant. Definitely one of the better Vietnamese restaurants in SanFran.
author: DV P.

description: Who would have known that this gem of a restaurant was on 6th street.  I typically avoid 6th street like the plague, but if you walk on Mission St to get here you can sneak around most of the street activity and duck into this calming environment for some great food, as well as friendly service.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I've had Bun Bo Hue here twice. It's not the most authentic, lacking the pork blood and pig's feet that you expect from the real deal, but the flavor was very nice. I had to request mam tom to boost the Vietnamese Quotient of the broth to my liking, but once I did I was very satisfied. My boys shared pho and it was fine, but not special. They ate the whole bowl.
author: Cory K.

description:
No need for a long review. 

We love this place...after a long day and with no motivation to cook for ourselves and are craving  a delicious bowl of Pho, we order pick-up and head around the corner.

The green papaya salads are delicious as well.

if this is spot is close to your apt, make the trip.
author: Daniel D.

description: In town for Night Club Monthly and didn't want Subway, which was across from my hotel (I can get this is my town) so I took a chance to find something else after stepping over several homeless persons and dodging street construction I found Miss Saigon. The place looked clean and welcoming as I poked my head in. The place was near empty 'cept for a cute couple sitting near the door. (it was 3pm)  I sat down and ordered my Vietnamees standard meal B'un (rice noddles/salad) with grilled pork and egg roll also I tried the Crispy Squid. The B'un was better than most large egg roll and Pork was of 2 types a patty and strips it was delicious. to my surprise the Squid was the stand-out OMG it was crispy not chewy and was dressed with Grilled Green onions white onions and crispy diced Garlic nuggets OMG sooo good.  I now have a fav Viet place in SF cool!
author: Phillip G.

description: The food was good, but it didn't knock my socks off. There are better Vietnamese restaurants in the area. I'd give this one a pass.
author: Frank A.

description:
I enjoyed meal no. 48. Chicken, rice and some vegetables. The rice was cooked to perfection. The chicken was so tender and fresh. and of course the vegetables too.

The location of the restaurant is not really great. Too many crackheads/homeless right outside the restaurant's door but let me tell you once you are inside, everything is different. Clean and cool place from inside. The waiters were all greeting you with smile. I arrived at 12:05 pm and within 10 minutes all tables were packed with people.

I can't seem to think of anything negative about this place but the awesome and the extremely delicious Vietnamese meal I had. Will I come back again? Hell yeah!!
author: Joe K.

description: Decent pho. The broth is crazy hot here though. Wish it could be toned down just a little. The service is prompt and friendly.
author: Grace H.

description: Ordered the Bun Bo Hue and pork rice plate. The soup is good - pretty authentic with lots of meat. The rice is bad - egg cake was hard as a rock and the pork was dry. Kinda pricey, too.
author: Julie L.

description:
I'm wondering if I just might be too white to eat at Miss Saigon? I stopped in here for a quick and easy dinner with Colleen C and ordered Bun bo Hue which is described as "spicy beef and pork." I might be a rookie, but usually when things are described as spicy at a Vietnamese restaurant they aren't kidding around. And I even said I would like it spicy. Alas, this was not the case. My soup was like the antithesis of spicy and that was sad.

However, I think our server noticed my frowny face because he asked if it was spicy enough for me, and when I said no he immediately brought me an assortment of goodies to throw in the bowl to up the spice ante. So, I did just that and was well pleased afterward.

It's a pretty basic space, clean, bright, and quiet. And the prices seem really reasonable for the giant servings you get. Plus the staff is uber nice.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Went out to lunch with the new work fam and apparently Miss Saigon is the group lunch spot as I've heard everyone talk about it.  I was excited as it was my first time and finally was able to see what the hype was all about, especially to see, "Miss Saigon" myself, which apparently was an inside joke, but she was right there at the front door to greet us as we walked in!

Looking through their menu, they had a lot of tempting items, including Pho, noodle soups, rice plates, a la carte items and OMG, Garlic Noodles!  My coworkers were raving about the Garlic Noodles so, that's what I ordered, the #57, Garlic Noodles with Filet Mignon.  We ordered quite a few appetizers, the Spring Rolls were great, the Fried Calamari was even better, actually, I liked it a lot, the Cream Cheese Wontons were pretty good; and the Papaya Salad, which I just had a little of was quite refreshing and I liked the bits of pork.  I ordered a Thai Iced Tea which was served in a tall, and I mean, tall glass but with a short bendy straw.  Trust me, size didn't matter, I made sure to suck every drop of that delicious beverage!  Whoa, did it just get hot in here or is it just me? :)

Our food came out pretty fast and when my plate was served, my face lit up as it my food looked and smelled so delicious!  I had quite a generous portion of Filet Mignon pieces that were cooked perfectly.  The Garlic Noodle, which was accompanied by a condiment bowl of seasoning and a lime, both which I spread all over.  Not sure what that seasoning was but it was so tasty!  I liked the Garlic Noodle very much, not quite the best I've had but for the price, it was amazing!

The staff was very friendly and efficient, which is always a joy.   I think Miss Saigon is going to be one of my solo lunch spots I'll hit up during the work week, but per the work fam, we'll make it out here quite frequently.  Check out Miss Saigon if you're in the neighborhood and craving some legit Vietnamese fare!

Side note:  I just noticed, on Yelp, the restaurant is listed as, "Miss SaiGon"...notice the letters in caps spell out, "MSG."  So was THAT in my bowl of seasoning? :)
author: Nick D.

description: Great Pho. One of the best in SF. But, It's not the best in SF and it's in the middle in Bay Area. The location isn't great but close to Union Square.
author: Ryosuke K.

description:
As two small Asian girls wanting to satiate our Vietnamese dinner cravings without having to wander into the Tenderlion, we google mapped it, which sent us down Minna St. Not a good idea!!! WAY scarier than the Tenderlion! Only come here at night with security sized dining companions.

In lieu of a hostess, they have "Miss SaiGon" the mannequin, which explains why nobody came to check us in for a good 30 seconds. While it seems ghetto that the menus are those old photo albums with the peel away plastic, I love that there were photos of every dish and numbered for the Vietnamese illiterate like us. And here's something quirky but sweet about how the stuff dried leaves in the menu. 

The service is fine. The decor is fine. It's clean, who cares about the freaking mannequin. $10-15/ person for dinner in SOMA? Not too shabby.

The food is tasty. The most flavorful and packed spring roll, light and generously portioned curry tofu, and perfectly seasoned and proportioned bun with pork. And the leftovers tasted just as good the next day.

Kind of worth risking life and limb for?
author: Snuffles B.

description: I've been wanting to try the pho for a few years now and yes, I came when the health score was low. What can I say, I'm daring. Came around 4pm and no one was in the restaurant, order the small 17b, which is pho with rare filet mignon, I asked for no onions, pho came out right away and the filet mignon wasn't rare which is great for me since I can't stand rare meat and I have to always let me pho sit for awhile. I also prefer the flat noodle but they only offer the rice noodle, shoot let's give it a whirl. I can say that the rice noodle was cooked nicely in this tasty broth and pho came out extra hot which instantly cooked my basil. It's Southern style pho and I was in pure bliss. And for everyone leaving remarks about coming to the TL, this isn't in the TL (Tenderloin) this is SOMA or as us people from SF like to use the OG name, South Of Market, 6th street wasn't even walkable in the day time 10 years ago. Suck it up and get some grit in your suburban self.
author: Sarah T.

description: Large selection of Pho and other Vietnamese food.  Overall good but the beef and pork were chewy.  Service was good too.
author: Dan K.

description: Above average Vietnamese food with OUTSTANDING service. They accidentally messed up my order, immediately fixed it AND gave me the filet mignon upgrade for free.
author: leland k.

description: I thought it was way good....imperial rolls and filet rare pho
author: Scott D.

description: This was hands down the most flavorful pho I've had in the city!!! Simply fresh and delicious.
author: Diana A.

description:
I went in.  The place was all but empty.  The server quickly came over.  I checked out the menu and decided to go with the Bun Bo Hue.

This is a style of soup that is not as popular here as pho.  It uses vermicelli noodles instead of rice noodle.  BTW - Hue is a city in Vietnam.   The soup was amazing.  It had a nice kick and I boosted it up some with added sriracha sauce.  It was such a fresh soup.  Lots of goodies to go along with the beef and noodle.

http://tinyurl.com/3k5o555

The server checked a number of times to insure everything was going well.  

The ambiance is plain and straightforward.

It is a shame this place was empty at prime dinner hour.  I will definitely return.
author: Mark D.

description: Truly an awesome place for Vietnamese food. My favorite is the Bun Bo Hue Heo Gio or #27b and #47 grilled pork with broken rice. This was one of those places I use to pass by on my way to go get some Medicine in the SOMA area. I glad I came in. I was eating here at once a week when I was working in the Financial district a month ago. I wish I could share my picture of my food on this page.
author: Joe H.

description: My favorite Vietnamese place in the city. My co-workers usually go for the beef pho (17 or 17b), but the noodle dishes have also been great in my experience.  I usually get beef with venrmicelli (36b); this place offers my favorite take on this dish in the city. Interestingly, I can't quite tell the difference between the variants #36 and #36b from the menu description, but one time they gave me the former by mistake, and it tasted completely different -- kind of like soggy Pad Thai. So make sure you get #36b. If you want to spend a little more, you can add fried egg rolls to the dish, which compliment it well.
author: Alex L.

description: The food was tasty, but the service was inexcusable. We waited 40 min for our order (two pho noodle soups), asked three times for the status of our food until we finally realized they forgot our order. Had to ask them twice to bus the table and twice to get our check. I would not come back.
author: Liz W.

description:
Awful experience from start to finish. 

My boyfriend and I walked in around 6:45 PM on Thursday night. He's recovering from a broken ankle and he was using a cane - clearly injured. There were two people working, a man and a lady, and the lady kind of ushered us in and gestured at all the empty tables - there were at least 15 open, towards the back of the restaurant. We made it halfway down the length of the restaurant - mind you, boyfriend limping and using cane - when the man rushed up and asked us to turn around, back up and sit at the table in the corner right next to the entrance, with a mannequin hovering over it. Like we had to move the table so that the mannequin's hand wasn't in between our faces. And the restaurant was empty, yet we were sitting at the table by the entrance, and every time somebody came in we got blasted with cold air and wind. The table by the entrance should only be taken as a last resort when the rest of the tables are full. 

My boyfriend ordered a Saigon beer and instead was brought an Export 33, which the guy argued had become the same company as Saigon or something. OK, fine. No big deal - even though you list them separately on your menu.. 

The lady was very pushy. We weren't ready to order and she kept coming back to prod us and ask us to order. She also insisted I say the number of the dish. The conversation went something like this: 
-"Can we have the summer rolls?" 
-"Yes, number two right?" 
"Yes, the summer rolls with pork." 
"NUMBER TWO RIGHT?"
 "Um.. *flips menu back open to check on the number*" 
"IT'S NUMBER TWO. YOU WANT NUMBER TWO RIGHT?" 
"OKAY YES. NUMBER TWO. THANK YOU."

We got the summer rolls. They were incredibly disgusting. We both took one bite and had to stop. The sauce had no flavor, but the worst part was the meat inside. It was supposed to be shredded pork. My boyfriend asked me "What is this supposed to be?" He said it reminded him of dog food crumbles (we were both a little grumpy at this point).

Our soup came. Boyfriend had pork wontons in his soup. Same problem with the awful "shredded pork". Mine was a traditional beef pho soup. The beef was old, dry, tasteless, and sometimes tasted just plain bad. I fished it all out of my soup and left it on a side plate. Couldn't eat it. The broth itself was good, so I slurped on that. Basically paid $9.50 for rice noodle soup with sprouts. 

After we'd finished, we sat for a really long time and never got the check. Finally I waved them down for the check. They brought it to us. My boyfriend put his card down. We sat for 10 minutes. They walked by our table a few times but didn't pick up the card. Finally he got up, with his cane, limped over to the counter, handed them the receipt, stood there while they ran the card, then limped back. 

Unbelievable. If you want Viet food in the area go to Tin's Vietnamese instead. I will never come back here.

EDIT: BF woke up at 3:30 am with stabbing pains in his stomach. They're still not gone 6 hours later.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Bumping my review to 5 stars.

This has become my favorite spot over the years. Really nothing to say other than I love it, including the weird shit they play on the TV and the strange female mannequin at the door.
author: Cheri R.

description:
The place doesn't really need the bump, but since I eat here regularly, I wanted to give it the props it deserves.  The food here is genuinely good.  It is a little more expensive than other Vietnamese places (which is to say, it's still cheap compared with most other cuisines.  $8.25 for your typically large bowl of combination pho.)  But their broth is really good - it has that good, rich, umami flavor, that fundamental goodness that you recognize right away, with just a little bit of sweetness.  

Their pork vermicelli is really good too.  Thin slices of pork, highly seasoned and tender.  The fish sauce is properly balanced - just the right mix of salty and sweet.  

Also a fan of their shaken beef w/ garlic noodles.  Again, a little more than you'd expect to pay at a Vietnamese place ($14.95 according to their online menu, I somehow remember it as cheaper though...) but compare it to $22 at R&G $36 at Slanted Door.  Oh yes, don't mind if I do order one to go...

The cross street is seedy.  It's opposite a couple porn stores.  There's a reason why the curtains are always drawn and you kind of need to peer in to double check that they're open.  The interior is pleasant and simple.  I personally think the photos on Yelp makes it look fancier than my impression of the place, but the bias could be on my end (plus, who wants fancy here?).  Not a place to take a date you want to impress (unless being the stalwart guide between the crowds of homeless people is liable to impress them).  But a good place to visit with your SO when you want some yummy, honest chow.
author: Monica L.

description: If you wanna find some place to enjoy "Pho", Miss Saigon Res can be my recommendation in this city. They serve you with the nice service. The broth of Pho is so good, and look the same taste in my Vietnam country. I strongly recommend you guys come here to try Pho. And I will be back for sure.
author: Liam T.

description:
Found the mannequin (wearing traditional Vietnamese couture) greeting guests, a little creepy. The only thing that would add to the creep factor would  to have a motion sensor and have the plastic lady say "welcome to Miss Saigon" when you walk in.  Didn't see too many  Vietnamese dining here at lunch time. Thought the TV's w/ the cartoon video loop, in keeping with the strangeness of the mannequin greeter.
Kinda like Miss Saigon meets Disneyland, thought that was funny since there were no kids present in the restaurant.  Probably no kids since the neighborhood is scary.

Food was just OK. (will say they have a large/varied menu)

Our table had goi cuon (over-stuffed with Bun'), spring roll (kinda more like a Chinese egg roll).... pretty good, not great. Sauces on the mark.  3 people at our table, took a couple of minutes to explain we wanted 3 rolls of each (the orders come w/ 2) and for that extra roll with a price more than it should be. The lunch special beef/lemon grass was tasty. Hu tieu Nam Vang was good.  

$55 for lunch for 3.   A tiny pot of tea for the table was $2. while not a cheapster, it seemed not appropriate. Overall price was higher than it should be. 

Yup,  it is a clean restaurant. Service was good. Since I don't dwell on 6th Street, no reason to go back.
author: Matsuo U.

description: The filet mignon pho (17b) was dank! Although we waited a while to get menus, the pho was yummmmy. Fairly priced for the city.
author: Anu C.

description: They have good service but everything is overly sweet  and lacking in any flavor. My noodles were overcooked.
author: Ellen F.

description: So good! I ordered the number 32 for dinner and finished the whole bowl. I thought I broke my stomach that day because I was so full. I wasn't even hungry until lunch the next day.
author: Theresa D.

description: Was there to try the pho. The atmosphere is really friendly and so are the waiters. The pho was delicious too and very affordable! I'm definitely coming back when I'm in San Francisco
author: Tschen Min W.

description: definitely my go-to place! I've never had a bad experience with this restaurant. The food is great and inexpensive, while the staff is incredibly friendly.
author: Pat C.

description:
Came here since my friend recommended that I give it a try.

I probably won't come here at night alone just because of it's location, walking there I just felt my blood pressure rise a little since I had to be on guard the entire time. haha. Walked past it a few times since they don't have a huge banner, but its right on the corner of Mission St basically. Once you get inside, you forget about the location though.

So I tried the bun bo hue. It's awesome that they don't mix up the chili sauce right away (since I sweat VERY easily) so I was able to scoop out some of the sauce so it wouldn't be as spicy. Granted, I was still sweating... but not as bad at least! But the bun bo hue here is SOOOO GOOOOOD. Definitely one of the best in the city in my opinion... I've tried a lot of places in SF and it's usually lacking in the lemon grass flavor or sometimes it's just not good. I usually have to drive to SJ just for a good fix. But now I don't have to since I've tried this place! Not sure how their other stuff taste, but I'm sure that it's just as good. Will definitely come back to eat here again!
author: Johnson S.

description: I was unimpressed.  The pork roll was awesome, but at $2 each eggroll, too much!  I also had a bahn mi. At $4.50 it was dry, and weak. Worst bahn mi I've had  in the city.  There was not enough of anything but bread.
author: nick p.

description: great pho but it took forever to get the order. Next time I will order ahead of time.
author: Amna I.

description:
Not much else to say about this place that hasn't been said already.

My favorite dishes are lemongrass pork with rice, pepper soy sauce beef, and cube steak.
author: Yonder B.

description:
This is my go-to Vietnamese place! I'm Vietnamese and I have to say that this place is AUTHENTIC! 

I go here all the time. Service is friendly and prompt. The staff there is so nice. Oh, and did I mention that the food is DELICIOUS? Everything I've tried there has tasted fresh, delicious, and authentic. The menu is very extensive as well - huge plus! 

Plus, the prices are affordable and the ambiance/decor is nice, especially compared to most Vietnamese places in the city. 

The only things I don't like about the decor is the creepy mannequin stationed at the front door and the weird things they sometimes play on the TV. Everything else is nice though :)

Also, I was able to easily make a reservation for a group of 11 of my friends on the 21st of this month - a night when most other restaurants are already booked up or are not interested in taking a group of this size. So great!

I have dinner here any chance I get :) I leave feeling happy that I just enjoyed a very affordable, healthy, yummy meal.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for dinner with friends or for just a regular weekday quick and casual dinner. Go go go!
author: Amy D.

description:
The pho here is awesome, if you can stand the long wait for a table at lunchtime. It's a small place, on a bustling SF corner, and is quite the interesting location for people watching

Service was slow and cursory at best... and every time I see that Miss Saigon mannequin, I think it's a person! Creepy
author: Steve K.

description:
Pretty good for vegetarians (for vietnamese food at least), good prices, and huge portions.

I've gotten the braised tofu in coconut curry twice now and love it.  It's the kind of yummy meal that stays with you all day.

For some reason they're always showing kids movies involving animals (Madagascar, Ice Age).

Watch out for the squail! (read the menu carefully for teh funny)
author: Jon M.

description: Pretty good lunch spot, right down the street from Tú Lan (i.e., a solid plan B.) I had the 5 Spice Chicken Banh mi - it was good, but not great. Would definitely try this place again.
author: Jesse F.

description:
Had a grubwithus meal here (which was an awesome experience) so they served up a pre-fixed menu family style for our party. They served me some vegetarian alternatives which included spring rolls, some fake chicken/veggie dish, and a coconut milk dessert with mango. 

Automatic +1 when places have fake meat. I know some of you are against the idea, but a girl needs to get her protein! Why not just eat the real thing you ask? Well, not that I'm a die hard PETA enthusiast but I like the idea of saving some animals from cruel conditions and it's also a little hard to stomach eating meat after being veg my whole life. I know, I know, I'm missing out on some good stuff apparently. Maybe one day.

Back to Miss SaiGon though, the manager was awesome as well and kept checking on me to see if I needed more food (it's as though he was ready to add another dish if I was still hungry at no cost!). Minus one star for location. That was not the friendliest walk at 7:30pm and I definitely cabbed afterwards as walking there around 10pm is just not a good idea.
author: Raina B.

description: Can't believe I never reviewed Miss Saigon....used to be a weekly staple.  The shaken beef was always very good, the service standard for a Vietnamese place and it's on a sketchy block, but there's usually plenty of parking. And if you want to buy rock after dinner +1!
author: Nobody M.

description:
Sorry guys, cannot recommend. Appreciate the vegetarian options and maybe I should have gone with veggie pho, as recommended by other folks, but wanted more protein, so went with vegan chicken and mixed vegetables. Very much a miss: parts of the veggies were kind of cold, so obviously reheated and the "vegan chicken" was super greasy, almost inedible and the few bites I ate made me feel queasy afterwards. Also a very strong, odd smell in the place immediately when we walked in, I should have walked right back out in retrospect.

Service generally nice, although occasionally difficult to understand.
author: Ara S.

description:
Very good pho place. I usually go to Tin, but I figured I could try this place out. First of all...take 7th street to get there if you are walking because 6th street is really dangerous. 

My boyfriend and I ordered the fresh spring rolls and a combo pho and a rare beef pho. The spring rolls were huge! They were delicious and the peanut sauce that came with them was amazing. 

We both got large phos and next time I want to get a small....the portions are HUGE! The broth was amaaazing. I'm used to a bit more clear broth. This broth was a bit creamier looking and had a more complex flavor....really good. The noodles were the same as all of the other pho places I've tried. My only complaint was that my rare beef pieces are a bit thicker than other places...I love it when its nice and thin. It was a bit harder to eat when it was thicker...but there was a ton of meat which was great.

The service was great. Our waiter was really hard to understand because he mumbled a lot, but he was very very nice and attentive. The decor is really nice...very 90s...but very clean and welcoming.

Overall, great pho place. I think Tin and Miss Saigon are tied in my book. Tin gets points for having a bit more modern decor. The menu is super cute. It's basically a handmade scrap book with pictures and descriptions. It must have taken someone a ton of hours to make all of those menus by hand. Dedication! 

They also serve beer and wine I saw, we didn't try any though.
author: Juliet S.

description: Best pho I have ever had. The broth was outstanding, and every pho broth I've had since pales in comparison and makes me sad. The spring rolls were just right, too.
author: Lily T.

description: Ordered food online, called 2 hours later to find out where my food is only to find out they had not even made it. Avoid this place like the plague.
author: Justin S.

description: Amazing... Prob best pho I've ever had.. And I live in NY. The beef was good quality, soup tasted good, and the noodles were perfect.
author: Strwberi N.

description:
Great little hole in the wall -- unfortunately, in the dodgiest part of SoMa (and since we live at 6th/Harrison, we have to walk through all the sketchiness to get there.) Try the beef papaya salad for an appetizer. You can get the pho any way you want it, as they do ingredient substitutions freely - I got pho with brisket and steak which is not on their normal menu. Their bun bo hue is also good considering it's very hard to find elsewhere (though I haven't tried Bun Bo Hue An Nam in East SJ, which I've heard is the definitive BBH. So, grain of salt.)

Staff is courteous and eager to please, no complaints there. We enjoyed watching Vietnamese karaoke videos on the TVs mounted to the wall while we were there, and afterwards it actually switched to 80s music videos, which was a blast from the past. Somehow I thought that Miss Saigon was too cool for that sort of thing, but I'm glad it isn't. :)
author: Josh K.

description:
Another great Vietnamese restaurant in the SOMA area.

Since it's right across the street from Tu Lan, I'll do a little compare and contrast.

Veggie pho at Miss SaiGon - also delicious, flavorful, and fresh.  Perhaps slightly better than Tu Lan.  Lots of bok choi, tons of delicious noodles, and came with the basil and lime that I'm used to.  Also - enough for leftovers.  It was $6.95, whereas Tu Lan's veggie pho is $6.25. 

Atmosphere here is brighter and feels cleaner.  Tall ceilings, lots of windows, random dummy mannequin in the entrance.  Go to Tu Lan if you're feeling seedy and are craving something divey, and don't want to run into anyone you know.  Miss SaiGon is more SOMA, whereas Tu Lan is more 'loin.  

We got lucky and didn't have a wait (arrived around 12:15), but if the likelihood is that you WILL have a wait, as the place filled up pretty quickly.  So far, I've never waited at Tu Lan for a table.

Overall...Miss SaiGon has the edge.  If I were allowed to give half stars, I'd give Miss Saigon 4.5 stars, while Tu Lan is a 4.  Both fantastic places!
author: Ashley M.

description:
What is it about their pork fried egg rolls that I find so addicting and delicious?  After calling in an order, then picking it up to take back to work...i found that they were STILL CRISPY after riding in my car in a closed take out container, wth?  Why can't the lumpia that i make on my own ever come out that crispy?  Someone from Miss SaiGon...teach me!

Crab Rangoons, they are worth the buy too...yum :)
author: Emy B.

description:
Miss SaiGon how I adore you. After visiting Walmart a few times you become very familiar with "The Greeter" or a person who gets paid to say hi. Miss SaiGon operates at maximum efficiency by having a strategically placed mannequin guide you into her palace, free of charge.

The oddly comforting confusion of where you want me to sit when I come inside has remained consistent, thanks for adding suspense to my lunch. I generally order the same item every time from your picture book of a menu. Nothing screams a great user experience like pictures next to items you know I'm going to miss pronounce anyways, instead, I get to kick back and confidently point at the dish and say "I'll take the #33".

The #33 is a majestic dish of what appear to be pork rolls cut into pieces on top of a delicate bed of rice noodles. I recommend ordering hot tea and pouring some of the tea in this noodle bowl.

Have you ever sat at lunch wondering, "Man, I sure wish there was some footage of owls tearing apart the inside of spiders on TV". Wonder no more. Miss SaiGon has some of the most intense national geographic footage I have ever seen, and I love every minute of it.

It is my duty to you Miss SaiGon, to create a time machine and invite you to my junior high prom because you make me happy. Thanks for serving deliciously affordable lunchtime delights.
author: Jason M.

description:
The service was mediocre. Even though it was a quiet weeknight it took the servers at least 15 minutes after seating us down to come bring us the menus and ask for our drinks. Our water glasses were never refilled. The waiters seemed to be hiding in the back somewhere and were never around when we needed something. One of the waiters completely ignored our request for the bill so that, after getting tired of waiting, we had to ask someone else to bring our bill.

Now on to the food. I fail to see what all the fuss is about. I can't say the food tasted bad but it was nothing special, nothing that would make me go back again. It is true that we didn't order the famous Pho, so my opinion of the food is purely based on their fried rice and the pineapple chicken.
author: Stef L.

description:
I was in dire need of a bowl of pho and ended up here after getting turned away at another Vietnamese place nearby that had a long line.

The pho was good (I had #17) and the iced jasmine tea really hit the spot on a warm day.  Given I went in the midst of the lunch rush, I was pleasantly surprised by the friendly (and speedy) service.

I definitely plan to go again.
author: Phil S.

description:
I went to this place about 4 times. The service was always good and the food GREAT.
Water service is pretty good. Me and friends always had a lot of fun there, and my last dinner in San Francisco was there, and i was not disappointed. I was even more surprised with all the upgrades they made.

I strongly recommend this restaurant.
author: Danielle S.

description: I ducked into Miss SaiGon to avoid the disaster ensuing in Soma and decided to eat lunch. The food wasn't very memorable. I believe I ordered the Com Ga Ngu Vi and thought it was just OK. The food wasn't terribly spicy but they did provide a chili sauce to help out a bit. Reasonably priced. Probably won't be in this neck of the woods and I don't see any reason to make the special trek for this restaurant.
author: Tommy C.

description: Being of discerning taste for bun bo hue due to the expert craftsmanship of my mother's home cooking, I have to say that many bun bo hue joints in the city hardly compare to miss Saigon. very authentic with a fragrant and flavorful broth. You have to have the pungent fish paste to make it authentic! Really great: my go to in the city.
author: Dzu N.

description: Oh my word, had the pork with rice (can't remember the native name), it was amazing  also had the Thai tea , loved it
author: Kwendo J.

description:
I have to say I'm not a pho expert, but man this place makes it good!!! 

I live near by and this is definitely one of my favorite spots for confort food! My favorite dish is the number 31, the vermicelli with grilled pork and vegetables, their sauce is the best! (sorry I can't remember or spell vietnamese dish names =P)  

I have to say, me and my boyfriend have been looking for other places to go, and try different options for vietnamese food, but we keep coming back because we can't find anything better, for our taste of course. Seriously. And every time we decide to try something new from their menu, we love it. We didn't try everything but I can't remember eating anything that I didn't like.

And I can't give my opinion about the staff, who was very nice since the first time we have been there, because as we keep coming back, they already know us and give us amazing service with a lot of smiles and friendly chatting!! 

Yeah... I know... I really love this place! #Number31Forever
author: Carla O.

description:
I'm a little curious how this restaurant manages to maintain a 4 star rating. The law of averages dictates that some Yelpers are handing out 5 stars, which is not deserving of this place. The food is not completely dreadful, just not overwhelming. 

After maneuvering around all the drug dealers and vagrants down 6th Street, stopping only to talk to some pimps (you gotta stay up to date on the ho network; it's hard out there for a pimp) Miss Saigon appears on the corner of 6th and Mission. From the outside, it looks a little 'divey'. The interior is pretty nice although you are greeted by a mannequin (Miss Saigon, I presume) dressed in traditional Vietnamese garb (kinda freaky, maybe the mannequin is the restaurant's enforcer - this ho got this corner) 

From here is a slight downhill, between three friends, we ordered the pho ga, vermicelli bowl, seafood clay pot rice, bun rieu. I had a quick spoon of the pho broth and bun rieu and was already disappointed. Not authentic and lacking real Vietnamese flavor. My friends didn't seem to notice and were content with their soups. The vermicelli bowl is spot on; it's kinda hard to screw that up unless you undercook the noodles. The seafood clay pot rice was my dish and for the most part was pretty good. Rice was certainly crunchy from the clay pot and the amount of protein was good. My problems are the crab meat used was imitation crab and the dish was rather pricey. Considering everyone's dish was under $10, the seafood clay pot rice was $15. I was hoping that paying the premium price meant having fresh seafood. If the dish was $8, I wouldn't complain, but charging $15 is a bit much for fake crab. 

All in all, not a terrible experience, but nothing to write home about either. Time to head up the Mission and set up appointments with Pimp Daddy Kane.

p.s. we paid cash for our bill, but noticed the waiter telling others that their Point Of Sale system was down and not taking credit cards. Other Yelpers have griped in the past about the same thing. I wonder if their POS system is a real POS or that's the restaurant's way of getting cash (aka creative accounting)  =)
author: Mike L.

description:
Miss SaiGon gives meaning to the famous Dr. Seuss quote regarding mutual weirdness:

We're all a little weird. And life is weird. And when we find someone 
whose weirdness is compatible with ours, we join up with them and fall into 
mutually satisfying weirdness--and call it love--true love." - Dr. Seuss

I'm a little weird and Miss SaiGon is DEFINITELY a little weird - noted as I walked in the front door only to be greeted by a plastic mannequin sporting a, "Miss SaiGon," beauty pageant sash - but our mutual weirdness just...works. 

When we first arrived it was completely dead inside; we may have been the only people in there other than the people who run it. Lucky for us we had juuust missed the rush because within 30 minutes the place was packed and bustling. And I found out why this place is so popular when our food arrived. 

The green papaya salad was unbelievable. I would go back just for that, over and over and over again. The garlic noodles weren't as good as Unicorn's but definitely a close second. The lemongrass chicken and beef dishes were also #winning! I have a feeling you can't go wrong with anything on their expansive menu.

See you again soon, Miss SaiGon. My, my, you're looking lovely tonight.
author: Julia N.

description:
Miss Saigon on the edge of the not so nice part of SF, but the scary looking mannequin scares the crazies away? Inside is nice and big. They seem to be able to accommodate large parties since someone was having one when I was there. Pretty tacky to have a bday lunch at a pho place, but to each their own. 

== Food ==

Miss Saigon seems to have quite a few popular Viet foods.They had sandwiches, spring rolls, rice dishes, noodle dish, and pho. There were also some interesting looking Asian desserts with a few European ones.

Beef Steak Pho. Broth was pretty good and delicious. The beef was good quality and tasted great.

Chicken Skewers with peanut sauce was good. Nicely marinated. The chicken was nice and tender while still juicy on the inside.

== Service == 

Service kind of sucked since it was hard to find a waiter. The food came out slower than expected for a pho restaurant. Maybe they were swamped? Who knows... 

== Overall ==

Overall, pretty good place to grab pho at a good price.
author: Steven B.

description:
Pretty good place for the area. 

Ordered:

1. Pho Tai soup - really good! Noodle is not clumped up at the bottom, quite a lot of need, delicious broth. Made right, I really liked it.

2. Catfish Claypot - tasty pieces of fish filet braised with some onions in a sweet sauce (I've added some chilli sauce to adjust the flavor and it was perfect)    :)

+ very attentive service
author: Mike D.

description: Really great Pho. The broth is so flavorful. The meat rice plates are just as good. Whenever I drive downtown to shop at Westfield, this is my go to after spot. :)
author: Andrew V.

description:
