Pretty good Vietnamese food, and you'd be hard pressed to find any good Vietnamese food in San Francisco.

There's a lot of variety at this place, and it serves the more authentic dishes of Vietnamese cuisine.  I'm not talking about pho and spring rolls.  I'm talking about papaya salad, ca kho, canh, and shaken beef.  The taste is pretty great too.  It's very flavor full, and the portions are pretty generous.  It's a little on the pricier side for Viet food, but what can you expect for the city.

There's also Viet desserts, drinks, and other side dishes.  And they play Paris By Night or some kind of equivalent to it.  Just watch out for the mannequin in front of the story.  If you're not careful, it'll freak you out.
author: Andy V.

description:
Fantastic and delicious! 

The food was very good and the service wonderful. I will definitely go back. 

They have some mock meat items for vegetarians, so I got the "chicken" and vegetables. It was delicious. My boyfriend got the chicken (real chicken) pho and really liked it.

The bathroom is super clean! Also, they have a flat screen TV playing old music videos of the 1980s, so everyone in there enjoyed watching videos like "We Are the World" and "Like a Virgin."

It was quite crowded for a Sunday evening, and there were a lot of people of Vietnamese decent there (many people in their Yelp reviews lament that when they go to an ethnic restaurant, there are never customers of that same ethnicity there because the food isn't authentic).
author: GreenEyez M.

description:
This place is really great. I have been here many times and the food is consistently good. The service is also always on target. I would definitely stick to the meat dishes in this place though. The shrimp is usually on the bland side. It is as if it is added to the dish after being cooked separately. Also I have had better Pho. Other than that great place. Nice/weird ambiance. Always odd music and even odder things playing on the tv screens.

Overall:
Certainly come to this place. 
Good food
Reasonable prices
Stick with a dish versus pho 
Stick with meat, pork, chicken.
author: Josh V.

description: Food was decent but I ordered online and was in a hurry so I didn't check the togo. They shorted me an order of spring rolls and I ordered extra rice and broth, which was also not included. Also, they offered a free desert and that was NOT in there either! 15$ with tip down the drain!
author: mia m.

description: Love this place. Super delicious food, extremely accommodating service. Been here several times now and, have been very happy with it each time. Means feeling under the weather today and went in for Pho Tai. Ordered a side of chicken broth and, one each of the fried and spring rolls... Everything was fantastic. The only   thing I don't like is the super sketchy neighborhood it is in.
author: Jen H.

description: Not the best vietnamese cuisines I've ever been to but I give a 4 stars bc customer service was excellent every visit. I ordered take-out and dine in 2x already. The food is good depending on what you order. I love bun rieu (crab soup) and this wasn't the best but it was ok. They have desserts like che and rice stuff both ok as well but again, I had better. Decor is nice and relaxing atmosphere.
author: AJ J.

description:
It is a decent lunch spot but if I have to rate this among all the pho shops I have been to, it is probably at the bottom tier. Reason being the steaks are cut too thick while the broth is good but the pho option is very limited. The very basic tendon and fat briskets are not available.

The interior is clean and pleasant. I enjoy my eating experience there but I just wouldn't give it any higher rating because of the pho itself.
author: Catherine Y.

description:
Not sure if this is a plus or a minus for other people but the most memorable part of this spot for me were the hilarious music videos of sappy and sometimes obscure 1990's love songs. Think, BBMak in white suits crooning on the beach or All-for-One serenading women on streets and buses. 

It gets stars for having authentic and decent Vietnamese food, fast and friendly service, and cleanliness. We had Hu Tieu soup and a broken rice and bbq dish, which were both satisfying but didn't really stand out a whole lot. The che was delicious and the coffee was standard Vietnamese coffee. It's slightly more expensive than your average Vietnamese spot but it'll do the trick if you're just in the area and craving Vietnamese.
author: RJ C.

description:
Another delicious restaurant within walking distance of my house! Unfortunately, you do have to brave some of the scarier parts of SOMA to get here. But, I would like to think it's worth the risk. 

My friend and I walked here to get a late dinner since pho sounded like it would hit the spot. We got here 30 minutes before they were closing and stayed well after closing, but the staff still graciously served us. We both ordered the Pho Tai Bo Vien (pho with rare steak and meat balls) with the rare steak on the side. They forgot the latter half of that order, but I forgive them because it was almost closing time. I thought the pho broth was very flavorful and definitely warmed me up from that windy San Francisco night. I also noticed that they serve durian smoothies, but I didn't want to inconvenience the wait staff; so that will have to wait for my next trip. 

I thought the best part of my visit was when they were closing, they changed the mannequin's clothes in the front! Awesome little place with some great Vietnamese pho and all the kitschy decorations to go with it!
author: Angela L.

description:
Ever since moving from the South Bay to SF, I've been on a search for good vietnamese food around the city. Of course this place isn't as good as most places in the SB, but it's clean and the broth of the soup is pretty tasty (not oily).

My roomie and I walked to this restaurant at night time. We were pretty freaked out by some of the people around. It's not in a very nice neighborhood so be careful if you're traveling on foot.

I had the pho (they don't have too much selection of pho). We also had the fried wonton with crab and cream cheese (yummy but fatty). Also had spring rolls and calamari (which was too salty but they give you huge portions).

Anyways I'll be back if I'm ever in the mood for some viet food while I'm in the city!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
The waiter took our order, a table of 5, by memorization.  However I never did get my appetizer, so writing down a dinner order would have worked out better? 

Three of us had a specialty plate, 2 consist of chicken, 1 beef.  All of the meat on our plates were very dry or over cooked. I was not impressed with this restaurant at all.
author: Linda F.

description:
Food is decent, service is slow and incompetent.  Took forever for waitstaff to take our order, and give us drinks (just water and tea), we had to specifically ask if we could order drinks. While it was a Saturday night, it wasn't excessively busy.

Dinner finally comes out (for one of us at least), still hadn't received utensils or napkins.  

After finishing eating the semi decent food, waitstaff asked if we would like anything else; we said we are finished....apparently that doesn't imply we would like our check.  20 minutes later, we flag down assistance (twice) to get them to close us out so we could finally leave.

Also observed a couple who sat indefinitely, receive food before getting their beverages as well.  

Seems like there is a systemic problem with culture and customer service. Also, didn't enjoy their bills that had been delivered earlier in the day just sitting on the table as if they were a third guest.
author: Staci S.

description:
Wow. A diamond in the rough that is SOMA/lower Tenderloin.

I went here with my parents after seeing a matinee showing of Spamalot. The walk down the street was SOOO sketch. How many crackheads did I pass? Don't know...lost count.

Once we got there, it was like a refuge from the craziness outside. Nicely decorated with shiny finished tables, crown moulding with a sky painted ceiling, and delicate little white porcelain pots for the soy sauce and chili. It was beautiful for a casual Vietnamese restaurant. And no smell! That was a plus.

We ordered the crab rangoon and crispy squid for appetizers. The server came out a few minutes later, said they ran out of squid and suggested we get the chicken wings, so we did. Crab rangoon was nice and crispy outside, super cheesy in the inside. It was delish! Another waiter took our appetizer plates, which threw me off because our chicken wings didn't come out yet. When our chicken wings came out, our waiter saw the puzzled look on our faces, and quickly got more plates. 

Our pho came out strategically right after we were done with the wings. My mom got the seafood combo with egg noodles, and my dad and I pretty much got the same thing: medium rare beef with beef balls. Simply delicious. Unlike other Pho places, they charge 6-7 dollars for a large bowl...flat rate, which I personally like. Get more bang for your buck that way. 

Their cucumber water is refreshing. Looked at the check, we weren't charged for our hot tea, which was a nice treat. Overall a great place to dine after seeing a show at Golden Gate. It's never dead. There's always a few people there dining and going in and out for take out. Beautiful atmosphere for a Vietnamese casual resaurant.
author: Grace L.

description: Five stars based on the pho ga (chicken noodle soup) alone. Excellent, clean flavors, chicken tasted great and is plentiful but I agree with other reviewers that the $8.25 is high. They call it free range chicken on the menu so if that's true I'll fork over the bucks. Really pleasant staff.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
Ordered #75 -- spicy flank steak with onions and basil.  Really good balance of flavor.  The fresh basil comes through nicely, though I found the spiciness to be lacking somewhat.

Had 8 in our party and food came out a bit staggered.  Reasonably priced and good portion size.
author: Josiah P.

description:
I like this place.  Interior is very nice for 6th street. 7 people ate for $120.00 not including tip.

The execution need work. Some plates came out a full 5 or 10 min before the rest and the appetizers were mixed in with the main meal.

Otherwise a great place. Good for last minute reservations.
author: Sean C.

description: Solid place for lunch. I work down the street and while I love Tu Lan down the street I hate walking past all the crackheads. Miss Saigon is clean and has modern decor. Staff are very friendly too. I a vermicelli bowl and mango drink and it was under $10. I'd definitely go back.
author: Carlos A.

description:
In my eyes the best Vietnamese place in San Francisco. I don't know why people cry about the closing of filthy Tu Lan when Miss Saigon is less than a block away? (*) Authentic, too - even their table ware is made in Vietnam. Hehe.

I have gone through all their soups - and with the exception of the crab meat in tomato soup base - I can vouch for all of them. When did I ever have a Pho in SF where the beef balls tasted like they were just fresh made?!

Sandwiches are a bargain, and almost all other dishes are absolutely excellent. You can taste the difference. I have yet to find a place that serves better dishes. To me, what Lers Ros is for Thai food in the city, Miss Saigon is for Vietnamese cuisine.

Just so you're warned: Their service is slooooooooow. Even sandwiches take an eternity, and that even when the restaurant is empty. The food compensates easily for that though!


And then finally (non-food related): What's up with their choice of music and TV selection?!

I have seen anything like nature and wildlife documentaries, over Fiji-inspired ab workout videos, to Kung Fu Panda to a 9/11 report on their LCD screens while the background music ranges from light muzak, to karaoke arrangements or unbearable Vietnamese covers of western music. Crazy! Adds to the atmosphere? No idea. I have been shaking my head more than once in disbelief about their questionable taste while sitting there, waiting for my food. :-)

(*) granted, I just looked it up, and Miss Saigon's inspection score of 69 on 03/19/2012 is not great. I hope they get back to their old 80+ score. Till then, I can only make this a 4 star review and not the 5 I would like to give them.
author: Tin Yan C.

description: Hands down the best Pho in all of SF!!! I've been going to Miss Saigon for years and the one thing you can be sure of, they are consistant and deliver quality every time. My favorite dishes are: #17B - Rare Beef Pho with Filet Mignon, #1 Spring rolls,  #45 Shaken Beef with garlic noodles (Amazing!!) also their vermicelli noodle dishes are delish! I've never had a bad dish. I've taken all my friends here and it's now their favorite Vietnamese spot.
author: Silvia S.

description: Food was good. The soup base for their pho is really well made. Also had their bahn mi - not as good as other places in the city. Service was horrible though. Took forever for the food to be served and for us to get the check afterwards. When we asked for the check the first time, they looked at us but pretty much ignored us. Took another 10mins and us asking for the check again. Will not be coming back.
author: Jason L.

description:
Sure the food is good, but the people watching is even better so be sure to grab a window seat!  I saw a transvestite prostitute with a visible gold thong riding a razor scooter and eating nachos.  I also spotted a crackhead presenting brand new high tops and DVDs to a chubby Godfather-meets-Samuel-L-Jackson-type on the street corner before getting his approval and entering his SRO together.  I also noticed some elderly Chinese ladies selling generic branded groceries they got for free (I know because I once volunteered at the food bank which packs those bags) to locals, undercutting the already cheap convenience stores.  The restaurant itself is many times nicer looking than Tu Lan, but doesn't rouse that same adventurous spirit of slumming it as duct tape covered bar stools.

Cha Gio: Forget all the vegetable crap in the Chinese and Thai versions of deep fried rolls, I'll stick with the meat intense Vietnamese versions.  Much larger than the mini rolls you tend to get at other Vietnamese joints, but smaller than the massive ones up the street at Tu Lan.

Wonton Soup: I was smooth talked into upgrading my meal into a combo which included this soup.  Looked Chinese, but had some Vietnamese aspects such as the inside of the wonton being reminiscent of the meatballs in pho.  I also appreciated the subtle black pepper broth even though I did eventually douse it with hot sauce.

Crab Rangoon: They should just call this Rangoon, since I didn't notice any crab.  Still tasty since it's basically deep fried cream cheese.  Obviously inauthentic, but so are fortune cookies and I enjoy those!

Bo Luc Lac: The crown jewel of my meal here.  Not the filet mignon version, but still nice cuts seared on the outside and just the right amount of tenderness on the inside.  The fried potatoes were a nice a touch because when paired with the onions and excess sauce, it reminded me of my favorite Peruvian dish - lomo saltado.  Of course lomo saltado doesn't have the delicious lime, black pepper and fried garlic dipping sauce... but maybe it should?

Garlic Noodle: I feel like garlic noodles is a comfort food akin to fried rice.  It's easy to make a good version, but rare to hear anyone rave about it explicitly.  Much better than boring white rice, wish more places would offer this as a starch alternative to those boring grains.
author: Adam B.

description:
Mot in the best part if town, but What a great find! This restaurant was recommended by a friend. I was skeptical at first,  but any/all doubts was gone once the food was served! 

The pho is pretty tasty, however I ventured out and ordered the Hieu Tieu ( vermecilli w/ crab paste). Not like my momma's but pretty darn close! 
The Garlic noodle & prawns were also a hit. The chicken salad ( goi ga) was a slight disappointment, not for the taste, but for the meager portion.  All in all I would definitely return! Until next time... Ciao!

Ps- order the fresh squeezed lemonade. It really is amazingly refreshing!
author: Linda D.

description: Stopped in at random because I was desperate for a bowl of pho. Was pleasantly surprised to see the place packed. Ordered chicken wings, egg rolls and a small #17 bowl of pho with medium rare beef. Wings were very mild but had good flavor and crisp. Egg rolls were standard yet hit the spot. Soup for the pho had awesome aroma and was very flavorful. More than enough meat for me. Overall very happy with the entire dining experience. The neighborhood isn't great but I'd say it was worth the risk ;)
author: N. P.

description: Great viet food. However, this time I ordered a 5 spice chicken sandwich to go and it took almost 1 hr. Seriously?!?  That's about the time it takes to go to a farm to kill a chicken and come back and cook it.  It's Saturday night but the restaurant wasn't completely full.  The sandwich tasted awesome which is why I give it 4 stars. Also, I've been here before and service was excellent. But seriously, get it together guys!
author: Jennie C.

description: The service is good but the food .. Err.. Pho has grounded beef, very weird because after all, is the beef that makes your bowl of pho good.
author: STEPHANY L.

description:
I love that their menu has names, descriptions and photos, to assist newbies to Vietnamese cuisine (like me). 

My family and I ate here, and all the appetizers and entrees were delicious. I had a noodle bowl with veggies and tofu, and it was very tasty. I should have added a bit of hot sauce to give it more kick.

The area is a bit sketchy, but if you go in the daylight hours, you should be fine.
author: Brandi W.

description:
To have a place this clean in such a gnarly section of the city is next to a miracle. That they serve decent food as well is a big plus. This is generally my spot to go for some pho dac biet or pho tai if I don't want to try and handle a trip to Chinatown for lunch. Like I said, the food isn't wildly incredible, but it's still good, reliable and the people are super friendly. 

The prices are reasonable $6.50 for a bowl (no option for small or large, I believe), and all the other dishes are in that same ballpark. Folks I bring here generally enjoy whatever they order, so that's good news, and it's definitely not as harsh as digging in on some Tu Lan. 

They can sometimes get packed for lunch and service can get a little scattered from time to time, but the friendliness and eagerness of the staff more than makes up for that. If, on your walk back to the office, the dude swinging the cleavers is out on Mission, just cross the street. It's not worth finding out whether or not he's out to get someone or just fighting the voices with edged tools. But I think that goes without saying.
author: Roy M.

description: I tried this restaurant because it's close to my office and went on two occasions, once when picking up lunch for myself and once for dinner with a friend. The food was fine (3 stars). I had the crab imperial rolls (meh), Thai iced tea (good and same price with or without boba/tapioca balls/pearls), and the beef pho (solid). However, I didn't like the atmosphere (1.5 stars). Upon walking into the restaurant on both visits, I was hit with a strong smell of cleaning products. I'm glad they clean, but the place shouldn't reek of it. Secondly, a really long-legged spider repelled down from the ceiling onto my friend's seat (she jumped off). All in all, I won't be back. There are a few other Vietnamese places in the area and PLENTY more in the city.
author: Glo T.

description: the exterior of the building might scare you go in, but you should get in and try! Love their combination noodle soup, grilled pork vermicelli, and spring rolls. They have a lot of choices that i haven't tried yet, but im so sure they all good. Highly recommand to all.
author: Diane Y.

description:
This is what happened. A while back I've got tickets to a show at the Orpheum and I've a mind to catch dinner beforehand, on the grounds that I've been told all my life that I have to eat at least semi-regularly if I don't want to die (technically, this remains untested conjecture in my particular case, but be that as it may). I have two standards: It should be cheap and non-toxic. Those are the same two standards I apply to everything, which I guess explains a lot about my life, but this really isn't the appropriate venue to interrogate that issue more closely, and besides you don't have all night. I get word that there's a really great Vietnamese place on this block. And it turns out there is: Tu Lan. But I get the directions scrambled and I end up at this *other* Vietnamese place, Miss Saigon, and assume it must be where we're looking for.

A word about Sixth Street: I'm generally of the opinion that neighborhoods with bad reputations usually aren't so bad, and that their biggest crime is daring to have poor and/or non-white people living in them, thus making them less palatable to those whose picture of an ideal city looks like an issue of LIVING, but more outside. Even I know when I'm in over my head, though, and a trip down just one block of Sixth Street is enough to tell me that it's a perfectly fine and charming urban corridor for anyone who feels they've lived long enough without personal hazard already.

Given this, it's a wonder that there actually are quite a few good eateries here, and after a while I decided I'd figured out how they stay in business: When you find yourself walking down Sixth Street, your lower brain seizes your motor controls and makes it Priority Number Now to get anywhere else. The closest doorway possessing more illumination than a birthday candle becomes a very attractive destination and you're inside before your conscious mind even registers what's happened. At which point you might as well stop and have a bite to eat while you mentally reconnoiter where you are and, depending on how rough the trip was, who you are.

All this is just a preamble to letting you know that if you possess the five basic senses that are sufficient to keep most people far, far away from the 100 block of Sixth (lacking unusually pressing business and/or the reassuring accompaniment of a flamethrower), you're missing out. This little place has a nice staff, affordable prices (even for me, a man who is one tax bracket away from having to rent his pants on a week-to-week rate), and really, really tasty cuisine. I don't know how they do it. When we hear self-serving homilies about risk-taking entrepreneurs it's usually in reference to some kind of Wall Street hoodoo that magically turns someone else's foreclosure into your vacation in Dubai, but if you ask me the people behind Miss Saigon are the real courageous pioneers in this economy. Beautiful place. Hope we see more like it around here someday.
author: Tam Lin J.

description:
I hail from the Pacific Northwest where it is the breeding ground for Vietnamese food, though I have no idea why. I stumbled upon Miss Saigon before a Yelp Elite event because I was too cold to walk elsewhere. 

Food was meh. I've definitely experienced better, but I was RAVENOUS, so it tasted like a 3-star at the time. It wasn't so terrible that I'd spit out my food, but I just wasn't very impressed. After seeing multiple reviews raving about the garlic noodles, I was disappointed to find it bland and greasy. Pho was better, probably the best meal I had there but it's pretty hard to mess up a bowl of noodles and broth.
author: Annie L.

description: Vancouver foodie here. It was hard to find a good pho restaurant in San Francisco. This place is pretty authentic and you should definitely give it a try if you like pho.
author: Steven P.

description: Best shaken beef I've found. Some places are just special. This is one of them. Carefully done decor, really nice service. Food is a notch above all the other Vietnamese places around. The owners moved into this miserable area several years ago and have stuck it out, slowly building a happy clientele. I am very glad these days to see the dining room full for dinner. These guys deserve it.
author: stephan k.

description: There are not enough options open in SoMa on a Sunday night. If you live in south beach, mission bay or SoMa and want something inexpensive and "ethnic", this place makes a great replacement for Tu Lan. I like it better. It has very easy parking. Love the Pho. lovely, festive Christmas cartoons, music and lights. It's kind of campy. Must try here.
author: Bill W.

description: Was in the hood running an errand and stopped in here. Spring rolls and Pho with wontons and pork. Yummy stuff. Pretty extensive looking menu. Looks like a lot of local office workers get theirs to go...bahnmi sandwiches as well. Stop in if you're in the hood...worth it!
author: Doug V.

description: I came here twice. The first time I had spring rolls and it was good. The second time, my friend and I ordered bun bo hue - spicy beef pho. The beef was so hard we couldn't chew it. It was as hard as a rock. We were very upset so my friend complained. She apologized and said they just hired a new chef. She tried to make it up by giving up free desserts. However, she should have given us a discount, cause we basically ate pho without beef. I'm not coming here again, especially since there are so many other Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood with better food and cheaper prices.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
It's been nearly two months since I dined here with colleagues and Miss Saigon's garlic noodles and shaking beef (bo luc lac) remain on my mind. The lunch specials are super generous and include soup and crab rangoon (there's something about cream cheese in a fried wrapper that gets me every time!)

We were steered here by a vegetarian so I think it's safe to say Miss Saigon's got something for everyone. I'll certainly return the next time I'm in SoMa.
author: Miriam W.

description: Mediocre or worse - had the Pad Thai to go and will not be going back. Plenty of other nearby options with better service and taste.
author: John S.

description: This place has terrible costumer service. My fiancé and I will never return to this establishment. We were looking for a place to eat and stopped in to check out the menu. While doing so, our friend went to the restroom. Accordingly, the manager of the restaurant approached my fiancé and me in order to lecture us about how expensive it is for him to allow people to use his restroom. His tone was demeaning and he was highly patronizing. I sincerely recommend people not patron this restaurant.
author: Stephen T.

description: Delicious and reasonably priced. The soup broth and sauce on the tofu dish I ordered had an amazing, fragrant taste of lemongrass. It was present but not overpowering in the dishes. Excellent balance.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Came here for lunch. 

The server was very friendly, the Pho was hot and fresh, and they have awesome Vietnamese music videos playing on the TVs. 

The price is right! I think my Pho was $7.   I would definitely come back for lunch again.
author: Bailey M.

description: Delicious pho, great location, cozy atmosphere, pretty awesome owner!
author: R C.

description: Holy cow this place is always packed, didn't take long for us to get seated but the waiter took a bit long to take our order. I had some pho tom (shrimp pho) which isn't on their menu but they made it anyway and it was awesome. Place is small and gets really crowded, loud and stuffy.
author: Betty G.

description: Great smoothies, good food and decently priced.  Sketchy neighborhood in SOMA.
author: Germán P.

description:
What a surprise!  I've had a good amount of Vietnamese food and this is by far the best I've ever had!  The whole experience was great.  The ambiance of the restaurant is very clean and well decorated.  The music is ambient as well with birds chirping and waterfall sounds and ocean waves and instrumentals.  Now the food: I ordered my usual Vietnamese vermicelli noodle bowl with barbecued pork and egg roll (sorry, don't now the Vietnamese name).  The pork was succulent and a huge bowl!  The chili sauce I added tasted homemade, I swear.  My husband had a gigantic bowl of spicy soup which was flavorful, too.  We ordered spring rolls as an appetizer and they were very fresh.  The service was great and attentive.
This is a gem in a very seedy area.  Walk down from Tu Lan and have a great meal at a very, very reasonable price.
author: Mary D.

description:
Long story short: They got my order wrong but they are psychic and knew what I really wanted deep down and it was delicious and I ate it all. 

Seriously. I was debating (in my head, I swear.) spicy pho or vermicelli bowl, but it was kind of hot so I ordered (tried to) the vermicelli. I just said the number cause I can't pronounce any of that Vietnamese, and the guy said it back to me it sounded like the number... but then he asked me about the spiciness level and I should have asked about that because the vermicelli I ordered didn't have anything that typically is spicy. But whatever.  Anyway, what I got was a bowl of spicy seafood pho with egg noodles. I looked and was like... THIS IS FULL OF EVERYTHING I LOVE. HOW DID YOU KNOW?!! and dug in. It was so yummy. I didn't even know that was something I could order. I saw the spicy beef pho, but didn't know there was a seafood option. Also, I like egg noodles more than vermicelli. They basically pulled out the perfect dish for me despite myself. These guys are some kinda pho gurus who peer into your soul and provide you with your deepest desires.***

Would come back but the neighborhood scares me a little.

***NB: Results may vary.
author: Lady V.

description:
Located in one of San Francisco's finest neighborhoods, nestled in the charming area of the Tenderloin sometimes affectionately referred to as Skid Row, you'll find Miss SaiGon, where the surroundings conjure up the feel of an oasis in the otherwise drab and decaying backdrop of Northern California. No matter the time of day: at dawn, mid afternoon, or at any given hour in the middle of the night, you're likely to see several fine folks out for a pleasant stroll. This is where the elite of San Francisco society come to play. 

Kidding!! Jokes aside, Miss SaiGon is in a very run down, depressing part of the city. It's more or less safe during the day, but at night things get a little seedier. There's always a number of characters milling about, but they pretty much ignore passersby, save for the occasional aggressive panhandler. If you're not overly sensitive to that kind of thing, though, what you'll get with Miss SaiGon is a decent little Vietnamese restaurant that has dozens and dozens of respectable dishes at affordable prices. The staff is friendly, the service is fast, and they do a good enough job of keeping things clean. The Pho is average to slightly above average, and in general, the ingredients they use for their dishes seem fresh and of moderately good quality.

Go there if you're craving cheap Vietnamese food and you're not intimidated by the surroundings.
author: Don W.

description:
Good soup, hearty rice plates, best veggie egg rolls i've had in quite some time.

Service was very friendly and helpful and nothing was too expensive. Definitely coming back.

Only element I didn't like were the music videos. When I visited they were cheesy country, and while it was amusing, it seemed out of place.
author: t g.

description:
Getting closer to finding my elusive (good) bun rieu...

Popped in here for lunch today and I thought it was pretty tasty.  Got the cha gio (crispy spring rolls) and ordered bun rieu (tomato based soup w/ vermicelli and crab meat - but I asked for shredded chicken).

The menus are cute, they used photo albums and scrapbooked in the items.
author: Priscilla T.

description: It was disgusting how much fat they leave in their pho. I spooned so much of it out and it still left my lips greasy. I grew up in the Little Saigon area in Westminster and have never eaten at a place that had so much fat.  The service was also poor...i waited awhile before anyone acknowledged us.
author: Nancy K.

description:
Had the usual beef pho and spring rolls

the beef was sparse and the soup was too salty, the rolls were average.

BUT what made it special was their accommodation for my bicycle!
author: Sam L.

description:
Oh my, do I LOVE this place! I'm just going to make this review short and simple.

+ CLEAN CLEAN CLEAN, place! Must be the cleanest Vietnamese Pho place I ever been.
+Ordering was quick and easy. 
+ Nice waiter, took my order without writing it down. Just stood, listen, nod, repeat. He can memorize your whole order! ( I came here with my parents, so it was around  3 people total)
+ They have clean bathrooms! That's like HARD to find! In this neighborhood AND in the normal pho restaurants. They have automatic paper towel dispenser!
author: Jenny N.

description:
a 1.5 stars - but i have to round down. yes, i was a disappointed customer.

- service was RIDICULOUSLY SLOW (we ordered two dishes, and we were there for two hours - not sure if they lost our ticket or they went to fish for the salmon. we have checked with the waiter, and he just said it's coming)
- lighting was unwelcoming and dim
- were out most of things we wanted to order (sea bass, green Thai iced tea, mango smoothie, etc)
- we ordered shaking beef and salmon. brown rice was not really brown rice; more like a mix of brown and white rice. i have tasted better garlic noodles. salmon's marinade was tasty, but the fish wasn't very fresh. beef was tasty, too.
- Thai iced tea was too sweet.
- not cheap for the service / ambiance / location

overall, i probably wouldn't go back. might only consider at most a take out.
author: Diana C.

description:
I came here through a gwu group and after walking by an alley way beat down and colorful language of all sorts I was glad that I made it to my destination safely. 

We started the meal with pork and shrimp spring rolls that were good but not mind blowing. Our second starter was the calamari. I would eat that calamari morning, noon and night. It was sweet and savory and melt in your mouth perfection. The third starter was a chicken salad with a sweet & savory dressing. I would hate performing after that calamari but many folks at the table said they loved it. 

Our entrees included a succulent filet mignon beef, delicious garlic noodles and prawns with an amazing garlic lime dip, rice and spicy yellow curry and a green bean and egg dish. This was the only dish I didn't really care for - the eggs were sweet (like sugar was added) and I felt it needed some heat .  

Dessert was an interesting fruit and coconut dish. Some folks didn't like it but I enjoyed it. 

I enjoyed the meal, the service was somewhat attentive and the group was very diverse. I've already signed up for 2 more gwu meals and if Miss SaiGon is a precursory of whats to come I'm sure I'll enjoy myself. 

I'll be back with some of my less-faint-of-heart friends.
author: Jade W.

description: Quite possibly the best Vietnamese food in San Francisco. Ignore some of the less favorable reviews; they are baseless and ignorant comments and most of them don't even regard to food. Don't miss out!
author: Samuel R.

description:
FIVE!

First off, A+ for being open on Easter Sunday. You can always rely on Asian places for that fact. :) Our group was in need of a place that can seat 8 and be close to the Orpheum for our pre-Wicked lunch. We came here because I dont remember wreaking of pho or fish sauce after my meal, which would be nice since some of us were dressed for a musical.

Service was a little off today--they seemed a little confused as to how to seat a party of 8 despite the fact that all their tables were empty except for one. There was also some misunderstanding which caused us to wait a little before we can put in our order. BUT i thought it was great that the person who took our order memorized it and didnt have to write anything down.

The pictures on the menu are deceiving--all the rice plates came out WAY better than the pictures (there was even a rendered plate, which was hilarious [no. 42 or something]). I only had a summer roll and appreciated that my fish sauce came with a little spoon. There's nothing i hate more than dipping my roll in the sauce and having the insides fall out. This solves my problem and I love that they're thoughtful like that. I still love the fact that they serve cucumber water!

I  l o v e  this place.

Yea, I said it.
author: Rena Y.

description:
This place is pretty decent. Was in the area for a friends birthday and needed to go somewhere for lunch. Looked for an Asian restaurant, it this was the closest place that had the decent reviews, so had to try it out.

Right when you walk in, you are greeted by Ms. Saigon! Yeah, a manikin right by the door. Kinda tripped me out since there was another guy standing right there. Thought he was a manikin too! LOL! Yeah, a lil creepy! Also, they have a background music inside the restaurant, that kind of make you sleepy while you wait for your food. 

Anyways, the food was pretty good. I ordered the chicken with egg over rice dish. The sauce was good that compliments the chicken. Can't really say anything special about the food, kind of the same as anywhere else. 
The service is good, but at the same time, it was pretty slow! There were only two tables at the restaurant. I also had to try their boba drinks. Every place has it different, and man was this one really different! I ordered the taro boba and it was good. Decent, but why is the Boba frozen??? That's the first.. different?!

Like I said, I don't have much to say, but I don't mind coming back if I'm in the area. But i'mma make sure I'm not ordering that Boba drink!
author: Marc M.

description: Not sure what the hype is all about, having had much authentic Viet cuisine.  I dont think Miss SaiGon is particularly trying too hard to be going the extra mile for run of the mill Pho options, nor the requisite grilled meats, such as grilled pork.  There was nothing particularly wrong with my Pho Ba, however the meats was overcooked, and the addition of other cuts were overly grissly and chewy, and require more cooking and less discarding in the bowl.  The broth was good but again nothing wow.  The grilled pork over rice, was thinly sliced, marinated in lemon grass, off the bone, which was ok, but again without much depth of flavor.
author: Alex R.

description: Wow!! Let's start off with two thumbs down. First, the three spice chicken was not even fully cooked. The fried rice was not fried rice. (smh) Second, I asked if I can change my order to chicken fried rice because I thought maybe I would be satisfied, well I was not. The manager said I would have to buy another order of dish. Third, I asked for water and never received it. I thought Christmas was in December. Christmas music is playing, surrounded by Christmas decorations that are not very warming, especially when Christmas is not yet around I thought. Overall, the manager was rude and the customer service was sad. The place has been consumer alerted for a poor food safety score of below 5%. I would advise anyone who is searching for a Vietnamese restaurant to eat at, not to come here. It's awful and my stomach feels awful thinking about it.
author: Eugene N.

description: My husband and I decided to eat here after a recommendation from a friend. We ordered the cold noodles for an appetizer and those were very flavorful and had a great price. I do like it when certain restaurants just go ahead and send out the food so it is fresh and doesn't sit in the window however, I waited a while for mine. By the time I got my food my husband was already finished with his. The tofu I ordered was excellently cooked. It is rare to find tofu that isn't soggy! I did think the vegetables were a little overlooked and I found a hair in my food. It wasn't the worst place but I don't think we would come back.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Recently, I've been craving hot soups and noodles because of these cold crisp days.  Working near the Tenderloin, I have plenty of choices, but I am always drawn to Miss Saigon.  After power walking down the long blocks with dogs doing their business and leaving their "gifts" left behind, I enter into Miss Saigon and reality is shut off.  It's warm inside, you hear all the slurping and forks hitting plates, and you see many happy faces eating their yummy food.

I usually order the Bun Bo Hue, which is a spicy tangy soup with different cuts of pork and thick vermicelli noodles. I like their BBH because they top the dish off with a heaping spoon of chili paste without mixing it in. Doing so allows you to control how much spice you want. Don't like spicy? Simply scoop it out! 

Imperial rolls are stuffed generousoy, always fried to order, and continuously makes me go " mmmmm"

Miss Saigon is always crowded during lunch hours Monday-Friday so if you don't want to wait, come after 1:30 or by 11:30am
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Good service, clean restaurant, decent food. Just your run of the mill Vietnamese restaurant in a super scary part of town.
author: Jeanne C.

description: Worst Pho I've ordered in SF.  Chicken was fatty and gross--and not much of it either.  Noodles seemed overlooked and the heated stuff was mixed in with the sprouts, basil and lime.  Would not order here again.
author: Michaela C.

description:
good food and a number of veggie options including a handful of fake meat dishes.  but the service could be better.

a nice oasis that makes you forget what neighborhood you're in.
author: Karen O.

description:
That mannequin... seriously.

Anyway, I ordered a bun (w/ grilled pork, vegetables and egg rolls).  It was quite delicious and the servers were very attentive to us.  It was no Pho Ao Sen (drool) but it still hit the spot.  

One thing that was really noteworthy to me was the amount of meat they give you.  I finished everything in that bowl but the meat because there was sooo much.  Pretty awesome.
author: Christine B.

description: Excellent Pho!  Best I've had in the bay area.  Rich broth with good sugar/salt balance.  Here's the DISCLAIMER: I'm pretty sure there is a fair amount of MSG.  If you're OK with that, the Pho is really good.  If you're sensitive, I would avoid.  The service is good, very friendly.
author: Justin J.

description: Delicious pho and spring rolls, verified "close to authentic" by my Vietnamese friends.
author: Nick S.

description:
My first trip to Miss Saigon included: 

- A crack ho haggling me about my bicycle basket and following me to ask very excitedly more about it
- A crack head bumping into me after chasing one of his runaway tennis balls into the street
- A very long hair wrapped around my vermicelli 
- Being moved from one table to another because I was dining solo and they needed to make room for another party

But I won't let no crack ho or hair in my food get me down. The vermicelli bowl with grilled pork and egg roll, drenched in spicy fish sauce was damn tasty and very reasonably priced. 

I'll be back, fo sho.
author: Jen D.

description:
I've returned numerous times for lunch and......

Drumroll.....

The service kinks are essentially ironed out!

Food comes quickly, the servers are the sweetest, and there's absolutely nothing to complain about.

Except for Sixth Street, but it's on the corner so your exposure is minimal.
author: Joanna M.

description:
This clean, bright spot is an oasis in a grim stretch of the city. Your best choice for lunch if you're doing business at the Federal Building, and not a bad hike from SF Centre or the Metreon, 3 blocks away.

they have a variety of lunch plates at 9-10 bucks but I was with a large group so we tried some of their specials. Standouts were the #83 crunchy rice with seafood (there were some mushroom bits that tasted like chanterelles in there too); #43 shaken beef with garlic noodles (really a lot of tender beef in this one) and #13 vietnamese pancake stufed with bean sprouts and pork. #11 green papaya salad was not spicy enough, but redeemed by lots of bits of candied jerky on top. #91 rib eye for some reason came without the asparagus mentioned on the menu, but in any case this was the least interesting dish--just some tender beef with a mustard gravy--and also the most expensive at $17.95.
author: Otis M.

description: Arrived in SF in the evening and was craving for Pho. Yelp suggested this place so there I went. I have to admit that the walk here was sketchy at night. I ordered the #20 Combination Beef Pho and wasn't disappointed. The portion was definitely generous and it was worth the money. Service was good (not sure what one can really expect) and food arrived promptly.
author: Anders C.

description:
Miss Saigon is an interesting place. Its pretty much deep in crackhead- land south of market. I like to do a jig step to confuse them and then perform a spin move. Works every time.

As for the restaurant itself. Very clean. I must say I was almost not sure about even placing an order here because it was TOO CLEAN feeling. I just see truly delicious Pho spots as slightly grimey. 

On to the food. I usually order Pho Tai Chin at every Pho spot I go to. I found the broth and soup to be very tasty. All very standard fair. I mixed it up a little bit by adding won-tons to my order. All was very delicious and reasonably priced. 

The service was good, however I had one gripe which led to my 3 star rating. If you are a "I remember your order instead of writing it down" type waiter, then you better not forget my order or mess it up. This was my second time at Miss Saigon. First time I asked for won tons, they confirmed it, then didn't do it. Second time I came they got the won tons but then forgot my order of Fried Pork Egg Rolls :( No need to be fancy, just write it down!

Bathrooms were also ridiculously clean. 

I can't say I will come back here often. There are spots closer to my house but today I was trying to be a little more adventurous. Plus there are some better Viet places deeper in the tenderloin.
author: Lawrence S.

description:
Came here with Grubwith.us and had a great time with cool people and delicious food!

Originally 12 people had signed up for the dinner, but only 10 showed up, which meant tons of food for everybody.  I think the amount of food we got would have filled up 12 people easily, but we scored leftovers, too!

Our family-style menu:
-spring rolls (a large, dense roll for each person, stuffed with noodles, pork, shrimp, and veggies.  served with a yummy peanut sauce)
-chicken salad (more of a vinegar slaw, with a shredded cabbage base, chicken, and topped with crunchy peanuts)
-calamari (crispy and salty [in a good way], with a bit of a kick)
-tiger prawns w/ garlic noodles (giant fried prawns and garlic = delicious)
-green beans (stir fried with mushrooms and egg, a great foil to the strong flavors in the other dishes)
-chicken curry (the curry was an unappetizing shade of neon yellow, but it did taste pretty good!)
-grilled lemongrass pork (unfortunately at this point of the meal I was so stuffed I could only fit in one little piece of the pork and steak.)
-filet mignon
-coconut milk w/ fruit for dessert.

An impressive menu, to say the least, even before considering we had multiples of almost every dish!  Everything was good, though my favorites were the chicken salad and tiger prawns.  

Service was surprisingly good for such a large group - my cucumber water was refilled in a timely manner, and the food kept coming and coming!
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Miss Saigon is a great place for a casual sit-down meal. By far, my favorite item on the menu is the #57 - Tofu with Yellow Coconut Curry. The sauce is really flavorful and rich.

The fried rice was a disappointment. I'm pretty sure the carrots came from a can and weren't fresh. Tu Lan's fried rice is much better.

The garlic noodle was pretty solid. Still no match for the #57.
author: Nikhil N.

description: This is my favorite place to get pho in all of San Francisco. My favorite thing on the menu is 17b, which is a bowl of sirloin pho. The area is pretty creepy but seems pretty safe on weekdays around lunch time since so many people are out on their lunch breaks.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
This spot is busy at lunch so go as early as u can.

They never let your water glass go empty

Every time I go if i'm with a group or by myself the service is great.. I love the Vegetarian dishes.
author: Sherrell D.

description:
I am writing this review right after recovering from food poisoning from the dinner I had at this restaurant.
I had their tofu with veggies and spices with brown rice. The flavor was a bit odd but thought it could be the way the tofu was cooked.
Not even an hour after I left the place I was throwing up. Spend all Friday night and Saturday living in the bathroom.
I would not recommend this place, its obvious there was something wrong with the tofu or it had been sitting there for days.
Speaks of low quality in their sanitary practices and the freshness of the ingredients.

Shame on you
author: Salvador O.

description: Very friendly service! And the Pho is good! Nice place to stop in on a cold or rainy day!
author: Nataja L.

description: Very large portions, and cheap prices.  It's hard to choose what to order, though, because the menu is freaking gigantic.
author: Bill H.

description: First visit was super successful, had some standard pho with filet and two spring rolls.  The rice paper on the rolls was a little tough but otherwise they were delicious.  The small pho was really small - I drained my bowl, a rarity for the normally giant servings! - but was absolutely delicious.  I look forward to going back in the future and trying more menu options.  (I was there for pho specifically but the menu was expansive and looked delicious!)
author: Aaron C.

description: Food was decent but service was pretty darn bad. Took almost 20 minutes for them to deliver the beverages we ordered. Overall meh experience.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I came here on a Thursday evening with a friend on a whim. The server was nice, but the restaurant has a weird vibe. Kind of hospital cafeteria-y. 

I ordered vegetable friend rice and it was some of the worst rice I've had. There was a fishy taste to it-- literally fishy. Like it had been mixed with seafood fried rice or something. The vegetables in it were clearly from a frozen vegetable pack. It was $9-- pretty pricey for the quality. 

My friend ordered something that we thought was Pho (probably our mistake), but when it came it had all of the fixings of Pho, but with no broth. Confusing. 

We also got shrimp spring rolls that were also not very fresh and the shrimp was not so delicious.

All in all, not a good experience and would not come back.
author: Lucas W.

description:
thanks again to yelp for this great find. let me tell you why i like this place:
- close (enough) to where i work (zendesk)
- cleaner and one block better than where tu lan is located
- lunch specials are generous portions!
- authentic tasting
author: Helen Y.

description: My  favorite to go to for vegetarian pho and thai papaya salad.  Service is always good.
author: Maria B.

description:
Not bad, not bad at all. Wouldn't choose it over Tin's, but unfortunately Tin's only opens during the week and NOT the weekend when chances of hangovers are eminent, thus making Miss Saigon probably my new go to spot for the weekends. The pho I like. The mi, not so much. Noodles were a bit too soggy and the broth could've used a little more oompf. Banh xeo was pretty satisfying and I enjoyed the spring rolls. I was eyes-dropping on a few other tables and it looked like some sort of fried tofu dish was extremely popular. I'll have to have a go at that next time.

Very friendly service on the 2 times I've been here. All in all, (OK hand sign).
author: Jennifer N.

description: Being Vietnamese myself from Orange County. It was difficult for me to find a really good Vietnamese restaurant in SF, but this place is actually pretty decent! I prefer this place over any place in the TL, and find it to be one of the more authentic. Not to mention, the servers are always very warm and welcoming. I come here with my boyfriend and we usually split the goi cuon(though very good, but you have to order it with extra shrimp and pork cause the skimp on meat sometimes), shaken beef with garlic noodles(not true to tradition but also very delectable), and their pho tai! Best broth in town! It actually tastes like pho! Unlike most places around where more often than not, the soup is very bland..
author: dylan t.

description: Ordered the vermicelli with grilled pork and imperial rolls.  The pork was not very good, and there was only one imperial roll, though it was delicious.  Over all, pretty good lunch.
author: Jett S.

description:
Hands down the cleanest and friendliest Vietnamese restaurant I have ever been to in San Francisco!  It is family run, has a huge menu with photos, and the food is great.  The tables are set with cloth napkins, plates and silverware, which is not the norm for reasonably priced Asian restaurants.

I've had just about everything on the menu and my rotating list of favorites include:  bun rieu (crab meat with noodles with tomato broth), pho, grilled pork on rice, garlic noodles and shaking beef.  There are plenty of options for vegetarians and the prices are very reasonable (most items under $10).

They play the strangest assortment of DVDs on the flatscreen TVs on the wall, but it just adds to the experience.  Last month it was a collection of Wham videos from the 80s which was a great blast from the past for me, and on a recent visit it was the Best of Bonnie M (carribean singer from the 70s?) which became the topic of conversation at our table because it was so bizarre.  

Food:  5 stars
Service:  5 stars
Cleanliness:  5 stars
Ambiance:  Friendly, quirky (unintentional), welcoming
author: K D.

description: Great Vietnamese food & great hospitality. I'd recommend the PHO and also any dish from the specialities. :-)
author: Adriana U.

description: YUM! I will start out by saying I am a bit of pho snob since nothing can compare to Ba's homemade pho. San Jose is usually the only place with authentic, perfectly executed broth, but this place gives San Jose pho a run for its money. The broth is always on point! Their Bun Bo Hue is pretty good too, and spicy! I cant get enough of this place, its my go to spot for soup. Their Banh Mi's aren't bad either. The neighborhood sucks, and parking can be a challenge (bring quarters!) but its definitely worth it!
author: Vee N.

description:
I really USED TO like this place. I would visit often because the Pho was great. I like the broth and the price is just right. I've tried other dishes here and they've been fairly good as well.

Lately, I've noticed that the quality of the beef in the Pho has gone down significantly. It used to be nice and tender. Now it's tough and chewy. I thought it was a fluke the first time, but it's been the norm the past few times I've tried it.

Also, the noodles aren't the same as they used to be. Before they were nice and soft, now they are too tough (almost al dente). This combined with the toughness of the meat makes for a very difficult chewing situation. My jaw started to hurt after a while :(

I also want to ad that the spring rolls are a total ripoff. It's mostly lettuce and they slice the cooked shrimp so thin that you literally get one piece of shrimp thinly sliced across a very thick spring roll stuffed with lettuce.  MAJOR RIPOFF.

I'm sorely disappointed because I really used to like this place :(
author: DJ N.

description:
I don't know if I like this place anymore.  For some reason the same dish of Shrimp with Asparagus in Chili sauce was very different than the one I had 4 days ago.  The previous dish had much more shrimp than the one tonight and was cheaper at $10.95 versus $11.95 tonight.  The most disappointing thing was the way they served the dish with the rice and 2 fried wontons(stuffed with ricotta cheese or something) on one plate versus the previous when they brought a whole dish of the stir fried shrimp and then the rice.  It just looked like a "lunch special" shrimp dish and at $11.95 it shouldn't. I am disappointed that they are going this route.  I know they have to make money, however before the dish looked very special like a true restaurant and meticulously prepared.  The one plate special tonight just gave me a very bad taste in my mouth.  When I paid the change they gave back contained a dank wrinkled $5 bill that stank so bad it must have came from a homeless person's ass.  

I don't think I am going back to this place.
author: Jim J.

description:
Bright venue.  Accommodate large group  (we must have over 12 people).  I ordered the small pho and it was just the right size for lunch.  Did I mention it is very reasonably priced (around $6).  This is one nice cheap + tasty lunch place.  

Did I mention the restaurant have many choices.  The menu is huge.   Always more dishes to try before you have to repeat.
author: Steven M.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet, I LOVE MISS SAIGON!!! I think it's actually my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city.
author: Heather B.

description: Sadly I was not a giant fan of this place. The restaurant was very nice and staff was friendly, but the staff was very forgetful and slow. Even when it was just my friend and I dinning. Food was good and I'm sure they get enough business but I don't think I will be returning anytime soon. :(
author: Joji V.

description:
When you enter Miss Saigon you are greeted by a very still hostess, no, wait, a female mannequin!

And from the rest of the decor, it's clear that the curators of Miss Saigon's walls appreciate the sensuality of the female figure, and also children's cartoons.

Because above the portraits of ladies, there are dual TVs tuned to The Tom & Jerry movie, or some similar kid's flick. Or, rarely, a nature documentary about penguins.

(I know I haven't mentioned the food yet but I'll get to it.)

If the decor causes too much cognitive dissonance and you're sitting by the window, people watching opportunities abound since it's 6th and Mission.

Then you receive your cucumber-infused water and a menu that's beautifully bound and has 80 or so surprisingly cheap dishes.

I enjoy the curry and stir fried dishes, but I've had the clay pot fish before and it was different and still delicious. Huge serving sizes mean you'll leave stuffed, so if you're thinking about going to one of the clubs on 6th street immediately after, it can be a bit heavy (but probably worth it regardless).
author: Alan F.

description: While in a sketchier part of the neighborhood, this was my favorite meal in SF.  My bowl was full of fragrant broth, fresh pork and seafood and quail eggs, and delicious noodles that had soaked up the different flavors.  Our waiter was friendly but a little difficult to communicate with, however, he made sure everything was clear before putting in the order - especially since one member of our group has a food allergy that needed to be carefully avoided.  Additionally, I loved the decorations and music they had for the holiday season.
author: Marianna K.

description: Good service but the food was not what i expected to be. The spring rolls tasted old! Old cabbage. Even the wrap smelled funny. But the interior is pretty decent for it being on 6th street. Also, don't trust the yelp menu, this needs to be updated. Prices went up.
author: Geraldine C.

description: This place has the best pho broth I've ever had at a restaurant. It's full, fatty, and delicious! The banh xeo was crispy and tasty as well. I loved the addition of sautéed shallots to the fish sauce. Great food, and nice decor too!
author: Dan H.

description: Hu Tieu w/ quail eggs. It's comforting!
author: Jeanette Y.

description:
Right smack on 6th Street with the loitering zombie crackheads and HIV health clinic, lies this legit Vietnamese restaurant that is a sure fit in the Inner Richmond. Convenient location for nearby Market workers and Soma dwellers-- a real hot spot for lunch.

The pho is not too shabby. For the purpose of presentation, they plate the sauces. This was a bit weird, as I like to place the sauces in my soup and dip the meats.. but they happily obliged to hand us over the big containers. For a clean environment and a solid lunch, not a bad choice if you're in the area.

BTW- potential usage of MSG.
author: sally y.

description: We stumbled upon this place one night & thanks to the Yelp reviews we gave it a try.  The food was FRESH, AUTHENTIC, FILLING & DELICIOUS! Probably one of the best meals of my life. Even-though it is in an 'interesting' neighborhood the food & service more than make up for what is outside. I will be making a point to visit this place every time I am in SF! Great food!
author: Lindze W.

description:
The food and atmosphere here are both really great. The place is clean and nicely decorated with pastel green colors, flat screen TVs and in general is very soothing and pretty. The pho is also very tasty - they have a lot of variety too and different kinds of dishes. I got #18, the pho with beef balls, for $6.50. 

Only complaint is that the boba drinks they had didn't come in the pretty glasses as shown on the menu.
author: Connie C.

description:
Miss Saigon serves surprising good food for reasonable prices. I've ordered the chicken wings, garlic noodles, & pho, which were all pretty good. However, my favorite item on the menu is the spicy papaya salad -- I can't seem to stray from the dish & consistently order it to eat as my main entree!!

The restaurant is never crowded, which is a little astonishing, considering that it is definitely one of the better restaurants in the area! I guess that's good because it means less of a wait for the locals. :)
author: Ruby H.

description:
this place is awesome because they have the most extensive menu of vietnamese food in san francisco.  pretty much anything that you can think of in vietnamese cuisine is on this menu be it northern, southern, or somewhere in the middle.

get:
any of the salads, my favorite is the lotus root
vermicelli bowls
dessert (omg the white bean dessert is one of the best in SF)

not as great, but still good:
pork chop is really fatty, not enough meat, could be charred or grilled more
catfish soup a little flat in flavor.  too sweet.

service is friendly.  my major gripe about this restaurant is that it's really cold/drafty.  so on rainy days, its not that fun to eat there, even with a steaming bowl of pho.

still, it's a great regular spot for an inexpensive and filling meal.
author: Josie M.

description:
It's hard to write reviews of a place when you've been there twice and ordered the same thing on both occasions. To be trusted as a critic, you probably have to be fair and try everything on the menu. But that's now what Yelp is about. I'm a damn food critic in my own way, I say! And if this restaurant only served the beef and noodle dish that I usually get, then that would still be enough for me to give it 5 stars!

Keep me happy by providing service that's friendly and quick and I'll gladly keep coming back. The location isn't ideal, but that is what's awesome about san francisco - there are little gems everywhere!
author: Lee L.

description: I'm not sure about this one. The service was very...strange. The people who worked here seemed extremely frazzled and were denying customers at the door, saying they ran out of food to serve. Then I mentioned that our party of 5 had reservations (I did not know that we didn't, that this wasn't even a policy of their's to take reservations), another guy just shrugged his shoulders and we started walking in and then saw an empty table and sat down. They didn't serve us for some time, and then apologetically said they don't have any pho or soup anymore, and pointed us to some remaining items on the menu. While I understand that they were under stress, it just seemed a poor way to manage customers (and quite frankly, manage a restaurant). Even though the food turned out to be good (just average, had better), I felt a bit stressed just being there. They made me feel bad for imposing on them and dining at their restaurant!
author: Vanessa X.

description:
Wow, this place is amazingly fantastic!  The neighborhood is kind of sketchy, but once you're inside you forget that.  The place is tastefully decorated with faux clouds on the ceiling to help set the mood.

For lunch,we had summer rolls, beef pho, and vermicelli with egg roll & shredded pork.   The summer rolls were all so yummy.   The egg rolls were tasty without being oily.  Everything was delish.  Add in 2 diet cokes and some hot tea our entire tab was only $20.  Such a deal.

The only strange thing was the music.  Somehow listening to "Edelweiss" in a Vietnamese restaurant just didn't seem right.  But it was pleasant and relaxing.
author: Ed J.

description:
My first review after lurking for years!!!! Has to be - MISS SAIGON!

I love this place! I was brought here a year and a half ago by a co-worker and have been back dozen's of times since. 

Since my gf wants to eat pho five nights a week.... We have tried a ton of places and this is my fav. The food is always good and the guys are the best. I know that some people have had a bad exp here, but it happens. I work in the restaurant business and can tell you that they have a good-to-go spot that is at the top of their game.

The bun is what I get or the shaken beef (yummmmm). The, Goi du du bo, is pretty good as an app.

Try it out, you won't regret it!
author: Jason C.

description: I love to get Pho Thai here, it's amazing the veggies are fresh and the meat is tender, top it off with a Thai Ice Tea and you've got a great lunch that will set you for the rest of the day. The restaurant is clean and the staff is friendly. For the amount of food you get the prices are great, and I'm a frequent visitor.
author: Meg L.

description:
I've been pondering where to pho for a while, ever since I moved out of convenient FiDi and into still convenient but a little further away edge of SOMA/train station to work.  Good places to get pho are difficult away from either GG Park or Little Saigon.

Finally the craving for pho lured me out to Miss SaiGon.

Why Miss SaiGon and not Tu Lan?  I'd never been to either but hubby has had Tu Lan takeout many times and gave me a verbal "meh" review.  So though many people raved about it, I wasn't that tempted.  Then Miss SaiGon showed up in the SF Chronicle's bargain bites and I thought, a new place, why not?

And now my tummy agrees - why not.  

The place itself is not a dive.  It's clean and an attempt has been made to give it a little decor and atmosphere on par with most Vietnamese restaurants in Little Saigon.  Food comes out promptly and it's pretty good.  

It's very good for takeout as they package the broth separately for you so the noodles don't get too soggy.  And even if the noodles get stuck together in your trek back to the office, the hot broth will sort them out in no time.

I only wish they had more 'brisket' cuts of beef for their pho.
author: Jean K.

description: This is a great Vietnamese restaurant! Their Banh Mi Bo Kho tastes sooooo goood! It's better than my mother's! When you order a certain type of soup or stew, they ask you if you'd like rice noodles or egg noodles. I chose egg noodles and it was magnificent! The broth was thick and dark. The meat falls right off the bone and you can tell that the stew has been simmering for SEVERAL hours and the meat just breaks down. Unfortunately, I don't think the cooker stirred the stew before putting it in my bowl because all I got was a few carrots and mostly fat. The meat fell off the bone and must be in the bottom of the pot. I also ordered Ca Phe Sua Da, and like all, or MOST Vietnamese restaurants, they hand it to you with a glass of ice (here, it's a wine glass) and a regular glass with condense milk at the bottom of the glass and the Phin with the Vietnamese/French roasted grinds and hot water. Let it drip, mix it up with the given spoon, and pour it over the ice. So elegant! On top of that, the Cha Gio was nice and crispy. You can tell it just came out of the fryer because of how flaky it was and crispiness. You get 2 with a side of fresh herbs and Nuoc Mam. I am definitely coming back here because the server is cute, friendly, and I think he was flirting with me :D BUT NO STICKY RICE FOR ME LOL
author: Kevin C.

description:
Ok Miss Saigon is totally worth the walk to the TL. While it's not the best I have had, it's certainly pretty good, especially for being in SF. (Better stuff in the southbay imo). The menu is a little tricky I mean there are few dishes that differ by a number however I swear their names and descriptions are the same (38 and 37 I think). You get a big bowl of broth that will definitely fill you up. I want to try their seafood dishes as they smell great, yet my fear of fish dishes at such a place still creeps me out. But my coworkers claim them to be pretty good. I think the crab pho will be going down next. Another good bet is the vermicelli bowls. Those things are huge and you get  a ton of noodles. Overall it's safe bet and I repeatable lunch venue in the area.

I always enjoy watching the strangely awkward karaoke of old music on the TVs in the background. Last time we were here it was the carpenters complete with music video and everything.  Overall it provides a good few minutes of entertainment while waiting for your food.
author: Greg G.

description:
I used to live in Saigon (HCMC) Vietnam and am always looking for a good authentic Vietnamese Restaurant.

This place was really impressive as the food is Fantastic, the restaurant very nice (not like the typical shabby place) and the service very attentive.  The prices are also extremely reasonable and I find myself thinking of this place first if I don't feel like shelling out $$$$ for Ana Mandara.  Five stars for Miss Saigon!!!
author: Mateo D.

description: What a find! Vietnamese food famously gets worse the further you get from San Jose, but this is one of the exceptions up here in the city. I'd love to tell you the whole menu is great but in the four times I've been there I've had a hard time getting past the AMAZING shaken beef!
author: Stephen H.

description: With Tu Lan being just up the block, why go anywhere else? Well, I'm glad I did. Miss Saigon is clean and they take cards! I always get excited when I find a Vietnamese restaurant that accepts credit cards! Their menu caters to a slightly less Asian palate, but still quite good. Their Pho doesn't stand out to me, but it ranks at a safe average. The lunch specials are worth going back for.
author: Helen L.

description: This is my go to for a big bowl of Vietnamese soup and #27 Bun Bo Hue is my poison. We consistently receive prompt and friendly service. I am disappointed that they don't consistently have all boba flavors available.
author: Catalina C.

description:
I've been here twice and both of my experiences have been top-notch! This place is truly a hidden gem because one would never know how beautiful this place is by judging simply by its exterior. If you're in Downtown SF looking for delicious, quality Vietnamese food with outstanding service this is the place to go.

My recommendations are the Shaken Beef with Garlic Noodles. It comes with a salt/pepper lime sauce which goes well with the shaken beef and potatoes.

They also have really great specials which they offer such as the Beef Bowl with Vermicelli Noodle along with a small bowl of soup.

This place is beautifully decorated as well and is mighty clean with 2 or 3 LCD screens hanging on the walls. One time they were playing 90's music videos which my guest and I enjoyed. (teehee!)

A+ for service
A+ for the food
A+ for the decor

The only con about this place is probably the parking even though there is plenty of street parking available. PARK AT YOUR OWN RISK!
author: Sandra P.

description:
This place is alright.... I had better... The people are nice and courteous. Food was served fast and we had great company. Had their beef, noodles, egg wrap, egg rolls, ice coffee and the price is a little too pricey in the financial district.  
The only thing that kills me is the tv. They had cartoon playing in the background and the music was alright.
I would go here again if I am around the area.
author: Valerie A.

description: Wow, haven't had such good pho in a while! I just moved to the city from Europe and will def be coming back!
author: Maciel C.

description:
Came here for a Grubwithus dinner w/ Cathy Y. so we got to sample enough dishes to feed 12 people.  That's really the best way to enjoy this restaurant, because everything was so good, it would be hard to choose just one or two options next time.  

The servers were very nice and attentive.  They refilled my water glass constantly.  Good work.  Don't let the outside fool you.  The neighborhood may be a little unnerving, but the restaurant is a nice haven.  

The food was all very good and very fresh.  The spring rolls were huge, the salad was delicious, the shrimp were huge, the calamari was well done, the chicken curry was drenched in sauce (like I love it), the lemongrass pork was good and fun to assemble, the filet mignon was a surprise to see on the menu and tasty (though not phenomenally tender like it could be), and even the green beans were enjoyable. 

I don't think there was a single dish I didn't like, and most people seemed to agree.  

I'd come back here, but I'd make sure to bring a large group again so I could enjoy a lot of the options and not have to settle for less.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
I've been here once, and I think the reason this receives a five star is because it surpasses my expectations here as my friends and I walked about from Embarcadero Square all the way over to Miss Saigon!

The environment was clean, not like other pho restaurants where the whole place looks janky. We were served water with a slice of cucumber in there, which I found extremely interesting and pretty delicious haha. 

With the food, I ordered Pho Dac Biet, which was great, especially for its price. I believe I paid 7.25 for a bowl that was large enough to make me full (and I'm a big eater). The broth was salty enough and I poured in some yummy sriracha sauce in the process.

My friend ordered a Thai Iced Tea to go along with it and they gave it to him in an interesting cup that was quite tall and skinny. Props for nice decor for a pho restaurant. 

Definitely going here again when I come around the area!
author: Andrew P.

description:
Miss Saigon is nicer than your average Vietnamese restaurant and the people working there are nice. The menu is extensive so you basically have your choice of whatever you want.

I made a mistake in ordering the bun bo hue. In the picture it looked spicy so I asked them about it before ordering. They said it would not be spicy coming out and I could put as much hot sauce in it after that. When they brought it to me, there was a big pile of hot sauce on top. I tried to get as much off as possible, but unfortunately some already got into the soup broth before it got to me. When I took my first sip of soup, it was so spicy I could not stop coughing. They did come over as helped by bringing some regular pho broth to mix in it.  The noodle soup was ok, but nothing special.

It is also in a ghetto area, and is not worth the walk from westfield mall. I would rather stay eat in the food court with many other better choices.
author: Yummy E.

description: Wow! Very pleasantly surprised by the quality of the Pho and cold noodle. I've eaten a lot of Vietnamese food in the past. This is one of the best - good solid food!
author: Kirk T.

description: I had great pad Thai here. For the price I was very impressed. Best fresh spring rolls as well! Atmosphere was alright.
author: Amanda Q.

description:
This place has both Vietnamese and Thai dishes on the menu, and things seem to be priced pretty reasonably.  The pho broth is flavorful and a little peppery, actually.  Their take on the standard Vietnamese vermicelli dishes is all right... Oh, their boba actually has the right consistency and chewiness; I'm a little ashamed to have doubted them.

I'm sad to say though that they don't equip their tables with those nifty utensil caddies we've always come to expect in a pho joint.  What's more, you don't get your own bottles of hoisin and sriracha; you have to ask them to bring it to you in a little sauce dish.  Phooey.

Is it just me, or are the better Vietnamese restaurants in southern California?  (e.g. Golden Deli)
author: Alex C.

description:
Went here because of the high reviews. It's pretty average. Also, It took a while for our food to come out and it was pretty empty. We went in for lunch around 2. 

I got the shaken beef, which I think is similar to other places that have cubed beef. It had good flavour and was the right amount of food. The lunch price is $8.50. 

Still a good choice, but needed to speed up a bit.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Delicious, cheap eats!  That's all I really need to be a fan.  This is not a place to take someone to impress them.  The decor is somewhat tacky; a mannequin standing at the front greets guests (she has a cute haircut).  Service is decent and quick. 

The menu is extensive, which is always a good thing.  I finally decided to order a soup - spicy beef (I believe it was #27 on the menu)!  It was delicious and under $7.  The portion was generous and there was probably enough for me to save some as a tasty snack, but I downed almost all of it.  I'm a growing girl!
author: Jaime L.

description:
I really like this place.  The interior is strange.  There is a modern influence fighting with a quirky, Asian esthetic.  You are greeted by 
a scary mannequin with a "Miss Saigon" banner......as if Miss Saigon herself is there to greet you!  There must be ten TV screens in this place...and they play the most retarded senior citizen sing along concerts from hell I have ever seen in my life!  The food.......Very fresh! Tasty! 
Spicy! Saucy! Delicious!  I like the dinners for two that they have already put together.....  They change often.. They also have YUMMY fruit smoothies with tapioca balls.  The service is not very good....but the food is great tasting, and a good value.
author: Bryan M.

description:
My favorite bún cha gió thit nuóng (vermicelli with pork and rolls) in the area.  The pork comes out sizzling and juicy, rather than kind of sad, dry, and looking like it's been sitting around for a while like other places.

Sure, the mannequin is a little weird, as is the fact that they're always playing a kids' movie on their screens (Barbie princesses, Alice in Wonderland, and some kind of Ariel sequel have accompanied my lunches so far), but despite those quirks, this place definitely has a nicer ambiance than some of the other Vietnamese places in the area.
