On the downside, I haven't had it, but my coworkers say their pho is not as good as nearby Tin and/or Tu Lan.

One of my favorite places in the lunchtime rotation.
author: Allison B.

description:
Good food, clean, bright interior, good prices. My favorite dish (so far) is the "Bo luc lac" (Shaken Beef).

Forget regular Thai Iced Tea -- try the Green Thai Iced Tea. Best thing ever.

The only downside is that it's in a cesspool of a neighborhood.
author: Paul L.

description: Good food but it comes out slow.  They took forever to get our bill too so if you are in a hurry, I suggest another place.  Besides the slowness, everyone was pleased with the food.
author: sonya h.

description:
I was raised in a Vietnamese household, and I will vouch for this place. 

I ordered the banh xeo (Vietnamese pancake), green papaya salad, and canh chua ca (sour/spicy soup?) -- all of which were excellent. I also ordered the bo luc lac (shaking beef), which I liked but seemed a little generic.
author: Jenny O.

description:
Hm. 

Came here with the gf & her friend in from out of town... I liked the food here.. It wasn't incredible, but it was good...

... That said it could have been a buck or two cheaper. Service was pretty good (though they did forget someone in our party of 3's beverage until almost the end). Ambiance/decor was pleasant & nicer than many other Viet restaurants I've been to. They're not open so late but they don't close terribly early either. Clean for the most part (including the restroom). Across the street from two adult XXX stores- funny stuff. 

I think, all in all, I'd eat here again though I wouldn't go so far as to say I'm a fan of the restaurant.

A-OK.
author: Kai S.

description:
I love bean sprouts with my noodles.  I often ask for extra at other places. They obliged and gave me what I wanted. 

The place is clean and quite nice on the inside.  The only problem I found was I ordered the pho xe lua.  The size was not as big as I usually expect when I order the extra large.  The fresh spring rolls were good and the meat were flavorful.  We also ordered a plate of mussels with this sweet powder.  It was just okay for me.  

The soup was real nice, rich, and sweet.  I thought it was quite frugal of them to give out the plum sauce and hot sauce in little plates.  Though it saves a little space on the table, I think I would prefer full control of the amounts of sauce ... also I saw others asking for the bottles.  

Service was good.  But the portions for the pho should have been larger.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Alright lets put the 4 stars into perspective. It's one thing to give a nice place 4 stars because you take into account the ambiance, service, etc. When you give a hole in the wall 4 stars you know they've earned it. 

Have to say the dish that really hit home for me was the beef with garlic noodle. I'm still thinking about that f*cker a week later. I swear to God they put MSG in that sh*t. There's no way I can be this addicted to it without some kind of chemical assistance. 

Anyways, here's the break down:

Food - 5 stars
Service - 5 stars
Ambiance/Decor - 2 stars

Definitely check this place out if you're in the mood for a good hole in the wall with great food. Yes, you'll be punishing your eyes, but what you lose in visual enticement you make up for with culinary excellence..and maybe MSG..
author: Shreya C.

description:
The neighborhood is kind of shady looking but is close to the Federal building and Superior court .  When you walk inside, you are surprised to find a pleasantly decorated restaurant that is nice and clean.  

The bf ordered a lunch special and I hadn't had pho in a while.  The menu is huge with a wide selection of items with photos.  It was disappointing to only find 3 different phos, when they were advertising pho on their awning outside.  I ordered the rare beef with meatballs.  First the broth wasn't hot enough to cook the bean sprouts.  The broth was nice and light, I think a little too diluted though.  The pho or noodles themselves were horrible, which is sad since I love my noodles.  They had a rough texture to it.  The meatballs were the authentic kind with the tendons and stuff in it.  What can I say, I'm an ABC I like it with just the meat.  

The BF wasn't impressed with his lunch either.  The lunch special comes with the soup of the day, which was hot and sour soup Vietnamese style, crab rangoon, and fried rice.  The soup was interesting, not spicy but sour like the Chinese hot and sour soup without the hot.  Anyways, it was OK.  The BF complained that the beef on the menu didn't specify what kind, which was short ribs that day.  He said that it was really fatty.

I don't know what people were talking about cheap.  The prices were decent, but I wouldn't call them cheap.  I guess I'm use to eating in Chinatown where it's cheaper and a lot better.  Granted, they give you a nice big bowl, but it wasn't good enough to want to finish.  Overall, If I was in the area and I needed a place to eat, I might try it again (something different, the boba smoothies looked good) but I wouldn't go there to eat there.  The pho is definitely way better in Chinatown and even the pho place in Ranch 99, which I think is OK  is much better.
author: Judy K.

description: Came here for a quick lunch.  The classic pho was pretty good, though even a large bowl seemed to be pretty small for me.  I also got a banh mi sandwich to go, which was good not great.
author: Josh Q.

description:
Oasis: something serving as a refuge, relief, or pleasant change from what is usual, annoying, difficult, etc. (www.dictionary.com)

After walking through the seedy part of SOMA, I was surprised and relieved to enter Miss SaiGon. The soft colors, warm atmosphere, and light music made it a welcome respite and set a wonderful tone for lunch. Even the menu was physical impressive - seemingly hand-made of rich paper with inlaid leaves and pressed plants, it included small photos of most of the offerings. Prices were quite reasonable, typically $6-9 for soups, noodles, and rice plates. I had a combination lunch special ($10.95) consisting of beef, chicken, shrimp, veggie fried rice, spicy cabbage, an eggroll, and a crab rangoon. It was all very good, though the crab rangoon, eggroll, and friend rice stood out the most. Also of particular note, my excellent Thai iced tea ($2.95) was enormous - filling a large pilsner glass! Staff were friendly and didn't dawdle, and everything was very clean.

It was with a very happy tummy and a reluctant heart that I had to say goodbye to this lush retreat and head back into the wasteland of the neighborhood. It's comforting to know that this beacon of brightness awaits my certain return.
author: Bill B.

description:
I ordered lunch to give it a try, but I think I was expecting more.

When ordering, I meant to order a chicken noodle dish and some seafood pho for my wife.  I ended up accidentally ordering tofu, but realized I made the mistake and figured I'd try their dish out.  The to go box it came it was real measly, where it seriously looked like someone already ate half of the plate.  The flavor though of the tofu was actually really good though, so I give them that.

My wifes pho was alright, have had much better.
author: Robert S.

description: Cheap, good eats before a show at The Warfield or the Orpheum Theater. Friendly service. Weird stuff on the tv, like a Dutch boy band concert...? This will be our go-to for pre-show dinner.
author: Emily B.

description: So this place is pretty awesome. It's in SOMA and on the corner of a fairly sketchy part of town, but the food makes up for that. We came in with a group of about 25 (we reserved first) and most of us are vegetarians. The staff was super accommodating and made sure to do their best to make dishes vegetarian for us, as well as not put onion and garlic. Our food came out pretty fast, and everyone had a really good experience there.
author: Julia H.

description:
I used to live really close to this place, and it was my fix for Vietnamese food.

I had actually never gone here for pho, just some other stuff. The crab rangoon (crab and cream cheese stuffed wontons) were pretty good. The fried eggrolls (they went by a different name here that  i can't remember) were pretty tasty. My usual dish here was the grilled pork over vermicelli noodles. It was pretty damn good.

Now, the few times i was in there,  the television sets were on and playing some pretty horrid music from the 90s. Toni Braxton (when was the last time she was relevant, folks?), Celine Dion, Brandie? Come ON! I'd have given this place 4 stars, but the ambience of reliving the 90s made me cringe and want to cry. Sorry folks! You'd do better to leave those sets off or get rid of them altogether.
author: Phuong M.

description:
I thought about walking away from this place, with my vague sense of dissatisfaction, and just leaving that feeling behind, skip the review, fuck it, there's other places that I feel more strongly about.

Stiff upper lip and all that, don't you know, "walk it off, Johnson," make lemonade, and so forth.

But they've got some issues.  And I just kept thinking about those issues, so had to write a review.  Oh, Yelp, let's you and I work this shit out... together.

Now, don't get me wrong, it ain't all problems--these folks have put together a clean and attractive place to eat.  The big windows fill the space with clean light, the glossy dark wood tables are attractive--it really does feel like you've stumbled through a wardrobe into a much better place than where you were before (i.e. shoving your way through crackheads, drug-dealers, and babbling psychotics).

Oh!  Their coffee was excellent.  And they do the condensed milk in a glass with the coffee dripping into it from the little suspended pot.  I fucking love that, and they are the only place I've been other than http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-84-oakland who does it.

I had a bit of three different items.  Their chicken salad was just fine--nothing spectacular, just shredded cabbage and carrots and bean sprouts and some chicken in a thin, sweet sauce.  Haven't ever had bad chicken salad in a SE Asian joint, I don't think (the one at http://www.yelp.com/biz/phnom-penh-house-oakland-3#hrid:TGw0Re5m8c3LHn7PQ89DFQ/src:search/query:phnom%20phen is in a class of its own in awesomeness, however).

My lunch date, Jane C., got what I would have assumed was pho, except for the big, fat noodles they used.  They were indeed rice noodles, but they looked like fat spaghetti--not udon-size, but opaque, white noodles.  No translucency, no gloss, nothing like the usual glass-like vermicellli.  Maybe I'm just culturally retarded and Vietnamese connoisseurs are all about the fat noodles, but to me, that's "incorrect."  And the broth... weak.  Salty enough, but a real pho broth is complex--we're talking 20 pound ox bones simmered for two days complex, like over at http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-anh-dao-oakland.  This could very well have been derived from boullion, and I *know* that's not traditional.

And finally, this might seem like nit-picking, but we got the banana cake.

Now, looking at the banana cake's photo on the menu, you see a very attractive, two-layer slice of cake, probably made of two cake rounds of angel food with a browned, glossy filling spread across the top and between the layers--and the spread has clearly defined slices of banana in it.  We weren't sure what to expect, after all it could just be angel food cake with some banana shit smeared on it, or there could be some kind of flavor marriage that would make us cream in our jeans, but that's what experimentation is all about, right?  It looked great, is the point.

When the "cake" came out, however, it was this round, flat little brown and grey splatter of a confection.  I mean, it tasted okay (like sweetened and baked banana), but what made this a cake?  It was a baked smear!  Your food's gotta at least *resemble* the menu, I mean, come on.

There were some other disappointments (what was that shredded brown stuff with the soup?  my vote was oxidized radish--bleah), but you get the picture.

Really, I think this was a two-star meal, but I've heard fair-to-good reviews from friends about this place, including from Jane C herself, and I'm open to visiting again--maybe a basic meat + rice dish will move them into my good graces.  I'd much rather give four stars than three--but this was not a great experience.
author: Martin W.

description: Fantastically delicious and authentic! And a great price on the Bánh Mì sandwiches, too... only $4 for take-away, $5 for dine-in at the time of this writing. If I lived here I'd be visiting often!
author: Joseph L.

description: The pho is phenomenal, the service is not.  Crazy lunch rush but the waiter managed to forget HALF our orders.  Literally 5 people out of 11 didn't get their lunch.  They were too busy to notice and had a very sincere "oh shit" moment when we let them know.  Guessing I'll be back because I work just around the corner and the food was great, just hope they can rebound on the service.
author: Rich L.

description:
I went to Miss SaiGon without checking their yelp rating, so I was incredibly nervous until our appetizer arrived. 
I'm a sucker for a lot of things -  carnival food, poodle mixes, Victorian love stories, clearance sales - but I'm an exceptional sucker for cream cheese rangoons (wontons). Miss SaiGon has some rad rangoons. They're just the right blend of crunchy, creamy, and salty. 
We ordered a delicious entree. It was some sort of beef, noodle, garlic combination, and it was great. We also took a gamble on a beer called Tiger, which turned out to be a good choice. 
The waiters were attentive, and a VERY friendly mannequin greeted us at the door. 
It was a great place to stumble into.
author: Chanti B.

description: Fast service, close to the office, and the filet mignon pho is amazing!
author: Labs P.

description:
I dropped by Miss Saigon for an early Sunday dinner with a novel to keep me company. I had the #3 dinner special, deep fried jumbo prawns with garlic noodles. The prawns were terrific, with crunchy, flavorful batter that went well with the garlic salt and lemon juice dipping sauce. The noodles were buttery and pretty good, though they didn't have the garlic bite of noodles from my usual noodle favorite, Perilla. Also, the portion size was a bit smaller than Perilla's pile of noodles, but I suppose I'm spoiled by their largesse.

The dish plus hot tea (teapot of Jasmine for $1) came to ~$20 - spendy given the neighborhood, but reasonable given the quality of my meal. Service was attentive and pleasant. My dinner had a somewhat surreal feel to it, given the background music was provided by a televised multicultural variety show, and the fact that I was reading a William Gibson book. I suppose Gibson would harangue me about not going to Tu Lan and immersing myself in its grimy zeitgeist, but bite me Bill: Tu Lan is closed on Sundays. Besides, sometimes it's nice to have an upscale alternative to my neighborhood's usual suspects. As the Governator says, 'I'll be back'.
author: Mark W.

description:
***DON'T COME HERE FOR PHO***
Yes this place is clean.  Yes the pricing is... OK.  Yes they have a cutesy, scrapbook-like menu.  But if you're here for Pho, then you're in the wrong place, my fellow yelpers.  I thought I would take a shortcut to Clement St. by having "4-star" Pho in SoMA.  And boy was I wrong.  Hell, this place even serves Pad Thai.  What self-respecting Pho place serves Pad Thai?  Pho nubs, knock yourselves out.  

To ensure this isn't just some random rant, please allow me to present the facts to why this place isn't a good Pho place as follows:

- Broth was... light... and lacking in flavor. 
- The menu was missing some key Pho ingredients, like tripe, fatty flank, etc.  They only had "medium rare beef" and "beef balls" as beef options.  WTF?!
- The "medium rare beef" that I ordered came well done
- They didn't have the bottles of hoisin and hot sauce ready at the table.  

While I find their Pho less than satisfactory, I do have to say that the service was excellent.  The water with a slice of cucumber in it was a nice touch.  If you're not from these parts and are curious about "exotic Asian flavors", this place is fine.  While you're at it, checkout our women-folk, too.
author: Leo C.

description:
Must say I know very little about Vietnamese food..but I am adventurous! With that said I met with Sister Selma Soul for an early 6 pm dinner. My spicy cabbage super duper good & my veggie soup with noodles enough to feed a family & most definately the food fare needed to fend of my cold bones for my day of city swaggering about town. I highly recommend Vientemese beer import ___ 33. It was a good beer. Service from Kory and Miguel excellent. I even shared some of my Panera coookie.  

Good eats, good price & great companion with my new friend who is way cool from Mocas Group.  

The only reason I cant give more stars is the really really scary location (maybe becoz it was dark) & quite possibly one of the raunchiest intersections in SF. If you get my drift...google earth it for entertainment value & live vicarously pr go in daylight..& safety in numbers
author: Bryan G. W.

description: Service is lacking and consists of a lot of waiting. There is no reason to be waiting 15+ mins for a check while there are only 3 tables including us and the 3 waiters are just standing there, staring off into space.
author: Cori W.

description:
I'd been dying to try Pho for a while now and just never got around to it in Chicago -- I'm staying in San Francisco for the weekend/beginning of the week for work and happened upon this place -- all I have to say is that it's amazing.

First off it's clean - immaculate -- which is key for me.  The service was prompt and welcoming and the food was absolutely amazing.  I had the shrimp spring rolls, the beef Pho and a glass of the pinot noir -- what a perfect way to end my crazy day of holiday shopping in Union Square.  I'm sure I'll even be back before I leave in a few days.  

Honestly, the portions are HUGE so either come with a big appetite or be prepared to leave with leftovers.  Unfortunately I'm staying in a hotel so I couldn't leave with mine.  I'm already thinking about my next meal there it was so good.  Yum! I'm a fan of Pho for life now!
author: Melissa K.

description: We mostly do carryout from Miss Saigon because we live close by, and it's a quick and consistently good, reasonably priced dinner.  We recommend the papaya salad with pork and shrimp and the shrimp/pork spring rolls in rice paper wraps - delicious  and fresh!  Also recommend any of the vermicelli noodle dishes. Good food and good value!
author: Barbara R.

description:
average at best, but it was an okay time.

highlight of the night was that they were playing the new tinkerbell movie on the wall mounted LCD.

all the dishes were very heavily peppered.
author: Ameer N.

description:
This cute little restaurant is a refreshing spot in a horribly shady neighborhood. If you can muster up the strength to come from beyond the civic center hood I think you'll find the trip is worth it. Thankfully for me, I already work in this hell hole so it's easy for me to jump down the street to this lunch spot. 

Tofu dishes were good and I appreciate being offered brown rice. I'll update the review as I will most likely make this my lunch spot. There aren't many choices in this neighborhood so I foresee an intimate daytime affair with Miss Saigon in my near future.
author: Tyler J.

description: A pleasant surprise in a not so pleasant neighborhood. I've been here several times and the food and service are always consistently good. I'm really happy with their pho, their curries, and their noodle salads (with rolls). It's a nice space usually filled with cheesy music that seems to enhance the experience. Well done, Miss Saigon. Well done.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
You must get the Shaken Beef with garlic noodles. You can also feel good about yourself because you are supporting a small, family-owned business! 

Perfect for lunch when you're in a rush but want to savor something delicious and filling.
author: Christina C.

description:
Hands down best Pho in the area. I can't eat Pho anywhere other than here now. I've been spoiled by this place, and frankly nothing compares. I wish they had hard liquor here, but hey - it's SOMA, I could just cross the street. 

We live in Hayward, and will make the trek out to The City just to go here.
author: Ward A.

description:
Miss Saigon is a good standard vietnamese place. The plates are good, they don't take too long to make (though I did have a significant delay with the lunch special one time). The food is plentiful and the servers are nice.

Gotta say the thing that makes this place is the young coconut juice. At first you're wondering, $3 for coconut juice, god damn't, I can get it a whole can for $1! WAIT! YOU GET AN ACTUAL COCONUT. Like a nice ripened coconut, they'll cut open the top so you can drink the delicious delicious juices. Then you can ask them to cut it open to get the sweet inner pulp of the coconut. I would go here just for this.
author: Rohan D.

description: Food was tasty.  The fruit smoothie also hit the spot.  We were there around 1pm and they ran out of a couple things we asked for but I'm still pleased nonetheless.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Amazingly clean, considering the neighborhood, spacious and 
modern deco. 

Food was average while portion is generous. Was there for lunch.

Service was slow, unfortunately. I go there just for convenience.
I might come back again as not many clean restaurants in the area.
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
My husband and I drove up to San Fran for a quick getaway a couple weeks ago and had lunch here.  We had a hankerin' for some vermicelli and decided on this place based on the rave reviews and its proximity to our sleeping quarters in the dodgy end of SoMa.  Don't be intimidated by the crazies, just fix your eyes on the door and walk on in. 

Superb experience, all the way around - friendly and efficient service, delicious food (oh my, the broth...) and a good price for lunch.  We will be back next time we visit SF, even if we move up in accommodations...
author: Susan K.

description:
Ok, so this is a "catching up" review. I've here twice now and both times (once for diner, once for lunch) were really good. Service is fast and the staff is friendly. Prices are really good. 

As for the food, it's also really good. I had soups both times and the broth was nice. Not salty, not greasy. Really hit the spot. 

The reason for the three stars (and i really struggled between 3 and 4 stars) is because I had order the hot and spicy beef soup and it was not anywhere (not even close) to spicy. It was still really, really good, but not what I had expected. 

The location is a little sketchy. I don't think I'll be going back for diner again, at least not until daylight saving changes and it stays light out until 8:00. 

If you're ever in the area (corner of 6th and Mission), you should certainly stop by.
author: Khim Y.

description:
So I yelped for good asian food in SOMA, this part seems to be a little sketchy and nearing the Tenderloin, which I didn't realize. Anyhow, this place has REALLY good service and VERY good food, also value for money; huge portions for the amount that we paid. 

It was my friend's bday dinner and they were very accommodating, let us stay past their closing time and were very helpful in explaining the dishes. They also have a huge variety of dishes, not just your typical pho or bun thit nuong (rice vermicelli) or spring rolls. They have banh xeo (vietnamese pancake), which is really yummy. My friend had the crab noodles (bun rieu) which she liked, I liked my beef stew noodles (mi bo kho).
author: Clarissa L.

description: This is my go-to place for pho in the area. And everyone else's considering how crowded it gets during lunch hours, especially on those colder days when soup just sounds amazing. I have tried their rice dishes and other noodle soups and those are all mediocre. I really would not recommend anything else other than the pho. It is well-balanced and rich in flavors and they do not skimp on the noodles, meat, or the extras (basil, beansprouts, etc.). Their only downfall is that their service is incredibly slow, even when the restaurant is not busy.
author: Brittany L.

description:
We went here because I wanted Vietnamese food, and the SO decided against Tu Lan, because he says that when he's there, he feels like he's just getting fed, rather than eating out.  For a place that serves pho, it's pretty nice, even though the mannequin near the entrance is kind of creepy.  Service was a little slow at first, because we had to wait nearly twenty minutes to order, but it gradually became more attentive.  

We started out with deep-fried vegetarian spring rolls, which were tasty and perfectly crisp without being overly greasy.  He ordered the prawns in chili paste sauce, which looked amaaaaazing, and he seemed extremely happy with his order.  I got the beef stew, which was pretty tasty. The soup was a little thin compared to other places, and although most of the beef was tender, there were a couple pieces that were pretty tough.  I'm kind of torn between 3 and 4 stars, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.  Given that the SO lives only a couple blocks away, I'm sure we'll be back here soon.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Please don't judge this spot simply because it's in the hood.  My coworkers and I came here for lunch after reading about the place on Yelp. We walked from 3rd and Mission. We walked and walked... and the more we walked the more ghetto it got...  Finally after dodging cat call after panhandler, we arrived at Miss SaiGon. WOW. Super classy spot!!  Beautiful high ceilings, nice seating area, clean floors, flat screen tvs, & a bar. We're greeted by 3 people who immediately seat us and bring us water with cucumber. Woo! The tables are SUPER clean and not sticky with bits of green onion or noodle left behind from the previous diners. *gag* We ordered spring rolls, chicken skewers (my personal favorite), and the vietnamese pancake as our appetizers and we proceed to order our individual entrees. I had the Pho Tai Bo Vien. Super yum!! Strawberry smoothie was delicious too. 

The service was something I would never expect from a Vietnamese restaurant at the price it was at. Water always filled. Smiles galore. Yummy food and nice menu selection with pictures! Very cute. 

If I'm in the area again, I plan to come back!
author: Rie P.

description:
I tried ordering different pho dishes 3 times at this place, and each time i was greatly disappointed by the lack of taste and authenticity.
if you are looking for a pho, this restaurant is not the place.

Service was good though.. 
giving 2 stars.
author: DImitry G.

description:
Do not get their pho. It tastes like shit. Wait, let me rephrase that. It tastes like sugary shit. Miss Saigon needs to get her ass back in the kitchen and learn how to make some proper beef pho broth. 

The bf and I were dying for pho and this place has 4 stars (330+ reviews) so we figured it must be good. Ugh. Has Yelp ever steered me wrong. I should've known it'd be bad once I stepped inside and there was only one other Asian person eating.

Got the #20 combo beef pho ($7.95). It came with two small meatballs cut into three pieces each. Don't try and trick me by giving me more pieces! I'm not stupid! The meatballs were already tiny so cutting them into three made them suppppper small. Not very good either. Lacking in flavor, needed pepper and were just plain bad. Rare steak was not rare. It was dry, hard, overly cooked and disgusting. Brisket was OK. That's a combo? Meatballs, shitty steak and brisket? What a ripoff. Now onto the broth. At first sip I thought ok, they get a 2. Then the more I ate, the more disgusting it got. The broth had no depth, no beef flavor, bland and not savory, rich and buttery at all. On top of that, they was way too much rock sugar and after a few bites, you feel like you're drinking sugar water. The bf and I are fattie ass pigs and we almost never waste food but after eating one fourth of our bowls we said "Fuck this.", paid and left. 

Side note: The mannequin in the ao dai is fucking terrifying. Why did they put her by the front door?!?!!
author: Beverly T.

description: Wait staff lacks attention to customers needs, drink took forever and had to remind them 3 times to learned that they ran out.  My #28, beef stew noodle was bland as hell.  The bill came and waiter charge extra for tofu on my co-worker's noodle which already has tofu.  The waiter tried to ignore us until we flagged him down again and question the extra charge on the bill.  He realized that he screwed up and took the extra charges off our bill.  The table next to us had the same thing happened to them.  If you plan to go there, make sure you check your bill to make sure they are not charging you for something that is already part of the order.  Overall, BLAH!
author: Jan S.

description:
Not the most authentic Vietnamese place in town but what are you going to do, not everybody likes authentic. I can appreciate authentic and not individually. This place makes tasty food at a reasonable price. I came to have a meal with a friend and we shared two dishes. We had the shaken beef and then sea food in a clay pot. Both dishes were obviously made with quality ingredients and I did not have much trouble getting help when I needed it. I did find it a little strange that it was completely empty other then us and two other tables (its a pretty big place). I am sure the service might not be as speedy on a saturday lets say.

Finally, I was a little offended that after ordering the regular shaken beef plate, the waiter tried to up-sell me on the one which is made with filet. I think his assumption was that we were on a date and I would look bad to refuse this ridiculously expensive dandy brother of the dish that I freaking asked for by name and number. I got the impression this is the sort of waiter that would point to the most expensive item on the menu if you ask for a recommendation and that just sucks.
author: Eric G.

description: Awesome place, great food, very tasty and hearty, huge portions. excellent value for your money and is very cheap! Waiters are nice, very good service. Its just Perfection!
author: Erik P.

description:
I have to say, this place is adorable. I had a great time sitting there dining with friends.

The food however, was not terribly impressive. We had chicken wings, spring and summer rolls for appetizers, all of which were well-presented but bland. My pho was also boring until I dumped a lot of chili sauce in it. Also, whatever you do, don't get the tapioca drinks. The tapioca balls come frozen and they use condensed milk.

Overall, I've simply had better Vietnamese food in various other places in San Francisco. Granted, for that area, this is probably the best place to go.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Came on a Sunday night about an hour before closing. Ordered pho. As others have noted, the soup was delicious. However I was expecting the beef slices to be brought out raw, so that it cooks in the soup but the meat that came with the soup seemed to be cooked well done already so it wasn't that tender.

Otherwise the service was friendly and prompt. Just try to avoid the colorful locals off 6th street...
author: Michael C.

description:
Oh how I love Miss SaiGon! The staff is friendly and the prices are right. And when I call to order stuff to go they remember what I eat... (maybe that is a sign that I shouldn't go so often)! 

Yes sometimes the meat is a little questionable but what can you expect when you are paying under $10 for entrees. A few of my favorites from the menu: 
-Papaya salad with fried tofu 
-Spring rolls 
- Vermicelli noodles with grilled pork and egg rolls 
-Crispy noodles topped with shrimp, chicken, beef and vegetables 
-Spicy pork and beef soup 

If you are in the 6th and Mission St area stop by! You will be surprised by how clean this place is. :)
author: Miranda R.

description: Mid-range priced and really good! I've been looking for a standard pho place and I've found it! I went with a friend and we got beers, an order of spring rolls, and two bowls of pho and paid $17 each including tip.
author: Lara O.

description:
I like big buhns and I cannot lie!

One my favorite places to get hot pho or a delicious buhn in the entire Bay Area. Buhn toppings are ample & super fresh. The service is friendly, attentive, and the prices are right. Take note: The 'hood... It is really important that we support businesses in the 6th St. Corridor, so do not concern yourself too much with being distracted by the people hanging out on the streets -- likely not going to be an issue, but it is definitely a rougher spot in the City. This place is worth the trek to the wild(er)-side. :)
author: Jasmine W.

description:
Went here for lunch with co-workers and enjoyed it.  The food is inexpensive, pretty good, and the portions are big.  They also have a huge menu so the odds you won't find something you like are slim.

The atmosphere is nice - clean, relatively quiet, and bright.

The service was pretty quick, everyone got their meals at the same time, and no one had any problems with what they ordered.
author: Ben B.

description: Pretty good food, beef cubes was good,  crappy music.
author: Michael E.

description:
Stumbled across Market in search of Sunday brunch, a terrible hangover clinging to my head. (I drank a bottle of wine the night before -- and I don't drink wine.)

I'm not a SF native but a huge, huge Vietnamese food nut. Amongst the throngs of homeless and street cretins, I saw Miss SaiGon. 

Hoping to not be mugged inside, I found a cozy, casual atmo.  

Had the Bun special and a Tiger 33.  I believe it was the beef bun.  

Having had a billion buns in my short life, I was impressed with Miss SaiGon's offering.  Cooked perfectly, sizable portion and was offered an extra helping of the vinegary-sugary sauce -- something that's never happened in my zillion times eating Vietnamese.  

I would happily eat there again.  Really want to try their Pho -- a true test of a Vietnamese kitchen.
author: Steve K.

description: So far everything was good, except the thai tea was TOO sweet. The #1, you all know what im talking about, the broth was also really sweet! but its a good thing for broth. Spring rolls were fresh with tender rice wraps. Chicken salad was spot on with the right amount of ingredients. the service was great too even though we went during the rush hour of lunch. She took our order while we were waiting to be seated because she saw us looking at the menu. It was nice to have food come out when we sat down :]
author: kim w.

description: Solid lunch option for a quick sit-down menu that I've been to several times. Since it's summer, my go-to dish is #28 - vermicelli with grilled pork and a spring roll. They don't skimp on the pork, and mix in a lot of fresh vegetables (carrots, cucumbers, and bean sprouts). It's also clean and the staff is courteous.
author: Wing Y.

description:
+1 Yummy for my tummy.
+1 Friendly waiter.
+1 Pretty interior decorations (although some may beg to differ).
+1 Affordable.
+1 It's clean!

What more can you ask for? Oh right, free food.
author: Stacey T.

description: Been here 3 times now; first was to get some "quick" Bahn Mi, but it ended up taking quite some time so I wouldn't recommend coming here to get fast takeout. However the other 2 times more than made up for it with the delicious Prawn Garlic Noodle which was a lunch special both times (served with soup and crap rangoons). Best garlic noodles I've had in the city so far!
author: Anthony P.

description: Went here on a Friday.  Inside the restaurant is very nice.  Very clean.  The service is also very good.  They refilled my water more than once and was always checking on us every few minutes.  I had ordered shrimp with egg noodles and it was very good as well.  My favorite was the spring rolls.  It is the best spring rolls that I ever had in any Vietnamese restaurant.  If I am in the area again.  I will definitely eat there.  It is worth checking out if you are in the area.  In terms of parking there is a cheap parking lot I think it is either $10.00 a day or $15.00 a day.  But you can get here on BART and exit on Powell Street, and it should be like about 2 blocks away, pretty close to the Westfield mall in the city.
author: Alice T.

description:
In SOMA near Yerba Buena Gardens Vietnamese restaurants are hard to find. So to find one that is decently priced, pretty good tasting and not located in Mission...awesome!

The only things I've gotten on their menu are soup based.  The beef stew I got last time was pretty frickin amazing.  That itself upped my review by one star.  Oh a hint would be to stay away from anything that says quail eggs because when I bit into one I had in mine it definitely did not taste right...yuck.

This is a perfect place to go grab a bowl of noodle stew/soup and watch the characters of SOMA shuffle by.  Also take a look up at the ceiling above the bar area...I think the next time a major rainstorm comes through they might get a bit of a soaking.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Best Pho in SF and i've hit up a lot of the spots in Little Saigon, Miss Saigon takes the cake. Always consistent and the staff is super friendly. Their Pho Dac Biet kills it with flank and brisket. Their Pho Ga isn't as good, but when you want to switch it up to chicken its there. They have an unusual Filet mignon Pho, which while not as good as the combo beef, is unique and worth trying. Had the clay pot fish their once and it was amazing, but my fix is the Pho Dac Biet just about every time. The corner of 6th & mision might be one of the worst in the city, but hey...nothing good comes easy right? Brave it out and thank me later.
author: Adrian S.

description:
has gotten progressively stingier with portions as they have grown.

in general, the meats are on the sweeter side for vietnamese cuisine.  for example, their fried shrimp had a "secret" or "special" sauce...which seemed like sugar water.  not bad at first, but harder to eat as you go on.

used to really dig their pork, cause they had a variation in the pork they gave you (like the pork vermicelli), but now it's just one type.  

coconut smoothie - they don't give you the leftover coconut juice anymore.

well the staff is friendly & nice.  but sometimes it's just two people serving the entire restaurant, so it can get pretty slow.

a good option if it's convenient, but wouldn't go out of my way anymore to go here.
author: Jeffry C.

description:
Five stars because their Dau que xao nam is to die for. The green beans are perfect, not wilty like every other god damn place. Their veggie dishes are consistently interesting, and fully flavored without being sauce heavy. And the price is right, cheap. 

Bonus, they have brown rice available. So I can opt for something other than white starch madness. 

They are always nice on the phone. I've never *been* there, just enjoyed take-out picked up by someone else.
author: Helena L.

description:
I just went there for lunch today. Right on the corner of 6th & Mission, it is definetly in the hood!
I was pleasantly surprise at how clean the place is... But of course it is new!!! 
I had the golden tofu and stir fry veggies on yellow curry and it was delicious. 
My friend has the Lemongrass Pork and although she thought it had some fat in it, I really loved it! 
THe imperial rolls were hot and fresh!
THe price was very affordable. 
THe paintings are so so cheasy, but beautifully made in their cheasiness. Hey, bad but original art trumps fake... Well, maybe. 
Come here and often. The service was nice and speedy!
author: Cristina R.

description:
Very nice and clean Vietnamese restaurant.  Although I like the grimey business model of Pho restuarants, this is a nice change.

The Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong I had was excellent.  The meat was very very lean and I had the most productive shit of my life after.  I know, TMI, but I just had to mention what was memorable.
author: Joey S.

description:
So .... I really didn't want to eat here because the neighborhood was pretty sketchy.  We were staying in SoMa, it was close by and we love good Vietnamese food.  Ended up we were pleasantly surprised.  And you can't beat the prices for all the food you get.

Great pho.  Loved the pancake appetizer.  Good shrimp spring rolls.  Would skip the spicy chicken sandwich.  It was too spicy to enjoy.

If I'm in the neighborhood again, I'll definitely eat here.
author: Lori S.

description: The food is a 3, but the decor bumped it up to a 4!  Miss Saigon is clean and has a look of its own. The food here was good.  I got the pho- nothing bad but nothing fantastic.  It looks like they have a variety of food including hot dishes.  The prices are definitely really a bargain.  I loved the tall glasses of Thai iced tea too! I just wish they had a long straw to go with the tall drink, since half the time my straw was drowning in my drink.
author: Nadiyah S.

description: Bánh mì chay aside, I'm not much a fan of Vietnamese food. This place, though--even with its Arsenic & Old Lace décor and sketchy location--was FANTASTIC. I've added it to my regular rotation.
author: Brian W.

description: Damn this place is solid. Of course its in a seedy area. But the inside is very peaceful and they were playing calming classical music when I was there. Was pretty mellow for a Saturday at 8. The pho was really tasty. They use thinner noodles than most places and their 17b filet mignon pho  was a better meat than the typical rare steak. The first thing I noticed is they put a good amount of onions and herbs (I'm food retarded so I'm not sure what kinds they are). The broth is excellent and everything just works well together. Highly recommend this spot! Got myself some Tiger beer too for the first time. Good stuff!
author: Shane W.

description:
Ordered the combo beef pho. It was excellent AND different. Pho is mostly in the broth - this one was not greasy, and they put a twist on the classic taste by adding lots of shallots. There was also a citrusy flavor, like of orange peel. 'Twas delicious.

Thing I couldn't get over, however, which brought me down to 3-stars was the ambiance. The restaurant was blasting super cheesy '80s music and playing the original Terminator movie. Plus what's with the mannequin holding a menu?
author: Richard Z.

description:
I've been here about three times, each in a large group, its a good place if you're looking to get a lunch reservation in a really large group, and has this weird habit of going from completely empty to totally packed in 15 minutes. Also, they play absolutely random stuff on the TV, from disney cartoons to the world cup to flyover scenery, not that I really mind.

I like the shaken beef, I tried the spring rolls once but they weren't really to my taste, but overall the food's good, and the cucumber water's a nice touch,
author: Abhinav S.

description:
I've been going to this place in the past 5 months and I'm never disappointed. They serve the best, most flavorful pho I've ever tried. 
The waiters are always nice, they have big portions and they are also cheaper than another (less impressive) Vietnamese restaurant 1 block away.

The only reason I give it 4 stars is because of the music they play from their stereos. Mostly very melancholic, movie-song covers, during which you also get to watch movies like KungFu Panda, Ice Age, and Kleopatra. What's up with that? I can't get over it....

Otherwise, the food is really good!
author: Gyöngyi G.

description:
Lucky for me I have been staying with a girlfriend who lives down the street from this restaurant.  The service is very friendly and the place is quite clean.  The food is pretty good.  I've had the Bun Bo Hue (Spicy Beef Noodles), Papaya Salad, Spring Rolls and Pho.. So far I've enjoyed all except for the Spring Rolls (which is very easy to make).

Price is also reasonable for food in SF.. Enjoyed it and would definitely recommend.
author: Thi N.

description:
This review is based on my lunch time experience.  My favorite thing here is the grilled lemongrass pork (you can get it with rice or over noodles in bun).  Marinated with the perfect balance of flavors and grilled to perfection, it is currently my favorite piece of meat.  I would choose it over sex with the other other white meat, Brad Pitt, it's that good.  I wonder what that says about me though...

The eggrolls are chunky and quite delicious.  So is the Bo luc lac (or the Shaking beef).  I have had the pho here - the broth is average and overall, I found it a bit gentrified with no tendon or tripe or any other parts of the cow that would frighten my white mother-in-law.  If I want pho in the area, I would probably go to Pho Ha Tien 2 but for bun or rice dishes, Miss Saigon is my new favorite.  All noodles dishes are priced around $6-7, quite reasonable considering that this place is cleaner and nicer than your typical pho joints.  

I guess the down side to the "upscale" nature of the place is that I had pay for tea and I had to ask for sriracha.  They brought me a teaspoon of it (sriracha, not the tea) in a dipping bowl.  Next time, I'm bringing my own.  Anyway, I had been meaning to crochet a sriracha bottle cover so I can carry it in my purse at all times.  You never know when you're going to need some hot sauce.
author: mia s.

description:
A colleague recommended this place, and I'm so glad I went!  The service and ambiance was superb, and the food absolutely delicious.

The server was more than happy to leave the prawns out of the dish, as requested - and he adjusted the bill accordingly.

Highlight:  authentic Vietnamese coffee.
author: Craig L.

description:
Recommended by friends and duly so.

Quick and courteous service, large menu with helpful photos, good-sized portions and reasonable prices make this a great casual restaurant. I will definitely be coming again!
author: Ryan G.

description: My sister and I had lunch here today -- it was great!  We shared spring rolls and lotus root salad, then each had a bowl of pho. It was all fresh and very good. We shared sticky rice with taro for dessert, something completely new for me, and I really enjoyed it.  Service was attentive without being intrusive. I am visiting from out of town, and we had a lot to talk about. The lunch crowd had left, so the wait staff cleared our empty dishes, refilled our teapot, and let us talk. Sweet hospitality - we appreciated it.
author: Ann W.

description:
I only go here because AllSTAR (at mission and 9th) is freaking closed all the freaking time. AllSTAR has better pho, no contest.

But... I have to admit Miss SaiGon has grown on me. They have what basically every other TL/SoMa pho place lacks: some kind of atmosphere. It's all clean and stuff. And there's a little waterfall when you walk in. The TVs that constantly play that stupid penguin surfing movie (like penguins could surf, whatever,) I could do without, but at least they keep them muted and play nice music. Sort of melancholy music. I've heard Moon River like 4 times there.

I like Miss SaiGon. You should go there. Especially before a movie, with a date who you don't really want to spend a lot of money on.

Update: I added a star. Miss Saigon has really grown on me.

Updated again: I've been going here frequently for a year now and these guys are awesome. They're always super friendly and sometimes randomly give us free desserts. I want to add one more star, but honestly I get the same thing every time I go there (rare beef pho and a Tiger) so I can't really tell you if the whole menu lives up. But for the combination of price and neighborhood, this is definitely some of the best food, atmosphere and service you're gonna get.
author: Thea K.

description:
A very airy, welcoming restaurant in a not-so-nice neighborhood, Miss SaiGon was the perfect place to while away a long lunch on a rainy afternoon. The pho was perfect. As everyone knows, the broth is the secret to good pho. It should be so good that you could have it by itself. And after I ate the noodles and beef, that's exactly what I did!

The staff was beyond friendly and gracious and...they were playing Michael Jackson's Moonwalker on their TVs!
author: Julia D.

description:
Not a bad place.  I was down in this area because my friends and I were about to watch Wicked and we needed to get some food first.  Rena Y. recommended coming down to this spot because most places weren't open on Easter Sunday.

Walked in and it was surprisingly clean and bright compared to most Vietnamese restaurants.  My friends were pretty much the only ones there and we were pretty much ready to order.  I think the person misunderstood us and didn't take our order, but instead he walked away for about 10 min.  It was kinda weird.  

Food came out and it was good.  Nothing super special.  I think this place has potential to really stand out but I wouldn't come out of my way to come to this joint.

A-OK.
author: Tom Y.

description: Substandard Vietnamese offerings. I had the overcooked bun dish which was a bit sour . Chicken wings are very hard to botch but  this place managed to do so.
author: aj s.

description: Great food, friendly service at very reasonabke prices.  Plus 10-15 minute walk to/from the Theatre.  Perfect!
author: Mais S.

description:
Stopped in here for dinner last night. Definitely a safe haven from the derelict surroundings of 6th, and  just what you expect it to be, cheap, solid and delicious Vietnamese.

The owners have clearly put in a bit of effort in this place, (ok, so they couldn't resist the tacky chairs and mannequin at the entrance who I actually, genuinely no kidding-- thought was real from the outside) but its a cute set up, with plants and pictures and cartoons playing in the background and they've stuck little dried leaves and flowers in their plastic menus which I think is just so adorable. (Oh and the menu also has photos which ALWAYS help!)

Our server was super attentive, friendly and we were always topped up with their cucumber water. We ordered fried rice, (wasn't feeling like pho) and stir fried green bean and egg. The rice was perfect, tasty, not too oily and good chunks of beef through it. The green bean-- delicious and I thought my mum's was good! To top it off, I asked for some chilly and low and behold our server brings out 3 different kinds of chilli-- now THAT'S what I call good service!

Overall, super impressed, both meals were under $10 and even cheaper of you are here for lunch. Will definitely be back soon and try yummy Viet desserts!
author: Shahirah I.

description:
Living with my roommate Steve also means I essentially live with his Vietnamese girlfriend. But that is totally cool because she is a great cook and both are very generous. 

So being Vietnamese she makes pho with homemade stock once in a while and GOOD GOD I LOVE IT! But seeing as she makes it like once every 4-5 months, I'm started on a mission to find decent and cheap pho places. 

And so it begins with Miss Saigon. Introduced to me by my co-workers (Hi Greg!) at exactly the wrong time (on a diet + 3 days before payday = no going out if I can help it), I reminded myself of the pho goal and how I haven't actually STARTED said goal. And that pho is generally cheap so I GUESS I can go.

So glad I did though. Large portions for cheap and happily clean and not scary for 6th street! The spring rolls had peanut sauce that I WANT TO BATHE IN so some of the awesomeness might rub off by osmosis. The pho was very good and now I feel like I have a solid baseline for what is acceptable when I go out. But never fear, I will be filling you in when I find one that is comparable to Hang's pho. 

One warning I will give is that if you can't stand 80's easy listening, get your stuff to go if you can. The entire time we were at lunch we were serenaded by the sweet musical musings of John Denver.

Please don't take me home to West Virginia.
author: Alexis B.

description: I am a Pho' connoisseur and I've eaten at most of the Vietnamese restaurants in the city and this is one of the best. If you trying not to eat pho, I recommend the #49.
author: Mikee C.

description: I love Miss SaiGon....they deserve a 5 star!!  This place is one of the BEST , CLEANIEST and FRIENDLIEST Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco.  I originally found this restaurant on yelp and I am so glad that it did!!  The food is authentic, flavorful and not to mention GENEROUS PORTION.  The menu has so much choices...over a hundred item and everything looks delicious- it is so hard to choose.  The only downside is that it is located in the hood, but the restaurants still get a lot of business which goes to show that the food is that good.  I will definitely go back when I am shopping in downtown.
author: Eva E.

description:
I liked the restaurant when I walked in. They have a lot of food to choose from whether you like the original pho or something different like a vermicelli noodle bowl or fried rice with vietnamese sausages.

I thought it was interesting how there was a loop of "best of" Celine Dion music (with music video!) playing in the background. Being a huge fan of Celine, I thought it was great.

The food was good and the people were really friendly. Oh, right on with the cucumber in the water. I only got cucumber in my water at a super fancy restaurant, probably paid too much, but not here.
author: Anna T.

description:
So I've had this crazy Vietnamese fever lately. Seriously. I probably eat vermicelli noodles + chicken + vegetables at least three times a week. They all have one thing in common - beautiful, sweet, sweet noodles with the sweet purple sauce that I surprisingly can't spell. Hoison? Hoisin? 

Anyway, this place is funny. The inside is spotless and super clean. The guy was wiping down the inside of kitchen doors with 409 when I walked in. Cheap food, too, but good lord - wear sunglasses while you're walking down 6th from Market so you don't make eye contact with any of the stoned druggies. The place is cheap, though, 7 bucks for a dish isn't bad in this area.
author: Mike G.

description: Great spot for Vietnamese food.  It is in a fringe area south of Market but we take the Muni to 6th and Market and walk a long block to the restaurant.  Wei had super fresh spring rolls with shrimp and pork, a fantastic green papaya salad, Vietnamese pancake and chicken with eggplant.  It's a tasty place and inexpensive.  Check it out!
author: Becky G.

description:
Good stuff. $6.95 for a big 'ol bowl of pretty good combination beef pho. They don't skimp on the noodles, either, which is usually one of my gripes for pho places, so bonus points for that. Fast, friendly service, and tasty food - maybe not worth making a pilgrimage to from the other side of the city, but worth picking over Tu Luan if you're in the mood for Vietnamese food in the area. 

So, their base rating is four stars; they get minus one star from that for not having tendon or tripe in their pho, but they regain that very same star for the never-ending Michael Jackson music video marathon they had playing on all of their four TV screens for the hour or so we were at lunch.
author: JR H.

description: Sketchy neighborhood, but totally worth going for the Pho. Delicious fresh herbs and spices in everything. Very reasonably priced. Good service. Hidden gem for sure!
author: Eva T.

description:
This place just keeps on getting better and better.  While I'm not a fan of the decor/music.  Mainly because I just don't get how ABBA music videos goes along with rice paddy pictures.  I am a fan of them being open on Sundays when no other Vietnamese restaurants in town are.  Don't they know Sundays are jack pot days from everyone that needs a hangover cure from partying late Saturday night?

They redid their menus- again don't get the artsy stuff but can appreciate the effort.  & They expanded their offerings.  Since my last review I've had the calamari, grilled meat combo platter, wonton soup. All were delicious and the service was great.
author: Manohak S.

description:
Delicious food and great portions at the right price. Had a quick dinner her before catching a show and was very impressed. Given the neighborhood...ahem... this place is a little gem. The interior is beautiful the staff was incredibly attentive and polite and a huge menu to choose from.

I highly recommend the Bo xao cari (#60). I would make the trip again just for it!
author: Audrey N.

description: Great pho and the service was good. I ordered a Thai Iced Coffee and they brought it out in a glass and a metal container. Apparently in San Francisco, you have to manually mix it but it tastes so much better that way. My first visit to eating Vietnamese food in San Francisco and so far it's been really good!
author: Cindy K.

description: They have been on the money every time since I had a problem with them. The food remains excellent and the price is right. The pho is great as are the crab rangoon.
author: Scott S.

description:
Live really close by here.  My roommate introduced it to me and I'm glad he did!

We had several dishes/family style.  I don't recall the exact dishes but it included some red meat dishes, a veggie, pad thai (old tried and true!) and fish.  What can I say...it's all good in the hood?  I've had better Viet food (grew up in Socal and spend 2 yrs in san jose), but for what it's worth this place is comparable.  Especially since it's a walk away and I don't have to go to the other ghetto - the TL; ain't nothing tender about that place.  

They even serve brown rice!  Which is my new favorite!  Ambiance was cool and I liked the fact that it was super clean!  Prices are reasonable for dinner..and I heard lunch is even better!  Now I can have my Viet food and disgust with all my roommates the competitive landscape of porn shops that are all within a 1-block radius of this wonderful restaurant!  But really..there must be some form of a differentiation (arcade anyone?).
author: Yup S.

description: Been eating there since they opened (i think around 2007).  Sweet little family that runs it.  They get busy at lunch but will always make an effort to make sure to greet you and ensure your order is proper.  Quality is consistently good.  Prices are competitive for the amount of food and quality.
author: Sam T.

description:
Grand Opening Night for Miss SaiGon Vietnamese Cuisine. It's located on a semi-sketchy corner of SOMA/TL so I applaud the folks for opening up what looks to be a somewhat upscale Vietnamese restaurant.

So opening night, there were just 2 or 3 other occupied tables. Everything was brand spanking new. Plusher chairs, shellacked tables, and smell of new paint. High ceilings give this place a very airy bright feel, as does the panel of green wall. Not exactly an impressive space. More like a simple neighborhood eatery.

So we had the Spring Rolls (2 for $3.25). They were fresh but a little skimpy with just 1 shrimp and 1 slice of pork per roll.

Then we had #25 Bun bo hue ($6.25) which had spicy beef and pork. It was peppery hot with a nice clear broth. What was different about this noodle soup was that it was served with more than just bean sprouts. The raw veggies were a combo basil, cabbage and sprouts. Different. My companion didn't think the Bun Bo Hue was authentic enough though, since it was missing pork blood and hock. (Honestly, I'm happy they left those parts out.)

Also tried the Bo Lu Lac ($7.95). Served with rice and a dry pepper salt dip. The beef was tender and interestingly served with little bits of potato and onion. It was good but I was craving a little more sauce to it.

The management was kind and gave us free dessert to complete the meal - Che Thai, which was a mix of fruits in coconut milk. Actually quite tasty and the green and white jello things gave chew to the dessert.

Seems like if you live around the area, a great take out option. Reasonable prices, decent food and portions and friendly service. I wish them luck in their opening!
author: Cindy W.

description:
Solid Vietnamese food for a little gem in SOMA. Once you get in, you realize they're put a lot of work to make this place a classy establishment; menus, waterfall, and all! They pay a lot of attention to details, and seem to have a decent range of Asian food, not just exclusively Vietnamese food. 

The price is right, and you can get stuffed for under $10. Their portions are pretty generous. Yum.
author: Emily A.

description:
Date:  November 12, 2008 @ 11:45 AM

Occasion:  Lunch Break

Girlfriends:  Jannette and Alexis

Decor:  Asian contemporary.  White leather on wood chairs.  Very immaculate and neat.  Matching porcelain containers for soy sauce, chili sauce, etc instead of the usual mismatched clear glasses.

Ambiance: Casual.

Social Scene:  Office employees  on lunch break.

Service: Polite. Efficient.

Salud!:  1 Thai Iced Tea
               2 Diet Cokes

Taste:  2 Vermicelli Noodles with beef and fried spring rolls ($6.95 ea)
             Beef and beefballs pho ($6.25)

Tab:  $33.00 including tax and tip

What stands out about this place is the owners' attempt to create a casual, immaculate, contemporary space while serving everyday Vietnamese dishes such as pho, vermicelli noodle bowls in the heart of 6th Street.

My gfs really liked their vermicelli dishes. My pho was okay.  It was on the lighter side which made it tasted more salty and lacking in flavor.  I will go back again for "okay" pho.

Side note:   Walk on  Mission to get to this place and avoid walking on 6th Street. If you know the City, you know what I am talking about.
author: Leah E.

description: ** Just realized I mistakenly posted a review here, thinking it was another place! ** I will have to update this once I try the actual Miss Saigon.
author: Cando V.

description: My go to spot for rare beef pho in the hood.
author: Eric V.

description: This is our favorite Vietnamese place in the city. Flavors are authentic and fresh.
author: Lydia M.

description: Foods awesome. Quick. Clean restaurant. Friendly staff. Off top. Beastin.
author: Wais H.

description: would frequent miss saigon when my office was located down the block. Solid pho and excellent service.
author: Robert C.

description:
Very good service. The food is really good as well. The only thing lacking is that the pho is only mediocre as the broth is a bit too oily. Everything else that I've eaten here though has been great.

Everyone who works here is super nice. The restaurant is very clean and so are the bathrooms. It gets really crowded at lunch, but dinner is a different matter.
author: Kevin H.

description: Affordable, fast and delicious.  A perfect lunch spot for me.  I might have to try this for dinner.
author: Michael G.

description:
Excellent -- finally a decent and non-overpriced Vietnamese restaurant (ahem Bong Su?)  in SOMA!

I've been waiting quite a long time ever since I saw the initial renditions of this restaurant in a neighborhood planning mailing.  As part of the ongoing gentrification of SOMA, I was actually surprised the owners agreed to take part in establishing their jewel in the heart of 6th Street.  Luckily, their vision seemed to have been carried out relatively well without cutting costs and/or lowering standards.  The interior is pleasant and the artwork is appealing in a conventional sense.

Originally I thought, "oh hell yeah, a dive Pho place!"  Little did I know that their menu extends well beyond the tried-and-true bowl of Pho Bo (beef noodle soup).  They have quite a selection of traditional and unique Viet dishes, most of which sound and look interesting (their menus have fun little pictures of them as well).

The service was extremely nice and attentive.  Unfortunately, they did not have the simple Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup) which disappointed me.  The waiter told me they might have it in the future so I'll be waiting patiently.  I mean, sometimes you just want a nice big bowl of chicken noodle soup, y'know what I mean?  Shoot...

Their springs rolls were small and didn't have as much meat as I wanted to believe.  They were also filled with too much cabbage/lettuce and not enough vermicelli noodles.  Perhaps if the rolls were a bit bigger, I wouldn't have minded.

A big problem that I've found in this city is that the Vietnamese restaurants don't stick to the more authentic recipes.  For example, I love my spicy Bun bo hue soups with AUTHENTIC pork blood and hock.  Damn, I miss those things... makes me want to go back to San Diego of all places.  I was really hoping Miss SaiGon's Bun bo hue would be different but alas, I should have given up hope before I ventured out north... sigh...

Through the thick of it all, I believe Miss SaiGon has the foundations for something special in this neighborhood -- MY neighborhood.  I'll definitely be going back on a weekly basis since it's so convenient now (I live on the same block -- no, NOT 6th street).

Can't wait to try their other "Dinner" dishes.  Also looking forward to trying their interesting desserts.

Miss SaiGon, I welcome you to SOMA!
author: Eric L.

description: Great Pho at night after drinking. Watch out for your life as you may not make it back to your car alive!!
author: Jared K.

description:
It's walking distance from our place and the food leans towards the healthier side. Lighter on the fish sauce, light on the oil and light on the soy sauce.

My favorites are the PHO and Vermicelli noodle with Eggrolls, bbq pork, and shrimp!

Very friendly staff and super clean dining room.
author: Oanh N.

description: Felt like having Phö with friends before the Auto Show and found this place using Urbanspoon.  Wow, was it good. Better decor than I would have imagined and the food was FANTASTC.
author: Bryon W.

description:
Do yourself a favor and order the garlic noodles!!
Also, the papaya salad was excellent, and so all the other dishes we've ordered. (egg rolls, fried rice, string beans...)
author: Noga R.

description: Food is good and cheap here.  Plenty of seating.  However, it's located in a kind of shady neighborhood.  When you're inside the restaurant, you almost forget what is outside.
author: A t.

description: I went for a grubwithus group. Great ambiance and eager to cater to our needs. Chicken salad was good. Curry was okay. Quality is above average.
author: Vivien S.

description: Good pho, better than any of the ones in the tenderloin. A high 3.5 stars
author: James V.

description:
Miss SaiGon just opened recently so everything in there are super nice, clean and new.  I have to say, i have never had pho in such a "fancy-looking" place before.  The staff are super friendly and enthusiastic.  haha, they have the funniest things playing on their TV...salsa dancing!

The food is alright, nothing special.  Although i do recommend their calamari..it's an appetizer. oh, so i was definitely expecting a piece of lemon in my cup of water..but guess what, they have cucumber instead!
author: Mandy L.

description:
I used to be a big fan of the OTHER Vietnamese place on 6th @ Market, but I've gotten tired of dining there and all the while trying not to think about their health inspection rating.  
That is NOT a problem at Miss Saigon!  Miss Saigon rocks!  It's CLEAN, the staff is super friendly, the food is delicious and the prices are excellent.  You will not be disappointed in this little gem of a restaurant.  
Two of us dined there last night.  Appetizer, two entrees --the bill was less than $20!  And the servings were big enough that we needed a doggie bag. 
Definitely will be a return customer!
author: Russ H.

description: This is my to go place for chicken pho. The broth is incredible and very light tasting with a lot of flavor.
author: H C.

description:
Fresh and good - veggie friendly - try springrolls and the crispy tofu 

Fast and friendly service and to be confirmed clean toilets we just can recommend that place
author: Zera K.

description: Really delicious- I got a chicken pho to go with the spicy beefy broth, and shrimp spring rolls. The prices are great and the staff is really sweet.
author: s b.

description:
Lunch! I love lunch! Its the one meal of the day I can fully enjoy the most.  
Breakfast: I can't really eat that much, only got room for tea and that's it.
Dinner: Eat too much, and you feel like a total fatass before you go to sleep
Lunch: On the other hand,  when it hits noon, stomach starts to growl, and you can EAT, yet if you eat too much its OK, cus you have like 5 hours to burn it!

So when I decided to go have lunch with my FiDi buddy, I was surprised when he said lets grab Vietnamese on 6th Street.  I was like SIXTH STREET?? I am not gonna eat at Tu Lan (which is yummy on the dollar, but not somewhere you would actually DINE at)! 

he was: " no no its this other place, don't worry its not ghetto"

So I was game, and luckily I was!  The outside of Miss. Saigon, looks like a typical blah restaurant front in the 6th street area, nothing special.  But WOW stepped in, and TOTALLY different!  Its VERY clean, roomy, and even stylish!

OK sooo the place isn't ghetto...but hows the food? Cus I'm a total vietnamese food whore, I can eat that stuff 7 days a week, and if its bad, it'll ruin my entire day. So its has to been good.

And it was YUMMY! they had allll the various Viet dishes!! From traditional Pho to their more traditional entree dishes like the Shaken Beef and Garlic noodles, even clay pot!!! Everything reasonable prices as well!

Usually for Viet restaurants, either the Pho is good, and nothing else.  Or the entrees are good and the Pho is bammer.  But NO, they were both awesome!! 

Its a bit far out of the way from FiDi, but its really worth it for the great authentic food, wonderful service, and dirt cheap prices!
author: Deanna T.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because it's Vietnamese owned and I wanna support my vietnamese peeps.  The pho was bland and the bun rieu was let down (barely any crab meat and soup was bland).  Maybe we ordered the wrong items.

+1 for the friendly service and clean decor.
author: Michelle T.

description: Had Pho Tai, egg rolls and chicken wings. Really good service, not sure how the waiter remembered all of our orders, there  was 8 of us and he didnt even write down any of our orders, drinks or appetizers. Clean place, even the restroom! Only annoying thing was the Lady Gaga music videos playing on all the tvs.
author: Dustin D.

description:
To quote the songstress Vanessa Carlton : 

Making my way downtown 
Walking fast 
Faces pass 


Staring blankly ahead 
Just making my way 
Making a way 
Through the crowd 

If I could fall 
Into the sky 
Do you think time 
Would pass me by 
'Cause you know I'd walk 
A thousand miles 
If I could 
Just see you 
Tonight 


No I will not walk a thousand miles to eat here but I will walk 5 long blocks, passing a XXX video store , a gun store and numerous shops along the way. #41 was really tasty and the service was incredibly friendly.
author: Sophia C.

description: Food here is really good but, more importantly, very consistent. Ambiance is the baby of Bare Bones and the 1980s, but a total gem for this neighborhood. Step outside the restaurant and you'll be met with the overpowering smell of trash and urine, with most likely a crazy person or two wandering down the street at any given time. If you can get over that though I totally recommend it, as the price is very reasonable and the food is really good.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Had dinner with friends recently.

Spring rolls, fried egg rolls are not as good as I expected them to be. Ca kho to (clay pot cat fish #86) is really good. Canh chua (sour soup #88) is really good.

I didn't quite feel it for the decor and ambiance, nothing to write home about. Service was quick.

Come for a quick and good bite with fast service. But nothing to impress your out-of-town friends with.
author: Mango M.

description:
I met up with a friend here and ended up staying 2 hours LOL. First off, its very very CLEAN...and the window out into 6th street offers free entertainment. You get the occasional bum peeking in throwing kisses in your direction, nice.

I had a BBQ pork vermicelli which was the typical size for the price. Our glasses were refilled often. The waiter didn't pressure us to leave after we finished eating. Everything about Miss SaiGon is reasonable.
author: Christina C.

description:
So I usually go here about once a week because I live in the apartments right next door to them.

Decor and staff:
Its always clean, staff always remembers me and  even when i just walk by they have a huge smile on their face as they wave me by. The decor inside helps out due to 6th street grungy run down look but the area has change lil by lil so this restaurant is a nice help to the area. The managers always have small chit chat with me each time I go there and extremely friendly and always offer me water and a dessert while I get my food to go. 

Food:
So I usually get one of the pho dishes or the vermicelli dishes here. The pho bowls are always hot and large so you'll leave full and the bowls are only about 7-8 bucks each which is the normal price in the city from what I've seen. The vermicelli dishes are great for when you want something light yet fulling. Especially for hot days and your not in the mood for a burger or pizza, this is a nice treat to cool you down. The food is always freshly prepared and its amazing how quick they get the food out to you.

Service:
Quick and efficient. Staff is always observant making sure your not missing anything and dont roll their eyes if you need something like other restaurants and shops on 6th street. Staff actually smiles here and are sincere when they say thank you. Nice casual feel where you are there to enjoy your meal rather then stuff it down your throat, give them your money and leave. 

Overall: Love this place, I used to go 2 Tu Lan all the time and just tried to ignore the smell, bums, rude workers,  or view cause their pho was great and cheap! But now that Miss Saigon opened up, I can sit down and relax without being asked for a cigerette or a quarter. Great owner and staff. Fast food. And cheap!!! Nothing bad to say.....YAY MISS SAIGON!
author: Charlie D.

description:
We've been looking for a good Vietnamese restaurant and Miss Saigon certainly fits the bill.  As lots of people have pointed out, this is not in the nicest area of the city, but inside it is clean, pleasant and both the food and service are great.  It's a convenient distance from the Century theatres at Westfield mall and also Metreon.

We had wonton soup (we always try this since there was a hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese restaurant in Hartford, CT that had great wonton soup), garlic chicken (ga xao gung) and a beef dish that I can't remember.  The soup and the chicken were both great and the beef was good (but we'll probably try the bo luc lac next time).

We'll definitely come back here (but probably not too late at night).
author: Richard M.

description:
Nice space in an OK hood south of Market.  I went here for lunch and was sat quickly.  The menu is huge like 2" thick!  They have daily lunch specials and numerous options for under $8.  I had the lemon grass chicken with vermicelli noodles.  The flavors were a little bland but I added some chile sauce and it was all good.  The space is very open and has a great green accent wall behind the bar and was very clean.
Service was pretty good except the bus boy took forever to give me more water!  Overall a great value for the food and it is close to my office.  I will be back again.
author: Prescott R.

description: Yummy Vietnamese and surprise papaya salad to go with free range pho
author: Sean H.

description:
5 stars for the imperial rolls, gonna see if they can make it non-seafood.  but the texture of the wrap is amazing.  u have to order this if you never tried it.

4 stars for pork vermicelli, pork very tender and good flavor.

3 stars for pho, i only tried a little from my gf's bowl, but it was meh
author: Michael R.

description: I'm glad there is now decent pho in SOMA that is open during dinner hours.  The restaurant is clean and the staff is friendly enough.  We had pho and the spring rolls.  The spring rolls were tasty and fresh.  The pho was good - although the beef slices were a bit tougher than I like, the broth was very tasty and not greasy.  I will definitely come by again.  Parking was easy on a weekday night.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Absolutely no complaints. I eat phò  regularly up and down the coast, and I have had only a couple that were "better" than this. By the looks of what others were having around me, I will have to be more adventurous the next time I'm back. But, when you are craving phò...you know. :-)'. 

Sometimes, I have come away from a Vietnamese restaurant feeling somewhat dissed because all I had for dinner was a soup and coffee; not the case at all, here. The waiters were quite gracious and efficient...and not bad on the eyes, either!

Prices seemed reasonably consistent with what I'm used to, especially for the Bay Area.
author: Chris P.

description:
Friendliest service ever .... and a great value just a short walk away from Westfield Shopping Centre.  I've been there twice now, and both times I was welcomed with smiles and asked to come back when I finished.

The dishes are pretty good .... above average in my humble opinion. The seafood pot dishes seem especially good.  I couldn't tell you the name of what I've tried so far, but it all has been very tasty. The summer rolls are pretty good .... though the rice paper seems a bit chewier than what I'm used to.  Still, for $3.50 or so?  Great price!

I believe this is a business that two entrepreneurial spirits were able to start with the help of non-profit 6th street business advocates Urban Solutions.  I will certainly go back to Miss Saigon for future dinners ... and encourage you to give them a try as well.
author: Jamie W.

description: I love pho but I usually feel a little gross after eating your traditional beef pho. Soo the free-range chicken pho here is the perfect solution. It's relatively healthy without tasting healthy (the chili sauce and sriracha also help with that). The -1 star is cuz it took a little longer than I would've liked for the food to come out.
author: Lilian W.

description:
I've been there a handful of times and ordered different items every visit, and EVERYTHING was excellent!! The service is superb and the price is very reasonable.  Timely service too! The only bad thing i could say is that they do not serve alcohol, yet.  Very clean even though in a crappy neighborhood.  

soups are delish
dinner items are delish
appetizers are appeteasers

i'm a regular there now!
author: Angela C.

description:
Definitely go for dinner, when it's a lot slower and you have more time to try the food.  The restaurant is spotless, service very friendly, and the food is delicious and fresh.  It's difficult with California ingredients to get most of the unique taste of the food I had in Vietnam a few years ago, but this comes close enough.
